PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to raise a matter of privilege.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I am indebted to you, Mr Speaker, for the opportunity to raise this matter at this stage. I wish to raise a matter of privilege relating to the Freedom of Information Act and the way it is being administered by the Government. My submission is that there is a potential breach of privilege constituted by four matters. At the outset I shall simply list those matters and then go on to explain as briefly as I can why they constitute a breach of privilege.

SPEECH.PARA: The first is a letter I have received from the Department of Territories, a letter addressed to me dated 25 September 1985. The second is a letter from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet dated 2 October 1985. I shall say two things about those letters at the outset. The first is that I have made photostat copies of them with which I will provide you when I have finished my remarks. The second thing I shall say about those letters is that they are only examples, because a number of members of parliament have received letters from Ministers and departments which in substance say that applications or requests under the Freedom of Information Act will not be processed until the members of parliament have paid fees which have been charged and levied on the members of parliament. That is the substance of the complaint I have.

The third matter of privilege relates to a Freedom of Information Act memorandum, known as revised memorandum No. 41. Those letters I have referred to and revised FOI memorandum No. 41 in effect in substance, to put it as briefly and concisely as possible, maintain the right of the Government to levy charges on members of parliament and on journalists, and indeed on others, for compliance with Freedom of Information Act requests. The fourth matter which I maintain constitutes a potential breach of privilege is the whole Government attitude which is now being implemented by departments and Ministers with respect to processing requests under the Freedom of Information Act lodged by members of this Parliament.

Perhaps I can illustrate the matter further by quoting briefly from both the letters to which I have referred. With respect to the letter from the Department of Territories, the FOI Co-ordinator has said in substance that a charge must be made before my request under the Freedom of Information Act will be proceeded with further. He then goes on to say:
No further action will be taken on your request until the deposit notified in the enclosed leaflet has been received.

With respect to the letter from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the author of the letter, who describes himself as the Deputy Director of the Policy Development Branch, Office of Youth Affairs, says, among other things:
I am writing to advise you, however, that I have decided that a charge should apply in your case and that I estimate that it will take half an hour to locate all the documents.
He then goes on at a later stage in the letter to say:
You are now required to pay an amount of $27.50 before your request can be processed further.
He goes on over the page to say:

Under section 19 (3) (b) of the F.O.I. Act, we have 45 days from receipt of your request within which to notify you of a decision. Counting of the 45 days will be suspended from tomorrow's date (ie, 3 October) and will resume on the day on which your payment of $27.50 is received.

So, in other words, the substance of all that correspondence and other correspondence that we have received is, first of all, one must pay a charge before the application will be processed under the Freedom of Information Act, and, secondly, the time will not run until one sends the money in. The Department is saying: `When you send the money in, we will continue to look for these documents and consider then, in our magnanimity, whether we will provide them to you'.

A number of points need to be made. First, a charge is being made on members of parliament to provide them with information to which they are entitled and to which they should be entitled without paying that charge or without having any impediments put in their way. The second point is that departments and Ministers are now adopting an attitude that no further work will be done under the Act-this is work which, incidentally, they are obliged to do under the law-until payment is made.

The argument can be put very concisely and it goes along these lines. The first point is that members of parliament, in a proper pursuit of their responsibility and role are, in our submission, entitled to government information. What we see here in the totality is an attempt to frustrate this work, to frustrate members of parliament in their attempt to obtain legitimate government information which they need to fulfil their role and to do their job properly. An attempt is being made to impose charges and to dealy work under the Act until payment is made. This is an interference with the proper and legitimate work of a member of parliament and it should be stopped.

Secondly, it is very clear that what we have here is a delaying tactic which is designed solely to defer and postpone the revealing of sensitive material which the Government has. The Government will put every obstacle in the way of members of parliament to prevent them from receiving this material. Thirdly, I must concede that there is a right to apply for a remission. However, in reply to that, we say that this is no defence whatsoever for the simple reason that members of parliament should not have obstacles and delaying tactics placed in their way when they are simply doing nothing but seeking information. All members of this Parliament on both sides of the House should be concerned with that as the primary objective, that is, the member of parliament is entitled to obtain information from the Government if he is to perform his job properly. He should not be subject to delaying tactics, appeal procedures, a trip to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or perhaps a trip to the Federal Court before he can obtain information to which he is properly and legitimately entitled.

The fourth point that should be made briefly is that it might well be said that the charges are comparatively slight but I am aware of other cases where the Government has sought to levy very substantial charges on members of parliament before applications under the Act are complied with. For instance, I know of one case where a senator has been asked for $900 cash on the knocker before-

TALK.START.PARA: — I know of one involving $2,000.

—The honourable member for O'Connor informs me of another case of apparently $2,000. This simply emphasises the magnanimity and the enormity of the obstacle which is being placed in the way of members of parliament. It may be only $27.50 in my case. However, as the amount increases, the obstacles that are being put deliberately in the way of members of parliament pursuing their proper task are increased.

—Order! I think the Deputy Leader of the Opposition should realise that he is entitled to put his matter of privilege. I think he is now reaching the stage of debating the matter which would carry on if I happen to rule that there was a prima facie case. I would ask him to round off his remarks.
—I will, indeed, Mr Speaker. I will simply make one final point. I have referred to the Freedom of Information Act memorandum No. 41.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, again I have made a copy of the relevant page for you so that you can read it as a whole. Without wishing to delay the House, I simply say that it contains this sentence:
There is no automatic remission of charges in the public interest for Members of Parliament or journalists.
We maintain that it is clear beyond any argument at all that it is in the public interest for members of parliament to have access to this information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition should realise that he is now debating the point.

—Mr Speaker, when you read that document you will see just how strong that point is. Finally, I say simply that the matter of privilege is that obstacles are being placed in the way of members of parliament performing their tasks. They are not simply obstacles which apply to the community at large, but are confined to members of parliament because, in this case, the letters are addressed to a member of parliament. The FOI memorandum specifically relates to members of parliament and rules for members of parliament which are specifically designed to frustrate the proper work of a member of parliament. The Government should not cover up. It should come clean.
—Order! The honourable member is now debating this issue.
—I am sorry, Mr Speaker. I do feel strongly about this matter.
—I understand that but I am required to run the House in accordance with its Standing Orders.

—Yes. I simply conclude by saying, Mr Speaker, that to assist your deliberations on this matter I have made some copies of the appropriate correspondence and of the appropriate page of that memorandum. Mr Speaker, I will provide them to the Clerk so that you can read them and consider your decision on what we regard as a grievous abuse of the privileges of members of parliament.

—Order! The honourable member has certainly raised the matter at the earliest opportunity. I must accept that he has raised a matter of privilege. He has raised it under several heads. I think it would serve the interests of the House if I considered the letters and material he has placed before the House and made a statement to the House at a later hour this day.

—by leave-The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), was kind enough to phone my office and say that he was going to raise the matter of privilege. I did not know what the matter was and I make no comment about it. I just ask you, Mr Speaker, when considering the matter to recognise that the question of freedom of information is covered by way of statute of 1982. The statute provides for exemption from any fees in certain circumstances. Of course, fees had to be charged, as announced, because of the cost of administering the Freedom of Information Act, but there can be discretion exercised so that no fees are charged. Mr Speaker, I ask you to identify the matters which relate to what the honourable gentleman has said about the matter of privilege. Also, Mr Speaker, one of the other matters which you will no doubt take into consideration, of course, is that members of parliament are entitled to get information other than by the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act.
—I think there is no need for me to comment on the statement made by the Attorney-General. I will make a statement to the House at a later hour this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX (INDIVIDUALS) BILL 1985INCOME TAX (COMPANIES, CORPORATE UNIT TRUSTS AND SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 1985MEDICARE LEVY BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 September, on motion by Mr Hurford:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill concurrently with the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill, the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Bill and the Medicare Levy Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A package of four Bills is being debated. They are the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill, the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Bill and the Medicare Levy Bill. Some of the measures derive from the Budget statement of August by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Other measures come from other statements on taxation matters, for example, which were made some considerable time ago. The Opposition will not be opposing these taxation measures but we will have something to say about some of them with which we are in disagreement partially or wholly.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer firstly to the two straightforward income tax measures which derive from the Budget-the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill 1985 and the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Bill 1985. Those two Bills put into effect the tax arrangements in the 1985 Budget for the current financial year.

It is hard to remember the Budget to which these matters refer because it was sandwiched in between a May statement, a July set of changes and the tax measures which were brought in in September. The Budget is almost a matter of stale history, given the nature of the tax announcements made subsequently. So the Opposition will not pass any particular comment on these two measures; it merely notes that they form part of that forgotten Budget.

The next measure I would like to refer to is the Medicare Levy Bill 1985. It sets the Medicare levy rates for this financial year and, unless Parliament otherwise decides, for the next financial year. It removes the ceiling on incomes on which the levy is chargeable from $70,000-the amount at which it was set when the Medicare scheme was set up-and makes the levy more like an addition to income tax. This is yet another promise that has been broken by the Government. When Medicare first came in it was claimed that the Medicare levy was, in effect, an insurance payment and that it would have a ceiling. That ceiling has been removed and, therefore, the levy is no different from income tax. In a few moments I will talk about some of the anomalies that that raises.

Just as the Government has broken its promise on the Medicare levy, it has also broken its promise on the privacy questions of Medicare by leaking doctors' incomes to the Press. We have no guarantee that there will not be further changes upwards in the Medicare levy in order to meet rising costs in hospitals and in overservicing through bulk billing. I draw particular attention to anomalies in the levy arrangements. All my comments will be based on the 1984-85 figures because they are the ones I have had analysed. The changes of August 1985 do not materially alter the situation. Obviously some of the figures will change but there is no real change to the points I wish to make. The regulations have been framed in such an inept manner that intrinsically the levy is raised equitably only in the case of single persons whose incomes are greater than the levy threshold. It is sheer coincidence that in a non-prescribed or standard family-by a non-prescribed family I mean a family which does not have, for example, a veteran who is entitled to free medical treatment and should be called a prescribed person-both breadwinners pay an equitable levy when each has an income higher than the upper limit of the single person's levy threshold.

In setting the family levy threshold at 1.66 times the single person's threshold-in 1984-85 the figures were $11,803 and $7,110 respectively-there is clear and specific recognition that an equitable means basis for family partners is significantly lower than that for single persons. We say that that is fair enough. However, by then raising the family levy contributions on an individual income earner's basis-in this sense the levy is really a tax; it is not an insurance contribution-one gets the following extraordinary outcome: Firstly, where either partner earns $7,110 or less, that part of the family income remains levy free, however much of the income of the other family partner exceeds $7,110. Secondly, where each partner earns not less than $7,111 and not more than $7,483, each pays less than the full levy up to a total family income of $14,966 per annum. Thirdly, where each partner earns $7,110 or less, both are completely exempt from the levy up to a total family income of $14,220 per annum. But if one partner earns more than $7,110 and the other partner's income is so low that the family's total income falls in the range of $11,804 to $12,424 the regulations require that the levy be raised on the basis of the aggregated family income. So virtually the full levy may be paid on a total family income of $12,424.

These rules create enormous anomalies. To illustrate the anomalies I will cite some examples of possible configurations of family incomes on which totally anomalous levies are raised for Medicare. The first example is where the first family partnership income is $30,000 and the second partner has a nil income. The one per cent levy raises $300. However, if the family income is split up with one partner earning $25,405 and the second partner earning at the then income tax threshold of $4,595, again giving a total income of $30,000, the levy is only $254.05. So the family income in both cases is $30,000 but the levy in the first case is $300 and in the second case is $254.05.

My second example concerns family incomes which are different but on which exactly the same total levy is paid. The first family has a single income earner who earns $12,425. The other person has a nil income. The total income is $12,425, which is the family upper limit. The levy is $124.25. The other family earns a total, not of $12,000-odd, but of $19,000-odd, consisting of an income of $12,425 for the first partner and $7,110, which is the single levy threshold, for the second partner. The total income is $19,535. The levy is identical with that of the first family, $124.25. One family earns a total of $12,425 and pays a levy of $124.25 whereas the second family earns $19,535 and pays exactly the same levy of $124.25.

If this were purely an income tax the amounts would follow automatically but this levy for health insurance purposes was claimed to be equitable. Yet we get these extraordinary anomalies. I cite another example in which almost identical payments are made on the family incomes. In the first case, the income is $11,803 for the first partner and $621 for the second partner, totalling $12,424. The levy is $117.99. In this case there is a family reduction clause, which I mentioned earlier, and which was applied to the levy paid by the first partner. In the second case the first partner earns $11,803 and the second earns $7,110, which is the single levy threshold for the second partner, so there is no family reduction. They have a total income of $18,913 and pay a levy almost identical to that in the first case, $118.03. So the first family income is just over $12,000 and the levy is $117 and the second family earns nearly $19,000 and virtually the same levy is paid.

I will now consider a non-standard family where one partner is a prescribed person; that is, a person who is entitled to all medical and hospital treatment at public expense-such as a veteran under certain circumstances. We also find astonishing anomalies in this category. The first example is of a single income family where the prescribed partner earns $28,000 and the non-prescribed partner has no income. The total family income is $28,000 and the total family levy is $140. The second example is where the prescribed partner's income is $20,890 and the non-prescribed partner's income is $7,110, the single levy threshold. The total family income is exactly the same as that cited earlier, $28,000. The levy paid is $104.45.

Here we have two families, each one with a pensioner entitled to free medical benefits. The levy which has to be paid by the pensioners for their partners is half the standard levy rate, regardless of what those partners earn. In the cases I have mentioned both families have incomes of $28,000 but the first family pays a levy of $140 and the second family pays a levy of $104.45.

I mention also a third case in which each partner earns $14,000. Again, although that is the same $28,000 in total, $210 is paid in levy-over twice the levy payment of the previous example. Finally, I mention a family where the income of the prescribed partner is nil and the non-prescribed partner's income is $28,000. In other words, the spouse of the pensioner gets an income of $28,000. In this case the levy is paid at the full rate of $280. In the lowest case of a family with an income of $28,000 a levy of $104.45 is paid. In the highest case the family with the same income of $28,000 pays $280 in Medicare levy.

I know it is tedious for the House to hear such detailed figures but these matters affect families in a very definite way. I have also had research done which seems to indicate that if these levies were all applied on a family income basis and on a totally equitable basis probably there would be an extra revenue component to the Commonwealth of about $24m. That revenue could be used for other purposes, for example, reducing the levy so that people would not have to pay any more overall. If the anomalies were removed that would mean an extra $24m in revenue for the Commonwealth and a more equitable situation for families in similar circumstances.

What these examples point out is that the whole business of the Medicare levy is a nonsense. It was never intended to be a real payment for medical and hospital services; it was always just a tax. However much the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) tried to make out at the time of the introduction of Medicare that it was an identified payment towards one's health costs and health insurance, they have never been able to sustain that argument either as to the total amount raised by way of the levy, in relation to the total health costs of the nation, nor have they been able to distinguish it in any way from a simple tax collection. Therefore, the removal of the $70,000 limit is one factor which proves that it is merely a tax. Also the totally anomalous cost to families in the same overall circumstances shows again that it is merely a tax that has nothing to do with health costs at all.

I now move to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 which is a grab-bag of a large number of measures of various kinds. I will deal with those measures in turn. The first measure relates to non-leveraged finance leasing and similar arrangements. Announcements were made on 15 May and 16 December 1984 which were designed to clamp down on certain taxation arrangements whereby taxation exempt bodies such as State statutory corporations were able to make arrangements with people who would otherwise pay tax so that those people did not pay the full measure of tax.

Earlier legislation was introduced in 1984 to deal with leveraged leasing. Those measures contained in that legislation deny to lessors tax deductions attributable to ownership of plant where the leveraged arrangements involve plant leased or in real end-use in tax exempt activities, including by tax-exempt public authorities. In fact that arose out of the Eraring power station lurk introduced by the Wran Government in which leasing arrangements relating to power stations in New South Wales were put into place by the State Government with the obvious intention of defrauding the Commonwealth of taxation revenues. The Federal Labor Government in effect had to legislate against the actions of its State counterparts. The legislation also related to leveraged leasing arrangements involving overseas plant used by non-residents, such as aircraft leased by foreign airlines and the sale and lease-back of existing plant already in use by the lessee or real end-user.

The reason for introducing the measures was that the arrangements involved financial benefits to the lessee and lessor which led to a substantial cost to the Commonwealth revenue. We supported those measures. It had become clear following that that the problems did not stop at leverage leasing, but also extended to ordinary finance leasing by governments and tax exempt government authorities. This measure extends the prohibitions to non-leverage finance leasing and similar arrangements. The Opposition supports these measures, which are said to involve savings to the revenue of $100m or so in 1985-86 and larger amounts in subsequent years depending, of course, on what will happen by the extension of those arrangements.

The next item in this Bill is the statutory loan back rules. There was an announcement on 11 March 1985 relating to the rules for investment by a superannuation fund in a sponsoring employer's business. This Bill sets a maximum of 10 per cent for such investments by the trustees of the superannuation fund in the business to which the superannuation fund is related. There are transitional arrangements over 10 years to enable existing funds to adjust by the effluxion of time and the moving in of new people so that they meet this requirement at the end of 10 years. If they do not, there is a 30 per cent tax rate penalty. The Opposition has some reservations about this. The purpose of it, presumably, and this is a reasonable argument, is that there should not be investments by the trustees to any great extent in the business in which the beneficiaries are working because it might tie the resultant benefits too much to the fortunes of that business. There might also be concerns about the manner in which the directors of a business might proceed with such funds if they had ill intentions of some kind. There are some genuine concerns there.

Our concern about this measure is that such arrangements do give the employees of a smallish concern a chance to participate in the profitable growth of the company within which they work. It is another form of incentive for people to feel that they are very much part of a business. In good situations where there is a good relationship between the management and the work force, arrangements of this kind, if not taken too far, can be quite beneficial both to employees and to management. We are a little concerned about the degree of regulation being introduced. We are not going to vote against this measure but we would like to register our concern over that aspect of it.

The next part of the Bill relates to superannuation arrangements for the self-employed and proposed an increase in the deduction from $1,200 to $1,500 a year from 1985-86. We welcome this measure. When we were in government we introduced this deduction. I might say that it was opposed by the then Leader of the Opposition, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). He did not approve of it. We are pleased that the Government seems at least to have recognised some of the error of its ways at that time and has increased the deduction. However, it is still at a very modest level. When one also takes into account the fact that the Government is bringing in a capitals gains tax which will be in effect a very severe reduction on the capital accumulation for retirement of small business people, we think that this gesture will be dwarfed by that other measure. There is absolutely no doubt that in a very large number of family businesses, individual businesses, the capital accumulation and the build up of good will owing to the skills and the entrepreneurial talent of the proprietors is seen as a contribution by them towards a retirement benefit. An asset is being built up and, indeed, often throughout their working lives to a very large extent they deny themselves week by week income in order to build up that asset for their retirement.

The capital gains tax that has been foreshadowed by the Treasurer strikes at the very heart of that process. It is one of the reasons why we are utterly opposed to that capital gains tax, why we will oppose it in this House, why we will vote against it in both Houses, and why we will repeal it when we get back into government. There is also a change in the lump sum termination payments. For people aged 55 or more the first $50,000 in superannuation payments is currently taxed at 15 per cent. This sum is being raised to $55,000 to take account of inflation. Rather, it is not directly for inflation, it is a measure which more or less makes up for inflation. We support that.

The next matter is much more controversial. I refer to the removal of the $2,000 concessional expenditure rebate. A medical expenses rebate is being put in its place but only medical expenses over $1,000 will merit a rebate. The $2,000 rebate has been completely abolished. This is the final nail in the coffin of this particular measure. Some years ago there was in the taxation system an incentive for families to provide for themselves in various ways. They were assisted by deductions for education, rates and so on and these deductions were seen as an essential part of a taxation system which aided families. Those benefits have gradually been removed by this Government. The ceiling below which one is not able to claim anything is rapidly being pushed up. It got up to $2,000 and now it is being removed altogether. The Government says that it affects only 6 per cent of taxpayers. After the various changes that have occurred, they are the only ones left who are able to take any advantage of it. The Opposition wishes to raise in the strongest possible terms its opposition to the way in which this has been done over a period and it does believe that there should be a proper incentive for families to provide, for example, for the education of their children and to pay rates on their homes. There ought to be some incentive within the system for such self-provision. Obviously this Government does not agree with that. In fact, there is hardly anything on the tax side of things in its various statements to aid the family. In contrast the Opposition maintains its policy on both optional income splitting within families for taxation purposes and child care rebates.

The next item, which no doubt is close to the hearts of some government Ministers, is the exemption from tax of animal racing clubs. This formed part of a curious trilogy of measures in the Budget which included a wholesale tax exemption on imported thoroughbreds and more generous livestock valuation options. We wondered why these measures were brought in in an otherwise colourless Budget. There was speculation at the time as to whether the Treasurer had gone off antique clocks and on to racehorses, and there was speculation about the betting habits of the Cabinet. We now find, following the more recent measure involving the quarantining of farm losses, that the racing confraternity is up in arms with the Government for having taken measures which savagely affect it. Therefore we regard the two measures taken together as a very curious set. There is probably something behind it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be suspicious, Jim.

—The honourable member asks me not to be suspicious but after the last few days, with the Australian Bicentennial Auithority matter and how long it took us to find out what was behind that, we will be sniffing around to see whether there is anything suspicious about it. We might ask a few more questions. The next item concerns local government election expenses. The Government has generously allowed aldermen and councillors a $1,000 deduction for their election expenses. Expense deductions have been allowable to State and Federal members of parliament and it has been unfair that aldermen and councillors did not have at least some benefit in this respect. The Opposition does not oppose that. However, we will be quite interested to see how this will be used by the members of the Sydney City Council, which has been undergoing some turmoil recently with by-elections and the like, and whether after they are sacked it will be the same group of councillors who come back for the $1,000 deductions in the subsequent election when the Liberals get back into power and restore the City Council.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer next to social security beneficiary rebates. The maximum tax rebates and taxable income levels at which the rebates begin to shade out for taxpayers in receipt of social security benefits, unemployment benefit, sickness benefit or special benefits is to be increased to ensure that people wholly or mainly dependent on these benefits pay no tax.

We obviously agree with that sensible measure. The next item relates to gifts. Tax deductibility is extended for gifts to the Australian Academy of Humanities and also the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists. We congratulate those two bodies on their success in getting past this extremely difficult hurdle and we wish them every success in their further fund raising endeavours. The measure relating to provisional tax sets the rate at which the income of taxpayers who pay provisional tax will be assumed to rise in 1985-86 over income levels in 1984-85 and increases it by 11 per cent. That is a fairly straightforward measure about which we will say nothing. People who pay provisional tax will be much more interested in the requirement to make quarterly provisional tax payments in the new tax package. That is of much more concern to them.

The next part of the Bill relates to co-operation between revenue authorities. Measures were announced on 20 December 1983 but, presumably, there have been lengthy discussions with the State authorities. The purpose is to help State authorities counter avoidance and evasion of State and Territory taxes by authorising them to carry out investigations in the Australian Capital Territory. This will enable State tax office people to come into these hallowed precincts, perhaps not within this chamber, to check whether residents of the Australian Capital Territory are evading State taxes. There are also other reciprocal arrangements with the States and Territories which will bring in complementary legislation. We have no quarrel with that. It seems to be a sensible measure on the assumption that the State tax officers are all clean. We presume that they are and we hope that they will continue to be. We will keep a close eye on that. Finally, there are some secrecy provisions in the tax legislation. These provisions are a tidying up measure which is not of fundamental importance. It has no effect on the revenue and we have no quarrel with it.

The tax package is a very mixed bag of Bills, many of them unexceptionable. But within the Bills are some rather unfortunate measures. The one I leave with the House for reflection is the Medicare levy, which has a wholly anomalous impact on families. Families on the same income pay quite disparate rates. I am surprised that members on the Government side have not taken up this matter until now. If the Medicare levy is meant to be any form of insurance against ill health and the costs associated with it it should surely relate to the capacity of families to pay and not be merely an addition to the income tax scales which brings about these extraordinary anomalies. With that, I say that the Opposition will not oppose the passage of these Bills either here or in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are in the process of considering a package of four Bills, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill, the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Bill and the Medicare Levy Bill, which cover a whole range of issues involved with the taxation system. These Bills are the means by which the Government has taken advantage of the opportunity to continue the process that it started when it came into government to identify major deficiencies within the taxation system and then to devise and introduce legislative provisions to overcome those deficiencies, to plug some of the loopholes and to overcome some of the inequities, injustices and impediments to economic efficiency in the taxation system and the way in which it operates.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills cover a whole range of different aspects of the taxation system. In the time available to any of the members who will participate in this debate it will not be possible for them to deal with all the issues. It will obviously become necessary for us to home in on the issues in this basket of legislation about which we are particularly concerned.

The most comprehensive of the Bills is the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) to which reference was made by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) in his remarks when leading for the Opposition. In passing, may I say that when the honourable member referred to changes in the superannuation provisions in that Bill, he also referred to the Government's proposal concerning a capital gains tax. I would like to make passing reference to that as well. I know that it is not part of this legislation, but I want to respond to the observation made by the honourable member because inherent in what he said was a serious misunderstanding about the nature and purpose of that proposal.

People who are familiar with the Government's proposal, if they are honest, will recognise that the essential purpose of that quite nominal capital gains tax is not only to pick up tax on what amounts to an alternative form of income for those who have been able to benefit from capital gains as their income to ensure in a very nominal way that they will pay tax on their capital gains income-the same as my constituents pay tax on their wage and salary income. The proposal is also designed to ensure that that loophole which has existed in the taxation legislation up to the present time could not itself be used to rort the taxation system by those people who quite cleverly have been able to use contrived and artificial and blatant schemes to transform their income from an incomes stream to a capital gain in order to avoid their taxation responsibility. This needs to be spelt out because a lot of deliberate misrepresentation has been undertaken by members of the Opposition. They refer particularly to the small businessman whom they claim puts all his time into building up the business, not taking out as an income flow on a week to week or year to year basis the accumulating financial benefits involved in that business, but choosing rather at the time he disposes of the business to get that capital gain then in a tax free form. That is okay, but when my constituents work overtime in their jobs and receive their income for that overtime in the form of an income flow each week and they pay tax on their income, I see no good reason to believe that people who put their own overtime into their own business and then seek to get the benefit of that accumulated value when they dispose of that business should not pay tax on it as well.

Any suggestion to the contrary is quite absurd, inequitable and anomalous. I shall not tolerate it and I am delighted that the Government will not tolerate it. Let me make it clear that my constituents will not tolerate it either. There is also no sense in Opposition members going up into my constituency and suggesting to my constituents that in some way there is an unfair burden being placed on small businessmen, because my constituents will not wear it. My constituents are much more perceptive and exercise much greater judgment about the inequity of the present taxation system than to be hoodwinked by all those conmen on the Opposition benches.

I want now to refer to some of the provisions of the tax package of Bills with which we are now dealing. The honourable member for Mackellar also referred to these provisions in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) concerning superannuation changes. There are two of them in particular. The first provides for the increase from $1,200 to $1,500 as the maximum annual income tax deduction allowable for contributions to approved superannuation funds by self-employed persons or employees not covered by employer-funded schemes. That is an important provision and it reflects the Government's recognition of the fact that a legitimate purpose is served by approved superannuation funds for self-employed persons. As a result of providing in this legitimate way for their own retirement some form of taxation concession is to be allowed.

The second major provision of this legislation concerning superannuation involves the adjustment from $50,000 to $55,000 in the amount of the superannuation lump sum payment. A person aged 55 years or more would be exempt from the 30 per cent taxation which is to be applied to lump sum payments in excess of that and will be subject to a tax rate of only 15 per cent. That was an undertaking the Government gave when it introduced the provisions for the taxing of lump sum superannuation benefits. There has been a lot of misunderstanding about that, too. It has been suggested that a person who saves, a person who puts his money into a superannuation fund in order to provide for his own retirement, should not, when he retires, have any of that accumulated superannuation benefit taxed to any greater extent than had been provided for before when, for example, 5 per cent of the lump sum was added to the superannuitant's income in the last year of employment and was then taxed at his marginal tax rate. The Government provided for substantial adjustment to those provisions.

I want to place on record the case for those particular adjustments which were made at that time. It was not just this Government but a series of governments over a period of time which have been prepared to make taxation concessions available to ensure that people would provide for their own retirement-that is, to reduce the pressure and the burden on the Commonwealth in its acceptance of its responsibility to pay age pensions. The current cost of all those concessions to Commonwealth revenue is about $2.6 billion every year. I refer to all the concessions that have been provided by this and former governments to encourage people to provide for their own retirement income, not for any other purpose. I will say more about that shortly. That $2.6 billion is additional to this year's provision in the 1985-86 Budget for a total of $7.5 billion to be spent by the Commonwealth to support its age and service pension schemes. That is a very substantial annual amount paid by the Commonwealth to assist people in their years of retirement: $2.6 billion plus for all the concessions under the superannuation arrangement and $7.5 billion in this current year for age and service pensions.

The following tax concessions were provided, and some still are provided, to encourage people to provide for their retirement. The first is that the employer contributions to superannuation funds are deductible from the assessable income for those employers. Like wage costs, they are a contribution to superannuation funds on behalf of their employees and are treated as another cost of running the business. Thus they are tax deductible.

Thus, they are treated as labour costs to the employers and they represent a form of deferred income for the employees. However, this deferred income is not taxed as it accumulates and as the employer pays it into a superannuation fund on behalf of the employee.

The second benefit for superannuation purposes was that investment income, which the superannuation fund earned as a result if investing those contributions by the employer into the superannuation fund, was tax free. That is the second major concession which has been and continued to be made by the Commonwealth to encourage people, as I say, to put money into a superannuation fund and provide for their own retirement income.

The third concession which was available to superannuation contributors was that provided for under the concessional expenditure arrangement, which this legislation seeks to eliminate as well, by which people whose concessional expenditure in various identified categories exceeded $2,000 could claim the balance as a rebate. Of course, this legislation seeks to eliminate that practice in general. However, this concession will still apply under the arrangements in this legislation which relate to superannuation contributions for self-employed persons. In fact, the value of this deduction will be increased from $1,200 to $1,500.

Those tax concessions were very substantial indeed. The only reason they were provided was to encourage people to provide, as I have said before, for their own retirement income. I emphasise the word `income'. An amount of almost $3 billion a year in the form of Commonwealth assistance to superannuation funds was not provided, at a cost to taxation and at a cost to other taxpayers, to enable people on retirement to provide themselves with a lump sum nest egg, to take trips, to relocate their residences, to trade up the quality of their homes, to buy new cars or to invest in real estate. The $3 billion worth of assistance from the Commonwealth was not provided for those purposes. However, it was used for those purposes.

The fact is that only about 50 per cent of the Australian work force is included in superannuation schemes. Many of my constituents are paying higher rates of taxation as a result of the need to finance that $3 billion worth of concessional treatment for superannuation schemes and superannuation funds. The suggestion that that situation should have been allowed to continue is absolutely intolerable and completely unacceptable. Yet, we heard all sorts of misrepresentations from members of the Opposition who paraded around the countryside and talked about a socialist government ripping off superannuitants and people in their retirement. What hypocrisy!

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—I am glad to have that comment of mine endorsed by the honourable member for Stirling, who, of course, is a well known and identified expert on questions concerning superannuation. Not only has he had broad practical experience but also has he-
—Do you know his name?
—It is Ron Edwards, my esteemed friend and colleague.
—A great member.

—The honourable member for Dobell reminds me that the honourable member for Stirling is an outstanding member. I endorse that remark and so do his constituents increasingly. As I say, the suggestion that that $3 billion should have been provided by the Commonwealth in order to allow people on retirement to take out a nest egg and use it for all of the various purposes I have outlined is completely unacceptable. It was in the light of that that the Government chose to vary the arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to the three tax concessions which were available before and to which I have made reference an additional concession was available to people who took their accumulated benefit in the form of a lump sum because of the large difference that existed between the tax treatment of superannuation pension benefits and superannuation lump sum benefits. The former-that is people who took superannuation payments in the form of a pension-were fully taxed on that pension and income flow to the extent that the income exceeded the tax free threshold. Indeed, the whole of the superannuation pension of a superannuitant who has other income equal to or in excess of the tax free threshold of $4,595 would have been taxed, and still will be taxed, at rates between 25 per cent and 60 per cent, depending upon his marginal rate. In the latter case-that is in the case of the person who took the superannuation in the form of a lump sum-only 5 per cent of the lump sum benefit was previously taxed at the taxpayer's marginal rate. That meant that the maximum rate which would have applied to the lump sum superannuation recipient was 3 per cent compared with 25 per cent to 60 per cent for the person taking the superannuation benefit in the form of an income flow. The maximum tax that a person who took the benefit in the form of a lump sum was 3 per cent, that is, the top marginal rate of 60 per cent or 60c in the dollar applied to only 5 per cent of the lump sum benefit. What a contrast! The person who received from the Commonwealth all of these accumulated benefits and concessional treatment during his working life in order to make provision for his retirement in the form of a superannuated income flow on which he would pay tax of between 25c and 60c in the dollar, would then choose to take out his benefit in the form of a lump sum and pay under the old arrangement a maximum of 3 per cent tax on that lump sum.

TALK.START.PARA: —It helps to make the capitalist system work.

—The honourable member for Berowra says that it makes the capitalist system work. If that is the way the capitalist system works, I make no apologies for being a socialist. If capitalism has to depend on that chicanery-
—A tax rort.

—As the honourable member for Dobell reminds me, it depends upon tax rorts-all of the rorts, the ramps and the rip-offs and all of the misuse and the abuse of the taxation system by the most wealthy elements of the community. According to the honourable member for Berowra, that is capitalism. At least I support restrained capitalism. I support social democratic parties winning government in order to put into place legislation which is designed to make the system work more equitably and more fairly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address myself in this cognate debate to the Medicare Levy Bill 1985. This Bill seeks to implement the Budget announcement involving the removal of the ceiling on the amount of levy payable. The Bill also seeks to increase the threshold below which people with low incomes will not pay any levy. Prior to this change, a common levy ceiling of $750 applied to single persons and married couples. However, as from 1 July this year, there will be no ceiling on the Medicare levy payable by a taxpayer. The removal of the ceiling will particularly affect two-income families who will now pay the one per cent levy on their total income without any ceiling limits.

SPEECH.PARA: The House will recall that, when the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) originally outlined the Medicare proposal to the Australian public, he said it `would be funded by a one per cent income tax contribution'. There is no doubt that the Government intentionally and systematically promoted Medicare on the basis of this false assertion. It clearly misled the public into believing that the one per cent levy would actually pay for Medicare.

Last year the levy paid for roughly half the cost of Medicare. This year it will pay for about a third. This year Medicare will cost around $3,600m and the levy will raise $1,280m. For all but low income earners the Medicare levy is now a one per cent addition to the income tax rate.

I notice that in the Government's recent taxpayer-funded full page advertisements promoting its latest tax package the statement is made that by 1 July 1987 no Australian will pay more than 49c in the dollar in income tax. That is a fraudulent and misleading statement, unless, of course, the Government is going to remove the one per cent Medicare income tax contribution. As the Government has no intention of repealing the Medicare income tax surcharge it should therefore be prosecuted for false and misleading advertising. The new tax rate will not be 49c in the dollar; it will be 50c in the dollar.

This year $8,181m will be spent by the Commonwealth on the provision of health care, an increase of over $666m on last year's expenditure. Around 15 per cent of the Commonwealth's health expenditure is funded by the levy. Of course, the rest comes out of general revenue. The Medicare levy is funding a smaller and smaller proportion of the health care budget because of the rocketing cost of Medicare. The Government is spending more on health than on any department except the Department of Social Security. The reason we are now spending more on health than on education and defence is the explosion in the cost of Medicare.

The rapid escalation in the cost of Medicare is a matter of deep concern, as is the fact that we are not getting value for money. The Government is spending more and more and getting less and less. We all remember the bold promise made by the Minister for Health, who is at the table. He said:
The introduction of Medicare is the biggest step taken by an Australian government to ensure that every Australian has the best and cheapest medical and hospital care.
In fact, the Minister has not delivered the best and cheapest medical and hospital care but the worst and most expensive medical and hospital care this country has seen for decades.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a disaster.

—It is a disaster. Medicare and the Medicare levy have forced a large number of people to give up private health insurance and become reliant on the already overloaded public hospital system. Nurses are resigning from public hospitals in droves as a result of the pressure caused by the overwhelming demand on the public hospital system under Medicare. Hospital beds are being closed as a consequence of these staff shortages. The result is growing queues of people waiting for hospital beds. Under Medicare the queues have more than doubled. In Victoria alone the queues have risen from around 8,000 people to around 25,000 people waiting for hospital beds. Doctors and doctors' organisations such as the Australian Medical Association have expressed concern about the deterioration in the standard of service provided in the public hospital system.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia-wide, the public hospital system is faced with increased demands generated by Medicare, Medicare-induced staff shortages, a reduction in the number of beds available, and a deterioration in the standard and level of service. Morale has dropped to rock bottom and the queues of patients seeking hospital beds continue to grow. In the midst of this worsening crisis the Government has decided to cut the funding to public hospitals in real terms by 8 per cent. Having encouraged 20 per cent of those privately insured to give up their insurance and rely on Medicare and the public hospital system, for the Government and the Health Minister now to reduce funding in the light of the increased demand for services indicates a cruel and callous disregard for the sick, particularly the poor and elderly sick. The champagne socialists in the Government, especially the Minister for Health, have no regard for those most in need.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is he? A Bollinger Bolshevik?

—He is. To continue to direct people away from the private sector and into the already overcrowded public system is totally irresponsible. The Minister is obviously prepared to continue his game of brinkmanship with the health system until he has just what he wants. That, of course, is total control of the health system. Even though the present crisis in our public hospitals is a direct result of this Government's Medicare scheme, which has systematically strangled the private sector and created chaos in public hospitals, the Minister nevertheless sits back and says that the hospitals are a State responsibility. Even though the present crisis is indicated by the long queues, we have had no expression of concern from the Minister for those people, especially in Melbourne and Sydney, who, in pain and suffering, cannot get into public hospitals for treatment. The cold-hearted Minister for Health has been uncaring and unsympathetic to those in most need.

SPEECH.PARA: Government spokesmen glibly report a reduction in the number of bed days in both the public and private hospitals. At the same time as people are shifting to the public sector, beds in that sector are being closed by the hundreds. So instead of seeing an increase in the utilisation of public beds there is, in fact, a slight decrease, simply because there are not enough beds to meet the demand. There are empty beds in private hospitals which could meet the demand, but the Government refuses to change its policies, which have put private insurance beyond the reach of all but the higher income earners. The Secretary to the Department of Health, Mr Bernie McKay, confirmed the point I have just made when he was speaking on 18 September in the Senate Estimates Committee. He said:
Private hospitals do have beds. A lot of hospitals, as you know, are operating at levels between 60 per cent and 70 per cent. They have the nurses; it is just that the patients are not there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—Why, indeed. The patients are not there because the Minister has introduced Medicare, which has forced people to give up their private health insurance. They cannot afford to pay the Medicare levy and maintain their private insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: I said earlier that the cost of Medicare is exploding rapidly and the Government has searched for areas where it can restrict this cost explosion. While the Government maintains its policy of promoting bulk billing, which provides an incentive for doctors to overservice, it is very difficult for the Government to control costs in the area of medical benefits. The only place where the Government can cut back significantly on spending under the present Medicare system is in the public hospitals. The Government has adopted this course of action. The cuts in funding, together with the staff shortages, bed closures and industrial disputes, have restricted the services which can be provided and have led to a rationing of the public hospital services.

At the same time as the Government continues to strangle the public hospitals it is spending more and more providing medical benefits to everyone rather than focusing resources on those who really need help. The budget for medical benefits and services has increased by 11.4 per cent this year over the figure for last year, a rate of increase nearly 50 per cent higher than inflation. This is an increase of $256m over last year's expenditure.

It is due to the rapid increase in utilisation which has come about as a result of this Government's Medicare scheme, a scheme which on the one hand subsidises the well to do as well as the poor for medical care while on the other it rations hospital care, so that those without money or influence must wait months for a hospital bed. Not only is such a system ludicrous; it is immoral.

The current increase in medical benefits is not due to a similar increase in illness, nor has it led to a similar increase in the health status of the Australian community. It reflects a growth in overservicing and overutilisation as a result of both doctors and consumers behaving as though health care were indeed free. We are spending much more but receiving no additional improvement in health care for it.

Under Medicare neither the doctor nor the patient needs to give any consideration to the cost of treatment. There is thus a tendency on the part of the patient to seek treatment for even the most minor complaint and an incentive for the doctor to maximise his or her income by advising repeat appointments which may not always be strictly necessary and by ordering tests which may not be medically indicated. More expensive courses of treatment or diagnostic procedures are likely to be chosen over less costly alternatives even though the more conservative approach may well be efficacious. So long as there is no disincentive to expensive options they may be chosen over less costly alternatives, especially if they result in more income for the doctor and are of no direct financial disadvantage to the patient.

The Minister for Health continues to deny the relationship between bulk billing and overutilisation and overservicing. However, the relationship has been acknowledged by others who understand the role of the present incentives in driving up health costs. The President of the AMA, Dr Trevor Pickering, and Professor David Penington have both spoken out recently against the Government's policy of encouraging doctors to bulk bill all patients. Both have called on the Government to limit bulk billing to pensioners and health benefit card holders. I have repeatedly called for an end to bulk billing. In so doing I am not doctor bashing; I am reflecting the concern of many of the profession who acknowledge that some of their number will succumb to the incentives provided by this Government to overservice.

It is ironic that a government which has been so critical of the medical profession, and in particular of doctors' incomes, has set about establishing a system which so obviously fosters abuse. Being committed to a system which enables the Government to assume an ever-growing control over doctors' incomes, it is now faced with paying the price for that policy or backing away from its commitment.

Honourable members may remember that, among the heady promises of Medicare, the Minister's health plan promised to provide access for all Australians, regardless of income, to the best available and most appropriate health care. However, his policies have resulted in dramatic increases in the waiting lists for public hospitals while beds lie empty in private hospitals. The very first principle of the Labor Government's health plan states:
The major test of any health insurance system is its equity, or fairness in financing and in ensuring access to high quality health services.

This Government's health insurance system has failed that test dismally. Not only has access to health services in public hospitals declined dramatically but also the high standard of health services which we used to enjoy before Medicare has deteriorated rapidly under this Government. As for fairness, it is only too clear that the people who are suffering most from the deterioration in standards and the loss of beds in the public hospital system are those who are most dependent on the public hospital system. They are the poor, the elderly and those on low and marginal incomes who cannot afford to take out private cover. The people who have only Medicare to turn to are inevitably the ones to be hurt most by the grievous effects of Medicare. Nevertheless, the Government persists in pushing the private sector further out of the reach of ordinary Australians, thereby leaving them with no alternative but to wait for a bed in the already overburdened public hospital system.

The Minister talks about access to health care, the high quality of care and fairness while at the same time he presses forward with policies which bring about the very opposite results. How can we believe what he says when we can see what he does? Clearly, the Government is more interested in implementing its socialist policies than in responding to the needs of Australians. So long as it continues to ignore the desperate situation in our public hospitals the situation can only get worse. Clearly, the Government is unwilling to fund the public hospitals at a level which would provide adequate services. Therefore, it must make the necessary changes to Medicare to enable people to return to the private sector.

The Government must take steps to restore the balance between the private and public sectors and make good the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to make private health insurance more affordable. It must permit people to opt out of Medicare and choose their health insurance from a genuinely competitive private sector. We can no longer afford to feed an insatiable Medicare appetite for medical benefits at the expense of the hospital system, nor can we afford to allow the private system to atrophy as the public system teeters on the brink of disaster due to the overwhelming burden of Medicare.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Barker is one of the many honourable members on his side of the chamber who were conspirators in egging on the doctors in the New South Wales doctors' dispute. TALK.START.PARA: —He urged them on.
