SPEECH.PARA: There are some other matters that need to be addressed. I note that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) spoke about changes in the taxation arrangements for horse racing clubs. He appeared to suggest that there were reasons why this Government would have made some changes that related to the Cabinet's own interest in horse racing. The honourable member for Mackellar needs to recognise that the horse racing industry is a substantial employer.

It employs about 250,000 people around the country. It is our intention to try to encourage that growth in employment. We have seen employment growth in industry generally but we are keen to see growth in areas such as horse racing. The honourable member for Mackellar spoke correctly about taxation arrangements. But he seemed to suggest that our motivation is other than to encourage employment in a labour intensive industry. It is important that there is encouragement for the employment of people as stable hands and strappers and in all activities relating to the conducting of racing meetings. We are keen to encourage that.

Three arrangements have been suggested. The income tax exemption arrangement will now cover horse racing clubs and greyhound racing clubs in the same way that athletics and football clubs are covered. Secondly, we have improved livestock valuation adjustment arrangements so that it will be possible for people in the industry to accelerate depreciation of their bloodstock, thereby encouraging them to improve quality. Thirdly, no sales tax will be levied in respect of importation arrangements which will also improve the quality of bloodstock. Being nationalistic, we hope that over the years that will result in an increase in the number of Australian-bred race horses winning major events such as the Melbourne Cup. Clearly, we have not paid sufficient attention to encouraging growth and development in that industry. It has been remiss of governments. These three arrangements are designed to encourage activity in the horse racing industry.

It was very pleasing to hear Colin Hayes, the well-known trainer, say recently that these changes in the industry were the most significant that he had seen, except for the development of the totalisator agency boards. In fact, these taxation changes will have a long term impact on the health of the horse racing industry. We hope that they will also have an impact on employment because the real motivation is to try to improve employment in a labour intensive industry. This is very good to see.

I will also direct comments on income tax assessment arrangements to the question of equity and averaging of incomes. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) spoke very eloquently about the question of equity and the proper arrangement of a tax system so that we can direct our attention to equity, fairness and the appropriate delivery of a tax system. That has been of considerable concern to us because we inherited a tax system with considerable inequities. There has also been a general loss of faith in the tax system within the community. The matter is difficult because whenever a system contains a great degree of voluntary arrangements under whcih we hope for the co-operation of people, if it is not fair and equitable, and it is not perceived to be so, we cannot expect that co-operation to follow. We want to restore equity and fairness in the tax system.

It does not ring true for members of the Opposition to talk about equity and fairness because their record belies that goal. They were concerned with looking after those with privilege and power and the capacity to arrange their interests for themselves rather than for the benefit of the community. There is no doubt about that. Their performance in government demonstrates that. I caution Opposition speakers who suddently want to become highly principled on fairness and equity about this conversion on the road into the chamber. Their record does not suggest that they were fair and equitable.

In relation to fairness and equity, there is a strong case for income tax averaging for sports persons, particularly for those in professional sport. Many people would be aware that football is an area with high fluctuations in income for those participating. The income tax exemption arrangements currently apply to football clubs as incorporated entities. They are exempt from income tax. However, the players are subject to the full force of the income tax arrangements. That provides some problems. In a 1979 case of a player from my home State of Western Australia, Adamson v. West Perth Football Club, Adamson sought a transfer to Norwood. The Federal Court determined that he was an employee and the football club was an employer. It follows logically that footballers, cricketers and other sorts of professional or semi-professional persons are employees. Therefore, we should do something to remove the inequities in taxation that exist for them.

Primary producers, authors and inventors have a tax averaging arrangement. That is logical because in a very short number of years they might earn a high income but in other years around that peak period, their income may be very modest. In equity, it seems to be very wrong to ask professional sports persons in particular to pay over a short earning life a very high marginal tax rate, when prior to and after that earning period they have very modest incomes. Often all they have to remember from their sporting exposure are one or two photographs, some Press clippings, tax receipts which indicate that they have paid very high marginal tax rates and some injuries. A case could be made for facilitating the option of averaging incomes for such people.

There are a couple of other reasons why averaging is important. Very often the reason that income prior to and after entering a professional sport may be very low is that the amount of time put into activities such as training is so great that the chance of pursuing another career is foregone during those critical years between the ages of about 17 and 30, when other people might have been able to pursue a career and establish a working life average income expectancy of perhaps $30,000. This person, such as a professional footballer, has been training in that time so his career path has been disrupted. The second reason is that injury or poor form can result from sport so that someone on a contract of, for example, $40,000 or $50,000 might find himself without an income because he has sustained serious injury or his form has dropped away.

Another recent problem which is very significant is that of politics in football management, in particular. Many people will be aware of the machinations of Dr Edelsten in regard to the Sydney Swans. People earning a respectable income, such as former coach, John Northey, may find due to the whim of someone with great financial power that their chance of earning an income is cut off completely, not because of their performance or ability but because of the personal preference of someone in that activity with a great deal of power. I regret that, because we are seeing an attempt by Dr Edelsten not only to buy a club and do a number of other things, but also to buy a premiership. The clear intention in football, as in all other sports, should be to seek the junior development of players and the development of clubs and districts, not to wave big dollars and totally disrupt what many people regard as a very important entertainment, activity and interest. We are seeing an obsession with success and big money trying to buy that success.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am pleased that the honourable member for Franklin endorses my comments because I personally regret this. In setting an example to young people we should not be saying that the only way to succeed is to buy success. Effort should be put into young players for their development and the patient and systematic development of clubs and the junior area. The performance of Dr Edelsten recently in trying to rip off the Essendon Football Club gives me no great joy. The fact that the words `junior development' have never passed his lips concerns me also because that ought to be a commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: Returning to my theme, we should have a system of tax averaging for sports persons. We then offer clubs the chance to get their financial arrangements in order.

We are all aware of the financial stresses facing football clubs, rugby league clubs and soccer clubs. Clearly, there are financial stresses. We are also aware that some of those clubs are in danger of going out of business because they cannot meet costs. I am suggesting that if we were able to introduce tax averaging for competitive players, the clubs would be able to offer a lower total salary package to those players because their net take-home pay, as a result of tax averaging, would be at the same level. That would reduce the financial burden on the clubs.

Incidentally, the other thing which I think is important to put into place is a proper system of arbitration of player payments, using the system of conciliation and arbitration we have established in this country. Even though the Opposition seeks to destroy that system, it will stay in place because it performs an important service. I believe that in relation to sporting activities it could perform a very significant service. In a sense, what we would be doing would be keeping the lawyers out of it. In disputes over sporting transfers very large legal fees and legal costs are incurred, with no money going back into the sports themselves. Clearly, if we were to marry to the system of tax averaging a proper system of arbitration for sporting disputes we would end up with a far better system.

Let me give an instance of one area of concern which explains why I believe we need a proper system of tax averaging. Three Richmond players from Western Australia-Maurice Rioli, Tim Gepp and David Palm are currently managed by a group called Australian Rules Football Management and Advisory Services Pty Ltd. What they have done simply is to set up a tax shelter. Again, I find it a source of regret that the fees charged these three players by ARFMAS are very high. It is clear that in order to set up a tax shelter players such as Rioli, Gepp and Palm end up with far less in their pockets than they ought to. As a government we ought to be setting in place a system of tax averaging which eliminates the need for such tax contrivances and shelters and such large management advisory fees. This would make it easier for people to recognise and meet their tax liability and not to have to go into areas of contrivance. I think that is very important. It is one of the things I believe we as a government ought to be pursuing. Such a system would set a degree of equity. I am pleased to see the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) nodding assent because I think these are matters we can work out sensibly in this place. We can do much for people in sport and we can set a standard for people in sport. The more we get away from the belief that somehow sport is a business in which people can be ripped off-that is the concern I have about the current Sydney Swans' manoeuvres-the closer we will get to a situation in which people's rights and obligations under the tax laws are clearer.

Let me sum up my comments about tax averaging. I have said that there is a clear employer-employee relationship in relation to semi-professional and professional sports persons. That has been established by some Federal Court decisions, and certainly it is endorsed by the income tax arrangements. The other thing that is very evident to many people who look at the situation of sporting professionals is that the income they derive, whilst it may be very high for a short number of years, is for a short number of years only. As a result of injuries and poor performance, or as a result of the political whims resulting from the privatisation of Australian rules football, which I personally regret, someone's sporting career could suddenly be terminated, not because of that person's ability but because of personality disputes. We are aware that that happens, particularly in football, but it also happens in cricket and other sports. Recently we have seen some very disturbing issues in relation to the national cricket scene in Australia where it is clear that personality issues have entered the picture. That has not been for the benefit of the players or for the sport generally.

If we were to establish tax averaging for sports persons we would be recognising the fluctuations in incomes and the high opportunity costs of pursuing a professional sport when one forgoes a proper path of career development. That is very important. We would also be recognising that we see sport as playing a very important role in this country. In my view, sport plays a very important role in terms of its public entertainment value. Sport is surely the talk of the town at grand final time and in the cricket season. I believe it is important that we as a Parliament should make changes to the income tax laws to facilitate that.

If we are looking at income tax law as a way of providing both equity and fairness and also incentive, it is important to recognise that if we were to introduce tax averaging we would be providing the incentive for people to say `Yes, I am prepared to commit myself to a career in football' or cricket, soccer, rugby league, tennis, golf or whatever. At the same time we need to recognise as a community that that person's income may have wide fluctuations. As I indicated earlier, authors and inventors have that recognition extended to them, and we should be extending that privilege to professional sports people. We would thereby eliminate a lot of the financial pressures, particularly in rugby league and Australian rules football at the moment, and what I consider to be bargaining of the worst kind, which has no thought for the development of sport but simply bids up the market price and, ultimately, threatens the future of these sports.

I think there are many people in Australia who would say: `I do not want it that way. I do not want people with lots of money running around disrupting what I consider an important activity and entertainment for me'.

I do not believe we should be encouraging high bidding. In terms of our taxation arrangements we should be saying that we are prepared to give an appropriate tax treatment to professional sports people that will enable these clubs to pay them, to have arbitrated arrangements that will be satisfactory to all parties concerned, and that will result in healthier and better performance in the sport. If we could properly address ourselves to these sorts of issues in this place we would do much to help many people in the professional sports and certainly to help the development of sports. It is my pleasure to commend these Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and cognate Bills, including the Medicare Levy Bill, currently before the House raise many issues of concern. One could reflect on what has been a very great debate on taxation over the past six months. The people of this country could be excused for feeling some degree of confusion about the whole spectrum of taxation and the intentions of this Government in regard to taxation. It is fair to say that the moment of truth will come not from the legislation with which we are now dealing but from the legislation that will be introduced later this session.

SPEECH.PARA: One would hope that the debate on the specific matters before the House will be just a curtain raiser to the very serious and important complexities of changes to taxation resulting from the implementation of major so-called reforms in respect of many of the matters glossed over in the current legislation. Of course, this legislation comes as a result of the Budget determinations, when we experienced for the first time in history a non-event Budget. I call it a non-event Budget because the problems that had arisen within the economy were not addressed, nor was there any attempt on the part of the Government to create even a holding situation to avoid the run-down and the disaster evident in many directions. I refer in particular to the run-down in the health services of this country, the consequences of the Medicare levy, and the policies it embodies.

Earlier in this debate the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) made a very constructive summation of the Medicare disaster. I want to add just a few words, particularly in respect of what is happening to the hospital system in New South Wales. Today we find what could be described only as total agony for ordinary people in the community in respect of hospital services. I am pleased that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is in the House because it is time he was made aware of some of the current happenings in the health field in New South Wales. He has spent so much time denigrating the doctors, carrying on `hate the doctors' campaigns throughout this nation, particularly in New South Wales, that he has apparently become oblivious to what really is happening in health services, specifically in the hospitals, in New South Wales.

If we look at the financial consequences of the Medicare scheme as it operates and the financing of health under that scheme we find, as pointed out so succinctly by the honourable member for Barker, that Medicare does not meet the requirements or address the problems and the situation of chaos is growing worse day by day, week by week and month by month. We are finding the closure of wards in public hospitals, with dire consequences for the communities served by those hospitals.

I refer honourable members to a hospital in the main centre of my own electorate of Page, the Grafton Base Hospital. That hospital was visited a few weeks ago by the Minister, who in a very glib comment on that occasion said: `We are looking after you. We are taking care of your needs in respect of hospital and health services, and all is well'. He did not bother to check what was really happening at that hospital. An emergency meeting has been called for today inviting the public, the Government of New South Wales, this Federal Government and representatives of community organisations concerned with health care to become aware and cognisant of the fact that that hospital will have to close a very important ward section and that it will have to cut back on services simply because the funds will not be there for it to carry on and provide the essential services that it is expected to provide between now and the end of the financial year. At this early stage in the current financial year a cutback of monumental proportions is being considered in order that the vital and essential sections of the hospital can survive. However, the closure equally removes the provision of bed space, an essential provision for that hospital to render the services it should render.

Who are the sufferers? We heard a lot from the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). We heard another honourable member talk just a moment ago about equity. Where is the equity when the ordinary patients, regardless of their status, are affected by these cutbacks? The blame, so far as this Government is concerned, rests with the doctors. I ask these questions: If it is because of the doctors, why is it that there are staff shortages? Why is it that there are vast protests by the nursing fraternity and why is it that the Government in New South Wales in particular is engaged in a massive cover-up of cutbacks in health services at present?

The truth is that the financial structure of the health services in this country is in chaos and the Minister is totally committed to a Medicare system which will not remedy that problem. So, in the legislation before this House to enact further provisions under the levy, we find that there is gross and deliberate fabrication of the facts about the financing of health services in Australia, particularly in the State of New South Wales. Of course, there is reference to the problem in respect of private hospitals, a problem which just should not exist. There is scope for treatment to be provided if those who require the treatment can afford to pay for it. If we did not have this one-sided, absolutely inequitable system of Medicare, those private hospitals would be able to render an effective service to all sections of the community-to those who need the service and to those who are waiting to undergo operations or whatever form of treatment is required to deal with their health problems.

However, this is not good enough for this Government. It wants to entrench a socialist approach. It wants to entrench an approach which, quite frankly, reduces the standards of health care provided in this nation. It is a very great reflection on the Minister and on the Government that they are the cause of the dilemma that confronts all who have a conscience so far as health services are concerned. That conscience begins with the dedicated doctors of this country who have been vilified now for months and who no doubt will be blamed again for the serious decline that is occurring today in the provision of health services on the excuse that there are financial problems that are the consequence of the difficulties that have occurred in the last six months in relations between the medical profession and the Government. It is utter rot to assert that that is the cause of the problem.

The cause of the problem is crystal clear. It is because of a change in philosophy and the introduction of a system which is not giving a practical result in terms of what is needed in this country to enable health services to be provided without them being a burden on the taxpayer and without them being a burden on those people who suffer illness in this period. The previous Government operated health services as the consequence of an equitable system, a contribution system. It was a unique system that was developed in this country over many years. That system has been torn up by two successive Labor Government administrations, to the detriment of the well-being of the citizens of this country. Small country centres now face the agony of seeing their hospitals close or being so reduced in terms of the services they render that families find that they are at great risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—The honourable member should look at hospitals in country centres. SPEECH.PARA: The truth of the matter really is that the Government is seeking to reduce the cost-a figure referred to by the honourable member for Charlton of about $2.6 billion under the systems that did operate. So these measures before the House and those foreshadowed in the tax package statement which will come before the House in the form of legislation are all pertinent and very much interrelated. Some of the other measures covered in this immediate legislation are without doubt part of an overall government plan and I believe that it would not be an exaggeration to say that it is deliberately intended to confuse the public of this country and in particular to confuse the taxpayer. TALK.START.PARA: —What about the other 94 per cent?

—We have the crazy interjection: `What about the other 94 per cent?'. The changes to the concessional rebates and the other provisions that were in place concern a lot more than 6 per cent of taxpayers. That has been removed and we now have a situation which can only be described as one of insecurity, unless we are to look at that great socialist umbrella that says: `There will be something there out of social security to look after you if you fall into difficulties or hard times or if you fall victim to illness or some other difficulty that affects your well-being'. SPEECH.PARA: I wish lastly to refer to one measure that I think has general support on both sides of the House, and that is the altered taxation arrangements in respect of the racing fraternity. In conclusion, let us be cautious about what is to come in the whole spectrum of taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time, Mr Deputy Speaker, I admire your patience and endurance in the chair when you have to listen to some of the drivel that comes from the other side. That which has just come from the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) and his colleague before him, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), is a classic example. We have before us a number of pieces of legislation covering the fairly wide-ranging areas of taxation, superannuation and health arrangements but for almost the entire debate this morning they have concentrated on what I describe as a nonsensical attack on Medicare. The reason they have done this is that they are terribly embarrassed about the nature of the legislation; they are embarrassed about what is really happening. They are embarrassed about what they failed to do during the time they had responsibility in this Parliament. Of course they endeavoured in their contributions to avoid the real issues; so I take this opportunity to bring the debate back to some of the issues that really should be covered.

SPEECH.PARA: The taxation Bills and the Medicare Levy Bill cover a wide variety of machinery matters, as I mentioned, and in fact they could easily be passed over as machinery Bills without any examination of their real significance. That would be a mistake. I want to draw attention to the directions being incorporated in this legislation. I must compliment my colleague the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) for his contribution this morning because he too drew some attention to the real aspects of this legislation. Let us look first of all at the problem of compliance with the tax system. There can be no misunderstanding within the community of the extent of non-compliance with our tax system. The task inherited by this Government to tidy up the tax system should not be underestimated. The efforts by government, committees, staff, the Treasury and the whole Federal bureaucracy in tidying up the mess and eliminating the non-compliance system which has been created also should not be underestimated in this Parliament.
These Bills have to address things like non-leveraged leasing arrangements and the tidying up of drifts and patterns in the use of these provisions in ways that were never intended.

We have had to amend provisions for the loan back rules as they apply to superannuation funds for businesses. The reason that the Government has had to address this matter is that there has been widespread concern that investment in these funds has led to situations whereby, when a business fails, not only do its employees lose their jobs but also their superannuation entitlements go down the drain. That is a concern shared by the Commonwealth Task Force on Occupational Superannuation. It was brought to attention by the Asprey Taxation Review Committee, the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry and the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. The action that has been taken by the Government ought to be commended.

Much was made of the statements of the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) when he ascended his throne that actions by this Government would be commended and credit would be given where it was due. But what have we heard this morning? We have heard drivel about Medicare, and there has been no mention of the prompt implementation of the recommendations of these inquiries. This Government is not about to pigeonhole reports that have been produced in the past. It will do something serious with those reports. No mention was made of that. Where is all the credit where credit is due that was talked about? No wonder the credibility of the Leader of the Opposition is disappearing so quickly.

While talking on that subject, let me look at three key reports that have had to be addressed in recent months by the Government. The Martin Review of the Australian Financial System has led to much of the Government's action in deregulating the financial system and making more sense of it. It has led to the opening up of competition. When we talk of opening up competition let us not forget that those on the other side of the House constantly preached terms such as `free enterprise' and `let us cut out the red tape'. While they talked all this drivel they introduce one piece of legislation after another bringing in one more loophole after another, one more regulation after another, bogging down the system in protection. Its rhetoric does not stand up to investigation. That is what we have to remember. The Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs concerned the problems we inherited in the labour market. The Karmel Quality of Education Review Committee identified the problems we inherited in the quality of education. The reports of all these committees have had to be addressed quickly by our Government. This has led to our Priority One: Young Australia policy of providing youth traineeships. This is a very genuine attempt by the Government to address the problems in this nation.

Having said those things, I will return more directly to the Bills. I emphasise that the Bills are not just for revenue raising purposes. They are designed to protect the benefits of members of superannuation schemes and to restrict the level of investments by sponsoring employers, which can leave both employers and employees at risk. I also draw attention to the move in the Bills to change the rebate for medical expenses in the tax system. The honourable member for Page made some comment about the fact that the removal of the concessional rebate affects only 6 per cent of taxpayers. From our information it does affect only 6 per cent of taxpayers. The other 94 per cent do not gain any benefit from the concessional rebate as it applies at the moment, but the whole Australian Taxation Office system is bogged down with having to review tax returns every year based on the claims that may be made by 6 per cent of taxpayers. That is not an efficient use of government resources and, of course, it leads to the measures which are being taken, and which have been foreshadowed by the Treasurer, to introduce a self-audit system. Much will be said of this later, and I give notice here that it will be welcomed by the Australian community as a recognition of the honest taxpayer, a recognition that the person who makes honest claims, who does not exaggerate expenditure or use all the fancy techniques and devices does not need to have his or her income tax return checked every year by the Australian Taxation Office. This Government is moving to recognise that and it is using resources more efficiently in a way which will help bring more compliance with the system.

I make special reference to the provisions in the Bill which ensure that income earned by racing clubs and other industries which derive revenue from animal racing shall be exempt from tax. I have a substantial racing industry in my electorate and I assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this measure has been very well received within the industry. I get the odd smile when I attend the odd race meeting in the electorate. It is good to see that group recognising that this Government has taken account of their interests and is acknowledging the substance of the industry and the need to provide those sorts of incentives to it. Another aspect of this legislation has not been touched on at any time during the debate this morning, as I recall, by members of the Opposition and yet, I believe, it is one of the most significant decisions taken in a minor way by a government for many years. I am delighted to see that the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) is at the table. He has had much to do with the priority given to local government and the announcement which is contained in this legislation. The legislation now provides for tax deductibility to be given to up to $1,000 worth of electoral expenses incurred by candidates in local government elections.

That measure may not on the surface seem to be very significant, but let us look at what it represents. It means that this Government takes local government seriously. We respect the role of local government as the third tier at the local level. It is closest to the people and we recognise the legitimacy of elections at the local government level and the legitimacy of the activities that have to be undertaken by a candidate for local government. This complements the approach which has been publicly espoused by the Minister. It complements the approach which has been taken in the recognition of local government in the Constitution and the majority decision taken at the recent conference which was announced by the Minister. It complements in a very significant way the treatment of local government in the allocation of untied grants in the Budget. It is with some pride that the Minister can point out to local government that of all the cutbacks that this Government has been forced to address in its economic planning one sector which receives significant real increases in funding is local government. This is another step in the ongoing program of recognising that role and it is to be commended. Once again, we have heard nothing from the other side of the House about credit where it is due, yet Opposition members purport to have such close contact with local government. I am afraid that they are out of touch.

The second reading speech of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) outlined the changes, particularly in the income test, applying to social security beneficiaries, changes in the rebate provisions and changes to the Medicare levy. In my view they are productive changes. Despite what we have heard from the other side of the House, I think they introduce more fairness and equity into the system. In response to the comments made by the honourable member for Page I say to him that he ought to wander down to my electorate, look at some country communities and have some real contact with them. I have some very significant small country communities working with their local hospitals, expanding their community health services, rationalising their operations and drawing closer to the needs of people in the area. I have no embarrassment at all about the directions being taken by this Government's health policies.

Again I make the point that perhaps they are just a fraction out of touch with what is happening. Let us look also at the aspects of this Bill designed to improve co-operation between Commonwealth, State and Territory governments. We have out there a significant problem with States not being able to raise revenue via their genuine revenue-raising techniques because they do not have the powers to police or force compliance with their system. We are all about breaking down these inhibitions and barriers. This legislation provides for the transfer and an overlapping of powers to enable smoother transition. It provides for Commonwealth officers of the Taxation Office to be given powers to assist States and Territories in the pursuit of those who continually seek to avoid the system.

Perhaps I should compare what is being done in these Bills with the approach adopted in the past by Opposition members, particularly in the measures relating to the social security system and the Medicare levy. Let me compare those aspects with what has been foreshadowed in what I call the Howard-Valder package. It has been made very clear in this House and in the Westpac tape that the way the Opposition would go about reducing the deficit is to cut social welfare expenditure-not by addressing tax avoidance or by getting a fairer system with which people will comply, for the benefit of all Australians, but making it harder for those who suffered under the former Government's policies. That is what Opposition members are about and that is how they would go about making gains in government revenue. The attitudes expressed this morning show the significant split between members of the National Party and members of the Liberal Party in approaching these sorts of questions. I shall be interested to watch particularly the privatisation issue regarding Telecom unfold because we all know that it is going nowhere. We all know that the rhetoric about a tough wages policy is going nowhere, and so too will these sorts of approaches because the Australian electorate will not wear them.

In the recent speech to the nation on the tax reform package, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) made a couple of points that need to be repeated. He said that the Government has confronted the issue of tax reform, and it has indeed. It has put enormous resources, energy and effort into cleaning up the mess. The Treasurer also pointed out that the Government had been willing to consult with the people of Australia in the process. We have no doubt that we have overwhelming support in the community for the efforts we are making to clean up the tax system. We have been willing seriously and responsibly to consider issues and, above all, we have been willing to take hard decisions. I think that is recognised and respected in the community. The Treasurer made one comment which I think may not prove to be correct. On the night of the announcement he said that the Government's tax reform process is complete. I do not believe it is. It is complete in the sense that it was being expounded in the decisions that were taken; but we are already aware that out there they are taking the new legislation, the new principles, the new policies, and they are looking for loopholes. The mentality among the high flyers is: `Let us try to find a way around it'. That attitude is still out there and will continue. This Government will continue to chase loopholes, to introduce new legislation, and take up the time of this Parliament continually trying to track down these things.

I invite the House to consider why that is the position. That mentality was created during the 1970s by a government which failed to address these issues when they started. It failed to give resources to the Taxation Office to get on to the job and stop these practices. It failed to give resources to the Attorney-General to police these things. We have had the absurd case of the bottom of the harbour schemes 12 years down the line now finally making it to the High Court. It is a national disgrace that the position should have been left in that way. It has encouraged an attitude of non-compliance. I hope that those responsible will hand their heads in shame for decades to come over their role. No tax system can successfully survive if people believe that it is unfair and they they are the victims of others' actions. In the end, others then start to look for ways to enjoy the same benefits, and the system breaks down.

I conclude by underlining the point made by the Treasurer. The decisions we have taken are essential to secure the future economic well-being of the nation. They are essential if we are to recover respect and integrity for our taxation system, and they are essential if all Australians are to be treated with fairness and equity. We as a government are confident that the people of Australia will recognise that these significant measures are taken in the best interests of the nation and for the greater good of every individual Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be addressing the majority of my comments today to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985. The first element of the Bill which I would like to congratulate the Government on introducing is the alterations to the social security rebates. Taxpayers receiving unemployment benefit, special benefit or sickness benefit will have their rebates increased when this Bill is passed. The rebates for single beneficiaries will be increased from $50 to $170. For married beneficiaries they will be increased from $75 to $220. This financial year single beneficiaries earning up to $4,795 will pay no tax. After this Bill is passed single beneficiaries can earn up to a total of $5,275 and still pay no tax. Married beneficiaries will be able to earn up to $8,795 and pay no tax. I would lilke to compliment the Government on introducing this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: The rebate shades out by 12.5c for each dollar in excess of a specified threshold. The rebate for a single pensioner previously shaded out at $5,195. After this Bill is passed the rebate for single pensioners will shade out at $6,635. The rebate for married pensioners and married beneficiaries previously shaded out at $8,815. After this Bill is passed it will shade out at $10,555.

I would like to cite the example of a single unemployed person who earned $5,275 last year. In the 1984-85 financial year he would have had an income tax bill of $170. This year, after this Bill is passed, he will pay no tax at all. The rebate for Social Security and Veterans' Affairs pensioners remains at $250. This Bill seeks to increase the rebate for those receiving unemployment benefit, special benefit and sickness benefit.

Pensioners who already receive the $250 rebate will be able to earn in this financial year up to $5,533 and pay no tax on that, whereas the ordinary taxpayer who is not a pensioner will pay $250 tax. Some pensioners in my electorate, and I am sure in many others, have been confused by some of the newspaper coverage of the announcements made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the 19 September tax statement. In that statement the Treasurer announced that the tax free threshold will be raised on 1 September 1986 from $4,595 to $5,100. As most pensioners on low incomes currently pay no tax on income up to $5,533, some pensioners have been confused. They have thought that, in fact, the tax free threshold had been reduced for them, due to some very sloppy reporting from some quarters. However, on the figures I have done I believe that after 1 September 1986 single pensioners will continue to receive the $250 tax rebate and they will pay no tax at all if their income is $6,142 or less. In fact, single pensioners who currently pay tax on amounts above $5,533 will pay tax only if their income exceeds $6,142 after 1 September 1986.

That is a very sizable increase of $609 for those single pensioners. That $609 increase is due to two factors: Firstly, the $505 increase in the tax free threshold which will apply to all taxpayers after September 1986 and, secondly, a reduction of the 25 per cent marginal rate to 24 per cent. I also congratulate the Government on the foreshadowed relaxation of the incomes test in relation to all social security matters after 1 November 1986.

Returning to the specific matters contained in the Bill before the House, I wish to address my attention to the sections of the Bill which refer to superannuation. Under the new arrangements for the taxation of lump sum superannuation payments, which were announced in August 1983, the Treasurer provided for the former rules to apply to the pre-July 1983 component of lump sum payments and for new arrangements to apply to the post-July 1983 component. The pre-July 1983 component is taxed at the old rate that is, 5 per cent of the lump sum is considered as taxable income. The post-1 July 1983 component is reduced by the amount of the employee's undeducted contributions-that is, the undeducted contributions made since July 1983. After we have deducted the employee's undeducted contributions, the remainder-that is, the employer's contribution and any earnings-is taxed at 30 per cent if the superannuitant is 55 years of age or older. Under the current regulations, if he or she is 55 years of age or over the first $50,000 is taxed at only 15 per cent. This Bill which is before the House raises this concessional limit from $50,000 to $55,000.

The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) complained that the figure of $55,000 was still too modest. In my opinion, that speaks highly of the total hypocrisy of those sitting opposite. In fact, the dries opposite remind me of several characters in a Robert Graves short story in which he recounted the very sad fate of a group of Americans who live in the backwoods of the United States of America and who, due to a genetic defect, have no sweat glands in their skin. I suppose it would be expected that these people would live very dry lives indeed. However, these unfortunate people must continue to douse themselves in water or wallow in muddy pools whenever necessary in order to survive.

It appears to me that the Opposition talks up dry policies. Honourable members opposite claim to be economic rationalists but when they are put to the test on specific proposals they dive into the muddy swamps of political opportunism. In my opinion they were put to the test on the matter of lump sum superannuation and they failed. They were put to the test of economic rationalism on the assets test and they failed. They were also put to the test on taxation reform and they failed miserably as well. As the current Federal President of the Liberal Party, Mr John Valder, stated in his famous private Westpac video show, the Liberals want this Government to implement all the tough but unpopular decisions and then promptly to lose office. The bad news for those opposite is that the Australian people want a government which is prepared to take the tough but unpopular decisions and I am sure they are prepared to back us at the next election.

As an example of the mass hysteria which was fanned by the Liberal Opposition on the matter of superannuation and the new tax on lump sums, I want to recount the position of one of my constituents who was totally misled by the conservatives. His undeducted contributions since July 1983 in fact exceeded his post-1983 component. Under the new arrangements announced by the Treasurer, in fact he paid less tax than he would have paid if there had been no change at all in superannuation arrangements. The reason is that the Treasurer has provided for the employee's contributions which are not claimed as a tax deduction to be deducted from the post-1983 component. I am concerned about one problem which this constituent has brought to my attention. The Australian Taxation Office has isued a guide called the `Australian Taxation Office Guide to Eligible Termination Payments for Approved Deposit Funds, Superannuation Funds, Life Assurance Companies and Registered Organisations'. As I explained, my constituent's undeducted contributions exceeded his post-1983 component. According to page 9 of this Taxation Office guide, he should therefore pay tax on only the pre-1983 component. But page 12 of that guide states that employers are not instructed to take account of undeducted contributions when calculating tax instalments. I am happy to advise the House that the Treasurer has agreed to investigate this apparent anomaly and to advise me in due course what action he proposes to take.

One of the other provisions which is provided in this Bill is an alteration in the concessional expenditure rebate. In the few minutes remaining to me before the suspension of the sitting, I would like to cite some figures which were provided for the Australian people in the Government's White Paper on taxation reform. They show that of taxpayers who had a taxable income of $32,000 or more, 31.4 per cent claimed a rebate under the concessional expenditure component provision. I repeat that that is 31.4 per cent of those earning $32,000 or more. Yet, when we look at the average overall income tax scales we see that only 6.2 per cent of taxpayers, on average, received any benefit from this rebate, but of those in the top rate receiving $32,000 or more 31 per cent claimed a rebate under that component provision. I am more than happy to support the Government's proposals that this rebate should be re-examined.

On the matter of provisional tax, it has been my experience that a larger number of my constituents who are pensioners are being hit by provisional tax. —Has the Minister for Defence noted recent claims by the Opposition spokesman on defence and Leader of the National Party of Australia that the Grumman Tracker aircraft now being sold by the Government still has a role which no other aircraft in the defence forces could fulfil? Are these claims accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. I note that the Opposition spokesman on defence in a recent Press release stated:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the Trackers were ideal for maritime surveillance, anti-submarine fleet support and had at least 10 to 15 years of effective life ahead of them.
He was then unkind enough to say:
When it comes to defence efficiency this government demonstrates a `Dad's army' mentality.

I would have thought that there was a small amount of embarrassment about criticising the Government for abandoning a technology that is now somewhat outdated-the planes are somewhat old-while at the same time accusing us of having a Dad's Army mentality about it all. To take it a point further, one of the implications in suggesting we have a Dad's Army mentality is that there is some problem on this side of the House with senility. One of the characteristics of that is an element of forgetfulness. In that case the problem is with the honourable gentlemen opposite. The honourable gentleman has provided me with an opportunity to make up for the 24-hour memory lapse on the part of the Opposition defence spokesman and to point out to him that it was not a terribly difficult decision for the Government to make. Why was it not a terribly difficult decision for us to make? It was because it had been made by him and his predecessor. So it was a fairly easy decision for us to make. On Thursday, 8 April 1982, the then Minister for Defence, Mr D. J. Killen, stated:

. . . along with the decision to purchase HMS Invincible and pay off the present flagship HMAS Melbourne, the Government had decided that the Tracker and Skyhawk aircraft should be paid off as soon as practicable.

That is not a bad start. My attention was drawn to a speech by the right honourable member for New England, the Opposition spokesman on defence, when he was Minister for Defence, to the Northern Development Council seminar in October 1982 when he felt obliged to say:

Some of you will remember the valuable work carried out by Navy Tracker aircraft operating from Broome and Darwin between 1975 and 1980. Both the Premier of Western Australia and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory have written to me recently seeking return of the Trackers. While I understand their concern, the relative capability of the Trackers and charter civilian aircraft means that the cost of using the Trackers is significantly higher without any immediate advantage.

So the former Defence Minister quite appropriately dismissed the use of these aircraft for those sorts of purposes. He pointed out to that seminar what I would have pointed out and agree with in regard to what is the most appropriate anti-submarine warfare and surveillance aircraft for the forces. The former Defence Minister stated:

``RAAF P3s fly frequent patrols of the Australian Fishing Zone'' which extends some 200nm from the coastline. Orions are used in preference to light aircraft because of their higher speeds and ability to search vast areas.

I must admit that when I had some involvement in these matters I did not necessarily take that at face value. I must admit that at one stage in my political career I advocated the merits of the Tracker as a potential surveillance aircraft. When I was Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence I was deputed to do an analysis of whether this claim was valid in the maritime surveillance area and an analysis of the conclusions reached by the right honourable gentleman when he was the Defence Minister, although this claim was abandoned by him when he became the shadow spokesman on defence. I did a study on the comparative merits, in cost terms, between chartered civilian aircraft in the coastal surveillance area and that of the Trackers. I came to the conclusion that the chartered civilian aircraft cost $174 per 100 kilometres of coast surveyed compared with $1,158 for a Tracker, more than six times the cost of a chartered civilian aircraft. So it was not a terribly difficult decision not to pursue that line in maritime surveillance and to reach agreement with Sinclair Mark I. That was no particular problem at all.

I turn to the area of anti-submarine warfare which is another matter which was mentioned by the right honourable member. He suggested that we should keep the Trackers for anti-submarine warfare presumably in addition to what we would do with the Orion P3 fleet. The Orions, which obtain the bulk of the Government's attention in this regard, are perfectly adequate for that task because of their size, legs and ability to be developed further in that area which the Trackers cannot. Basically the Trackers, particularly in the Australian context, are viable only in an aircraft carrier type context; they are not viable as a land-based aircraft with the sorts of distances we have to cover.

What this Government is on about in increasing defence expenditure in real terms-it is substantially greater than that of our opponents-is doing it in a manner that does not waste money. In this way we do not retain capabilities which are completely unnecessary. On those grounds we will not be able to move into a position where we can accommodate Sinclair Mark II as opposed to Sinclair Mark I when it comes to planning an appropriate force structure for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the availability to the Treasurer of the details from Treasury of the consequences of his tax package, what is the expected job fall-out in the restaurant industry as a result of his proposed introduction of the disallowance of entertainment expenses for tax purposes? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot understand this concentration on the restaurant industry. What is implied in the question, again, is that the restaurants of this country are entitled to reside and profit and prosper under a tax shelter, that the people those opposite have represented for years should be able to continue to slide through the 60 per cent marginal rate of tax and not pay their fair share, while they drop the burden on high and marginal income taxpayers. I cannot remember one occasion on which this Government has legislated against tax avoidance and needed an employment impact statement. It is absurd.
—You are not worrying about unemployment.

—Yes, we are. This tax package will lift aggregate employment. The economy will be more dynamic. The change in marginal rates from 60 per cent to 49 per cent and the imputation package for companies will make this economy far more dynamic than it has ever been. I should have thought that those opposite would be the last people to talk about employment. Unemployment rose dramatically in their period of office by a quarter of a million in their last year as against the 430,000 jobs created by this Government. —They had one growth industry before.

—As the Prime Minister said, for years they had one growth industry-the tax avoidance industry. This Government will not do employment impact statements on tax shelters. It is time we had a decent, fair, clean and honourable tax system, and we will have one now.
—Including seminars? What about seminars?

—The Leader of the Opposition talks about seminars. I make a point about entertainment. The whole question of the non-deductibility of entertainment is confused with the question of meals. Meals do not intrinsically go to the question of entertainment. Entertainment is about purpose and circumstance, and we are refusing to have entertainment as a tax deduction in the system. If at a convention or a conference meals are served, they are not served to entertain, just as meals are deductible as part of overnight or travelling expenses. When someone travels the cost of the meals they have is deductible.

ANSWER.PARA: We are removing from the system a tax ramp which is being abused and used by certain categories of high income earners primarily for the purposes of social value and entertainment. Because it is unreasonable to expect the Commissioner of Taxation to make judgments on these matters, and because it is unreasonable to provide the Commissioner with laws which we know he is incapable of administering, we are doing what Britain has already done and the United States intends to do, that is, we are curbing the abuse of this section of the tax system. It is simply a further commentary on the policies of the Opposition that it should defend this area of the tax system which has been so open to abuse and suggest that we need an employment impact statement when wiping out a tremendous and outrageous rort in the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question concerns the taxation system. Will the Treasurer inform the House how the Government's recently announced tax reform package will correct the decay in the tax system which occurred under the previous Administration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The history of taxation under the former Government was one of obfuscation and concealment of the most blatant tax avoidance and evasion practices in this country's history. The former Treasurer was dragged screaming to reform the most outrageous areas of the tax system by the McCabe-Lafranchi report, which he described as being a stunt by the Victorian Premier, by the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, which he hid behind under the secrecy provisions of the Taxation Act, and by the Gyles report, which said that if there had been an adequate administrative, judicial and political response in the first place the situation would never have arisen.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the coalition was tardy about tax reform, tax avoidance and evasion because it knew that its friends could escape through the system. It left all the holes in the system so that the people it represented would not have to pay the full rate of taxation but would have that burden placed on every other taxpayer. By contrast, this Government has debunked all those myths and has taken firm action on the tax system where the coalition failed. We will cut personal income tax rates-the top rate from 60 per cent to 49 per cent and the next rate from 46 per cent to 40 per cent and we will end double taxation of dividends and remove the basis for tax avoidance and evasion by a fair and reasonable capital gains tax.

Where is the Opposition's policy on taxation? Yesterday's financial review by the Opposition taxation spokesman, Senator Messner, was another hollow policy sham by the Opposition, as is its wages policy. It exposed again the total confusion of the Opposition's ideas. We see trotted out again a proposal for a flat tax system. It is simply absurd for the Liberal Party to believe that the workers of this country will wear the burden of a flat tax without it impacting on the wage system. The Opposition's total incognisance of the interconnection between taxation, wages and inflation was obvious yesterday in Senator Messner's statement about the need for a flat tax system.

The other issue is that Senator Messner has backed the coalition away from a consumption tax. He said that there would be no consumption tax. All this brave stuff we have heard from the Leader of the Opposition about a consumption tax is to be debunked. Those opposite will not have a consumption tax to pay for their other tax changes. That will all be blurred. They will walk away from it. Interestingly, Senator Messner has endorsed the concept of a services tax, the very option the Government rejected because a services tax will not yield a fiscal dividend to the system, will not reduce marginal rates, and will not pay for flat taxation. If the government of the day compensates people adequately for the inflationary impact of a services tax, the fiscal dividend is obliterated. That is why the Government walked away from it. The Opposition is contemplating a services tax without compensation. We would be going back to the Howard policies of 1980, lifting sales taxes dramatically without compensation. What the Opposition really has in mind is a services tax without compensation, picking out all the industries about which it is now crying crocodile tears-the restaurants, the dry cleaners and all the other service industries-and taxing them. Yet they question me about the tax treatment of restaurants!

The most interesting part of Senator Messner's statement was that he said the coalition would have a capital gains tax. He made that clear. He said that they would have an extension of section 26AAA. Over time, that is the most punitive option a government can have in capital taxation; that is, the full marginal rates taxed on the full nominal gain, not the marginal rates on the real gain, as this Government has in its proper tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—Senator Messner said it yesterday. Let us get it quite clear. Yesterday Senator Messner said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . as long as the law was modified, possibly to merely have specific time limits on sale of assets for capital gains, such as the existing-

TALK.START.PARA: —You modified it. Why don't you represent it-
—Oh, shut up for a minute. Senator Messner continued:

ANSWER.PARA: Section 26AAA, would sufficiently serve the purpose of a capital gains tax on speculative profits.

How about that? So do not ask me about the quote. The quote is dead right. The fact of the matter is that what they are about is the most vicious, the most punitive, the most savage capital gains tax that this country could have; that is, full marginal rates on the full nominal gain. By contrast, the Government has a capital gains tax at the full marginal rates on the real gain with inflation washed out of the system. Senator Messner went on to make it quite clear that he does not think that the coalition could repeal a capital gains tax.

Senator Messner also made it clear that the existing method of taxing some capital gains-section 26 (a) or section 25A-could be amended to get around the problems of its administration. Senator Messner makes two or three clear points about capital gains taxation. He says that section 25A can no longer and should no longer work in its present way with the Russian roulette operating under the Taxation Commissioner's discretion. He makes that clear. He says that the existing capital gains provisions are inadequate and that we must do something about section 25A. He goes on further to say that the way to do it is to extend section 26AAA to a medium term capital gains tax against speculative gains. That is a tax at the full marginal rate on the full nominal gains. Here we have the coalition parties which made absolute harlots of themselves on this issue at the last election campaign, coming round to the most savage, most penal, capital gains proposal this country could see.

Where is all this flat tax to be paid for? There was some vague mention of expenditure control. But when the shadow Treasurer is asked about where the expenditure control will be, he says that he will not start brush fires by nominating expenditure controls. This Government can wear the public opprobrium of wiping out tax shelters to produce the revenue to pay for tax changes, but apparently the Opposition believes it has to identify no such revenue for its tax changes, that it can just say that it will look at expenditure control and the rest of the country should accept that, while the discipline on the Government-

I will just wind up on this point: It has been a very interesting week because we now have bipartisanship in this country on capital gains taxation. That is an advance. However, this Government's capital gains tax is fairer than the punitive one signalled by the Opposition. What we do not have is some decency in public policy whereby the coalition at least identifies where the revenue will come from for the tax changes that it proposes. That is why it is that only from this side of the House will the public of this country get a decent, fair, equitable and efficient tax system and more growth, prosperity and employment than any of the policies of the coalition will provide. I make it abundantly clear that Australia's credit rating is as good as it ever was. This very day Moodys, one of the two major assessing houses in the world-the other one is Standard and Poors-has given Australia a triple A rating once again. So much for that. The Prime Minister has just handed me a statement of the former Treasurer, who said:

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that if they-
the Australian Labor Party's economic policies-

are implemented in Australia our international economic reputation would be affected and so far from instilling that private sector business confidence, which in theory everybody agrees is necessary, I believe it would have the opposite effect.

It comes from the Liberal Party which is about market outcomes. It comes from the Liberal Party which is now witnessing interest rates in this country being set at tender in a public process in public markets. It is really saying that it wants the Government to rule the markets down. It simply wants interest rates to decline and it wants the Government to do something about it.
