—Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the growing impatience and frustration of Queensland cane growers regarding the delay in decisions following the report in August of the sugar industry working party? Would it be reasonable to assume that the position being projected by the Queensland Government during discussions is consistent with the interests of the large milling companies and the major supporters of the Queensland branch of the National Party of Australia? Can the Minister inform the House of the progress that has been made and of his understanding of the stage reached in coming to a joint decision for a package of assistance for the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will set out for honourable members the reason for the frustration in the Queensland sugar growing industry. It is rather interesting that no National Party members ask me questions in this House about the sugar industry, because they are just as confused as their Queensland counterparts. This industry is a difficult one to deal with. It is an industry that is bound up in some 70 years of regulation involving two boards and judges setting prices. It is centred principally in Queensland and the Queensland Government controls its legislation. In November of 1984, during the election campaign, the Prime Minister and I met with the Queensland Cane Growers Council so that we could break what was virtually a political deadlock in terms of moves by the Government to assist this industry. In other words, there are two fundamental political problems: It is an industry bound by regulation, and is not likely to accept any suggestions about deregulation, and it is involved with the Queensland Government, which sets out as its main purpose the bringing down of this Federal Government. The Premier says that all the time but we do not wander around saying those sorts of things; we are trying to help the sugar industry.

ANSWER.PARA: The cane growers agreed to get the Queensland Government to come to see us, or we would see them, with the industry, so that we could discuss the industry in a non-political and sane atmosphere. Eventually the Premier of Queensland consented to talk to the Commonwealth Government about the sugar industry and that meeting took place on 1 April, some four or five months later. Out of that meeting we set up a 100-day working party which eventually became known as the sugar industry working party. The report of that party, made up of the Commonwealth Government, the Queensland Government and industry-the three concerned groups-was presented to the two Ministers, Mr Turner and myself, on 14 August. At that stage I was ready, due to a Cabinet decision by my Government, to negotiate with the Queensland Government on the recommendations of the report. It must be said that the report was agreed to by the Commonwealth, the State Government and the industry. It made recommendations in four areas partially about deregulation, partially about rural adjustment, partially about research and, also, most importantly, about income support. On 23 September the Cabinet met again to discuss the progress that had been made because after the handing over of the report on 14 August there was no contact from the Queensland Government. It was very busy, it said, consulting with the industry before it would talk to us.

Following the Cabinet decision and the announcement we made in Townsville, Mr Turner and Mr Hallam met with me on 25 September. Out of that meeting, particularly following discussions with Mr Turner, came an agreement-I have it here before me-which was confirmed in correspondence. It is an agreed schedule of deregulation drawn up as a result of the Commonwealth-Queensland meeting of 25 September 1985. We reached agreement on that on the basis of a nine page document supplied by the Queensland Government headed: `The Queensland Government position on the report of the Sugar Industry Working Party'. I thought we had reached some agreement on the basis of those disussions about that and also about rural adjustment assistance and research. There was no agreement reached on the levels or methods of income support because Mr Turner had no power to negotiate. What has happened since then is a fair reflection of the Byzantine workings of the Queensland Government. I also met with Mr Hallam on that day; both Ministers had to go to their Cabinet on 30 September. Whereas the New South Wales Labor Government was able to respond-I have here a telex from Mr Hallam, the New South Wales Minister-the Queensland Government was not able to respond.

What happened, of course, was that the Queensland Minister gave to the industry his nine-page paper. In other words, he leaked the wrong document. That caused a lot of confusion. Since that time I have been trying to work out what has been happening in Queensland. Quite frankly, Mr Turner does not answer the telexes I send to him asking for the status of this agreed schedule, and neither can officials get anything from officials. What the Queensland Government does not understand about the question of income support is that if it is not to be involved in price support for the industry the Commonwealth Government will have to deal directly with the industry to try to get money into it. Of course, in the meantime, the National Party, particularly at the State level, has been running away at the mouth. Mr Menzel has one theory and some other member has another. All sorts of theories are being bandied about. Some people are saying that because the price has picked up a little there is no need for assistance or that assistance will not trigger.

The whole problem is that the Queensland Premier will not take a decision, so he says, unless the industry is totally agreed. In other words, he is not prepared to show any leadership or take any hard decision, nor is he prepared to put any money into his own industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has put in $40m.

—That is just a lie. He has put very little money in and he keeps running that lie. The industry has been consulted. It was involved for at least the last 40 days of the 100-day sugar industry working party. The industry had representatives on that working party. There have been responses since. I would have thought, in terms of all the consultation that has gone on, not just this year but over the last year, that the Queensland National Party would at least now have reached the situation where it could express an opinion. In fact, I thought it had expressed an opinion. But, as I said, due to the Byzantine politics in Queensland and the lack of leadership of the National Party in that State, it is near impossible to get any sort of answer from that Government. We do not have the same problems with the New South Wales Labor Party. What is going on in Queensland is nonsensical.

ANSWER.PARA: I would have thought that by now, given the announcement we made in Townsville, members of the sugar industry and the National Party in this House and in Queensland would have realised that we are prepared to assist this industry at least to an amount of $150m on two conditions: First, that there be some price support from Queensland and agreement on the method and level of financing of this industry and, secondly, that there be some moves with respect to restructuring of the industry, not because of any ideological belief but because, if the taxpayers are to put hundreds of millions of dollars into the industry, there is a need to try to give that industry a better cost structure at the end of the three-year period of assistance. It is the National Party in Queensland which is holding up assistance to this industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. In the answer that the Minister gave to the question on sugar he read from a document outlining the agreement with New South Wales. I wonder whether the Minister will table that document.
—Was the Minister quoting from a document on public affairs?

—No, Mr Speaker. I read the heading of the Queensland Government position paper. I referred to the agreed schedule of de- regulation drawn up as a result of the Commonwealth-Queensland meeting and I merely waved around the telex from Mr Hallam and quoted no part of it.

—Order! I advise the House that we have present in the gallery Mr David Buffett, the Chief Minister of Norfolk Island, and two of his executive colleagues. I am sure that the Chief Minister appreciates the warm welcome he receives. I welcome him to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Clerk-Notice has been received from the Leader of the Opposition of his intention at the next sitting to move:
That this House censures the Prime Minister for his handling of matters related to the Australian Bicentennial Authority and specifically-
(1) his gross administrative incompetence and neg- ligence regarding the payout of over $500,000 to Dr Armstrong;
(2) his attempts to cover up and suppress his own role in initiating Dr Armstrong's removal and approving the payout;
(3) his persistent refusal to make full disclosure of relevant facts to the Parliament, and
(4) his attempts to blame others for his own administrative failures and mistakes.
Motion (by Mr Young)-by leave-agreed to:

That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith the motion of censure of the Prime Minister of which he has given notice for the next sitting.
Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Prime Minister for his handling of matters related to the Australian Bicentennial Authority and specifically-
(1) his gross administrative incompetence and negligence regarding the payout of over $500,000 to Dr Armstrong;
(2) his attempts to cover up and suppress his own role in initiating Dr Armstrong's removal and approving the payout;
(3) his persistent refusal to make full disclosure of relevant facts to the Parliament, and
(4) his attempts to blame others for his own administrative failures and mistakes.

It is perfectly obvious from the answer that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave in the Parliament today that he regards the concept of ministerial responsibility so far as he is concerned as an absolute joke. He may treat the concept of ministerial responsibility as a joke and the Leader of the House (Mr Young) may treat it as a joke but, quite clearly, the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) does not regard the question of ministerial responsibility as a joke. I say to the Prime Minister that many people in Australia, not only members of the Opposition, neither treat the concept of ministerial responsibility as a joke nor regard the behaviour of the Prime Minister on this matter as an issue to be dealt with by laughter and indifference.

It was perfectly plain from the Prime Minister's conduct yesterday, when he took part in the matter of public importance, that he regarded the tabling of the report of the Solicitor-General as being in some way the great Hawke king hit on the whole matter. At the end of the matter of public importance he was almost breathless coming toward the end of his allotted 15 minutes. He tried, in dramatic tones, to grab everybody's attention and said: `Madam Deputy Speaker, we now have the report of the Solicitor-General and it will vindicate everything that I, as Prime Minister, have done in this matter'. So far from that happening, so far from the report of the Solicitor-General being a king hit against those who criticise the Prime Minister's role in this matter, it has turned out to be a king hit against the Prime Minister himself.

The document that was to vindicate the Prime Minister, the document that was to demonstrate that at all times the Prime Minister had a firm grip on the administration of the Australian Bicentennial Authority, the document that was to indict John Reid, the document that was to implicate John Reid and Dr Armstrong, the document that was to clear the Prime Minister of any kind of culpability and guilt in the whole matter is the very document which has underlined the administrative failure and incompetence of the Prime Minister in the conduct of his ministerial responsibilities in the whole matter. That is why the Opposition brings forward this censure motion today. That is why it has not been prepared to let this matter rest on the basis of the material made available yesterday. That is why the Opposition asks the Prime Minister today to tell the House whether he believes that he discharged his ministerial responsibilities. Because of the inadequate answer given by the Prime Minister to that question the Opposition brings forth this censure motion.

I remind the House of the terms of this motion. It seeks the censure of this House of the Prime Minister for, firstly, his gross administrative incompetence and negligence regarding the $500,000 payout to Dr Armstrong; secondly, his attempts to cover up and suppress his own role in initiating Dr Armstrong's removal and approving the payout; thirdly, his unwillingness to make full disclosure of relevant facts to the Parliament; and, finally, and I think most blameworthy of all, his attempts to blame others for his own administrative failures and mistakes. It is worth reminding the House of that very bland and innocent Press statement that was issued by the Prime Minister on 11 September when news of the whole matter first broke. When Laurie Oakes, on the Today show, on the morning of 11 September first disclosed that there had been a payout of almost $500,000 to Dr Armstrong, the Prime Minister's office issued a very simple Press statement which made it very plain that the Prime Minister had had a discussion with Mr Reid.

Let me read the Press statement because it bears recalling precisely in what way the Prime Minister set out to mislead the House and the way in which he tried to dissemble-the way in which the Prime Minister as early as 11 September was starting to shift blame to other people. These are the Prime Minister's words in the Press release:

I have been asked about reports of the settlement of the terms of the contract of the former General Manager of the Australian Bicentennial Authority, Dr David Armstrong. In recent weeks I have had several dis- cussions with the Chairman of the Authority, Mr Reid, about both the specific criticism of the ABA and the plans that were being made for the 1988 celebrations.
Listen to this:
After these discussions took place, Mr Reid and Dr Armstrong concluded that the interests of the Authority would be best served if Dr Armstrong were to leave its services.
He then went on to say:

The negotiation of the terms of settlement of that departure was, as it had to be under the terms of the legislation establishing the ABA, entirely a matter between the Chairman and Dr Armstrong. I have no comment to add to those terms.
What he was saying was that it was all a matter between the Chairman of the Authority and the former Chief Executive of the Authority.

Of course the Government would like yesterday to have been the last of the matter. Of course the Government did not want us to bring it up again today. Of course as far as the Government is concerned it is a great big joke, and the whole concept of ministerial responsibility for this Prime Minister as far as his affairs are concerned is a great big joke. After all, he is the man who told Mr Reid to get rid of Dr Armstrong. He told him to do it quickly, quietly, and to err on the side of generosity. He thanked him for moving so quickly. Now he has the audacity to pretend that it is all somebody else's fault. Fascinatingly enough, the thing that has brought the Prime Minister unstuck and the document that has demonstrated to the people of Australia how careless, negligent and indifferent this Prime Minister has been about his ministerial responsibilities on this occasion is the very document the Prime Minister thought was to be his life raft in this whole debate. I have not the slightest doubt that when the Prime Minister came into the debate yesterday he saved up Dr Griffith's report right to the end and he thought: `I will slam it down on the dispatch box right at the end of the speech. This is my king hit. It is about 150 pages long. This report will fix them. It will fix Reid, it will fix Howard, it will fix Allen, Allen and Hemsley. It will fix everybody else and will completely clear me of any kind of involvement or any kind of blame in this whole matter'.

Of course, the reverse has proved to be the case. What the document did very clearly, if we are to accept the document as being an accurate analysis of all the legal and factual issues involved in this dispute, was to drive home to the Australian public one thing with brutal clarity. It is that the Prime Minister himself was totally negligent in not obtaining that opinion weeks ago and that if the Prime Minister had been doing his job competently, if he had been careful about the money of the public of Australia, if he had worried about the $500,000, he would have got that report weeks ago. He would not have waited until he was under parliamentary and public pressure. He would not have waited until he was being criticised. He would have embarked upon one of the most fundamental things of ordinary prudent administration in government, that is, get the advice of the relevant department. One does not always take it. It is the mark of a good Minister and of a good Prime Minister not always to take the advice of his department, but it is the mark of a foolish and careless Minister or Prime Minister that he thinks he is so good he never gets the advice of the experts who are available in government.

The Prime Minister thought he was too good to get the advice of the mere humble Solicitor-General. He was too good to get the advice of the Tax Commissioner. He was too good to get the advice of his own Department. Remember the evidence of Rose before the Senate Committee? He said that that letter of 28 August `came as a complete surprise to us'. But this Prime Minister is too good to get advice. He might get advice on the telephone from his mate, from the minder who listens in to private telephone conversations with the Prime Minister, but does he get the advice of the Solicitor-General or of the Tax Commissioner? Does he check out whether what the Chairman is saying is correct? Does he check out the legal opinion of Allen, Allen and Hemsley? Of course he does not. But he gets into trouble, he is found out, he is flushed out and people realise they have been misled. So far from having nothing to do with the settlement between Armstrong and Reid, which the Prime Minister pretended to be the case on 11 September, it is established after questioning and scrutiny bit by bit, answer by answer, dragged out of the Prime Minister, that, so far from having nothing to do with it, he was the architect of the whole arrangement. He was the person who called Reid in and said: `I don't care what you say. Get rid of him. Get rid of him quickly. Do it quietly, err on the side of generosity-and for heaven's sake keep it quiet'. That is what the Prime Minister did, despite what he said on 11 September.

The Press statement of 11 September stands as a dissembling piece of misleading deception by this Prime Minister. He sought by that Press statement to mislead the Australian public and to mislead the Parliament. Having got into difficulty, having been forced by the pressure of public and other opinion to admit that he had in fact prevailed on Mr Reid to get rid of Dr Armstrong, did he then do the responsible thing? Did he then come into the Parliament and say to the Parliament: `Look, I made a mistake. It was my idea. Reid did not want to get rid of him. I don't think Reid was correct, but I as Prime Minister determined that my will should prevail over Reid. I told him to get rid of Dr Armstrong, and the haste of getting rid of Dr Armstrong was one of the reasons why the payout was so large. I lay out all the facts and I accept responsibility for the matter'? Did this Prime Minister do that? Having been found out, did he admit his role in the matter? Of course he did not.

Having been found out and having been demonstrated to have misled the public, he then embarked on another shabby little exercise. He then cast around in very courageous fashion for a scapegoat. That is a good principle, is it not, for the Prime Minister when he is in a corner? When he has a problem, when he has been found out on misleading us, when he has been shown to be incompetent, what does he then do? He casts around for a scapegoat. He sought the scapegoat in the person of Mr Reid. I have to say about Mr Reid that at all material times in this matter Mr Reid was doing the Prime Minister's bidding. If Mr Reid did something wrong, he did something wrong because the Prime Minister wanted him to do something wrong. That is the fact that comes out in all the documentation and all the developments in this matter. What does the Prime Minister do? He casts around for a scapegoat and says: `I have got a scapegoat. I will get rid of John Reid; I will dump it all on John Reid. I will blame him for the fact that we have got into this mess, and I will somehow or other try to transfer to Reid the blame and the odium for that huge payout having been made, perhaps in circumstances where there was no legal liability'. So what does he do? He casts around to find some basis on which he can have Mr Reid blamed for this episode.

The Prime Minister constructs two alibis. The first alibi he constructs is that of tax minimisation. The second alibi he constructs is that Reid misled him about the nature of the settlement. Interestingly enough, the first alibi is exploded by none other than the report of the Solicitor-General that was supposed to be the life raft of the Prime Minister in this whole matter. If one reads section 46 of the report of the Solicitor-General, one sees that he disputes the assertion made by the Prime Minister at his Press conference on 26 September that Mr Reid had been involved and had promoted tax minimisation. So strike one against the Prime Minister's attempt to make Mr Reid the scapegoat.

The second attempt by the Prime Minister to make Mr Reid a scapegoat was in some way to allege that Mr Reid had misled him about the terms of the contract and the terms of the settlement. Yet the documents tabled before the Senate Estimates Committee and the documents tabled in this Parliament, and they go undenied in substance by the Prime Minister, demonstrate clearly that Mr Reid kept the Prime Minister informed. He told the Prime Minister in his letter of 19 August the nature of the buy-out. He told the Prime Minister in his telephone conversation of 19 August. He told the Prime Minister by letter of 28 August. If the Prime Minister is puzzled, is now concerned and claims to have been misled, why did he not express that concern on the 19th, on the 28th or on the 30th when he wrote in effect giving written approval to Mr Reid for the allocation of the funds that would be involved?

Why on earth, if the Prime Minister was concerned, if he had been misled, if he believed one thing and was then being told another, did he not give voice to those concerns and to that puzzlement on those three opportunities that presented themselves? The truth is that the Prime Minister could not have cared less as late as early September what the payout was. He could not have cared less about the basis of the settlement. If he had cared about the basis of the settlement, he would have sought the advice of Dr Griffith. Surely a Prime Minister who is told that $500,000 is going to be paid to somebody for five or six years' work as a payout can only be doing his duty in the most elementary way if he says to the Government's lawyers: `Is this okay?'. Why did not the Prime Minister go to the Government's lawyers before the cement had been set, before the cheque had been paid over to Dr Armstrong and say: `Look, this is what Reid says; this is what Allen Allen and Hemsley say. Is it okay? Am I protected? Am I doing the right thing by the public's money? Am I doing the right thing in the discharge of my ministerial duty?'. Did this Prime Minister do that? No, he did not. This Prime Minister was too good; he was too clever; he was too smart; and he organised the thing far too effectively to do that. This Prime Minister said: `Go ahead, John, do it. Good on you for doing such a good deal. Thanks for getting it done so quickly. I want you to err on the side of generosity and, above everything else, will you please not say anything about it; will you please all keep it under wraps?'.

Of course, having done that, having been found out and having been exposed for having misled the public, he then resorts to the very shabby device of trying to blame somebody else for a debacle of which he was the prime architect. If Reid deserves to go and to be condemned, this man deserves to be condemned for his role in this affair because it was his idea to get rid of Armstrong. He may or may not have had good grounds to get rid of him. That is not really the point. The point is his own ministerial involvement. He said: `Get rid of him; get rid of him quickly; pay a reasonable amount for it; err on the side of generosity; keep it all hushed up; don't tell anybody the details of it but, I tell you what, if I get caught out, if I am found out and I am exposed, you will carry the blame for it, not me, because I am the Prime Minister and I cannot be expected to carry any of the blame for a problem that arises as the result of a decision I have made'. That is the standard that the Prime Minister has applied on this occasion.

I say to the House that, having come into the debate yesterday, having lifted up the report of the Solicitor-General and having no doubt thought to himself: `Well, my king hit will be the tabling of this report; this report will fix them; that will silence the Opposition; that will demonstrate how Reid misled everybody and will put me completely in the clear and I can go on to other matters', the Prime Minister now finds that so far from the Solicitor-General's report being a king hit against the Opposition or against Mr Reid or Dr Armstrong, it is a king hit against the Prime Minister himself.

The Solicitor-General's report leaves the Prime Minister jammed right in the middle. If the Solicitor-General is right, the simple question the Australian public wants answered is: Why did not the Prime Minister get the right advice before 30 August when the money was paid over? That is the only question to which they want to know the answer. They want to know why the Prime Minister did not get it before 30 August; why did he not get it before the horse had bolted; why did he not get it before the money was paid over to Armstrong? So, if the Solicitor-General is right, the Prime Minister now has to tell the public why he did not get that right advice before 30 August, why he did not have the concerns and why he did not express the concerns and the puzzlement that he now, with great enthusiasm, says that he had always had.

On the other hand, if in fact the report of the Solicitor-General is not to be believed, if in fact the legal analysis of the report of the Solicitor-General is wrong, what justification can there possibly be for the Prime Minister's conduct in getting rid of Mr Reid? Because, in getting rid of Mr Reid, the Prime Minister is asking Mr Reid to accept a greater responsibility for things done by Mr Reid at the behest of the Prime Minister than the Prime Minister is himself prepared to accept responsibility for. It is a pretty fundamental breach of ordinary human dealings with people to say to somebody who does something at one's instruction in one's name at some risk to himself: `If something goes wrong, you can carry the blame, I will go scot-free and I will not accept any of the responsibility'. So, on either count the Prime Minister is jammed and condemned by the report of the Solicitor-General. On either basis, the House ought to pass the motion of censure against the Prime Minister's conduct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker, I believe it is appropriate at the outset of this debate to test the integrity of the person who leads for the Opposition on the motion of censure of the Prime Minister because if there is anyone in this whole episode who comes out with grubbiness and with a total lack of integrity it is the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). Let me establish that point at the outset. It will be recalled by all members of this House that, on 19 September, I tabled a number of documents. The first page of that set of documents was one which was tabled in error. That is a fact which was conveyed to the Leader of the Opposition here on the floor of the House. He knows that it was tabled in error because in fact it referred to some personal characteristic of Dr Armstrong which it would have been totally inappropriate and unfair to have had tabled in this House. I spoke to the Leader of the Opposition on this matter and informed him that it had been tabled in error. He understood that but he was not prepared, as any decent person leading the Opposition would have been prepared to do, to accept the fact of it being tabled in error and for it to be withdrawn. There was no possible advantage to the Leader of the Opposition. However, he insisted that it go in with a whiting-out of this reference.

SPEECH.PARA: That was bad enough. But what happened then? Following that, the next day he came out and said to this House and to the people of Australia that the Prime Minister misled the Parliament and misled the people because there was a second page of this document which he did not put in. He knew on the floor of this House and had been told that it had been tabled in error. We wanted it withdrawn because it went to the question of the personal characteristic of Dr Armstrong. The Leader of the Opposition went around this country trying to say in regard to something on which he knew the total factual situation that this was a deliberate misleading. He knew that it was not the case but such is his attempt to try to bolster his position that truth has no concern for this man no concern whatever. He knew the facts but he said: `Well, we will try to twist the truth in this matter to see what we can get out of it'.

The judgment will be made of the Leader of the Opposition who makes this attack upon me when he knows that he deliberately misled this House and the people of Australia on that issue. The honourable gentleman has continued to do it. Every time has has spoken about the question of what happened on 15 August he keeps on saying that there was an instruction given by me to Mr Reid to dismiss Dr Armstrong. He knows that this is not the case. He knows that what happened on 15 August was that I discussed this issue with Mr Reid, that I conveyed to him for the reasons which are now obvious to the House that it was in the best interests of the Australian Bicentennial Authority and certainly in the best interests of the preparation for the bicentennial celebration that the services of Dr Armstrong should be terminated.

That was the view I put strongly to Mr Reid. But there was no sense then in which I instructed Mr Reid. Never once did I instruct him and there was no word of mine by which I instructed him because, as a matter of law, I had no authority or capacity under the law so to instruct the Chairman of the ABA. But does that fact concern the Leader of the Opposition? He has consistently and persistently said from the beginning that I instructed Mr Reid. He knows that it is a deliberate untruth for him to say so, but he continues to put it. That is the measure of what credence once can attach to the Leader of the Opposition when he talks in this matter. He deliberately misled the people of Australia in regard to 19 September and he has consistently misled and misrepresented about what happened in regard to 15 August. There was no instruction because there could not be.

That leads us then to a consideration of just where the Leader of the Opposition is in this matter. As I said yesterday, when people come to look at this issue in the future, what will be the central issue is the question of what are the standards that should apply, particular to a public authority, in regard to the matter of tax minimisation or avoidance. Even at this late stage not a word has come from the Leader of the Opposition to say that he or the Opposition has any attitude against the concept that a public authority should in any way be engaged in tax minimisation. This should not come as any surprise, given the record of the current Leader of the Opposition, the previous Treasurer of this country, under whom, of course, the tax avoidance and evasion industry became the only growth industry in this country. The present Leader of the Opposition is thoroughly tainted through and and through with association with and condemnation of the practices of tax avoidance, evasion and minimisation. So it is little wonder that when we reach this late stage of this debate we still have no condemnation from the Leader of the Opposition of what has obviously transpired in this case.

The Leader of the Opposition went on to say that at all times the Chairman of the Authority was doing the Prime Minister's bidding. Again he knows that that is not the truth. But we have to recognise that when we are dealing with this incumbent of the position of Leader of the Opposition we are dealing with a person for whom truth matters not at all. He knows from the written record and he knows particularly that it was at Mr Reid's insistence that the negotiations on this matter were something from which I was divorced. Mr Reid said to me on 19 August that this was a matter which he must and will conduct. We had the situation, of which the Leader of the Opposition is totally aware, that that was the position of the Chairman of the Authority after I had put my view to him that the General Manager should go. I put that to him and he said: `I will go away and think about it'. He went away and thought about it. He came back to me on the 19th and said to me: `All right, I accept that but, Mr Prime Minister, you must accept that as a matter of law I, the Chairman of the Authority, am going to conduct this matter'.

That is the fact. The Leader of the Opposition knows it is the fact, but he gets up in this place now and, in moving this motion, says `at all times Mr Reid was doing the Prime Minister's bidding'. The opposite is true because as far as the negotiation of that matter is concerned Mr Reid insisted that he should handle that. Once he had made his decision that he would accept the recommendation I put it was not an instruction because there could not be one-he then handled the matter and insisted that it should be so. He handled it in the context of saying to me on 19 August that he would be handling it in terms of there having been the need to buy out this contract with six years to go, which would give the sort of amount of money which we now know is at issue.

He went away from me insisting that he would conduct this matter on those terms. I had no reason at all to believe that he would then do other than act according to the indication he had given me. He went away; he was involved in the negotiations; he handled them; and at every material point from 19 August up to and including the night of 26 September when I finally indicated that I wanted the resignation of Mr Reid. Mr Reid did not demur from the proposition that he was conducting those negotiations in terms of buying out a contract which had six years to run. Even on the 26th, in the final hours before his resignation was tendered and accepted, he was saying that that was the framework and he was acting because he thought that if he did not do that he could be up for an action from Dr Armstrong for wrongful dismissal. It was only on that night, not before, that he produced the letter of 12 October 1979, I think it was, which made it crystal clear that any suggestion of buying out six years of the contract was a nonsense. The letter of 12 October, which was not produced to me before then but was produced on 26 September, made it crystal clear that the whole edifice upon which this negotiation had been constructed was not in accordance with the facts.

So, Mr Speaker, you have it from 19 August to 10 September in conversation with him. Again let me remind the House as I did yesterday that I spelt this out in this House on 19 September. Five days later Mr Reid reported to the Bicentennial Authority that the record of what the Prime Minister had said was accurate. So he accepted before the Board on the 24th that what he was doing-he was negotiating, not the Prime Minister-was on the basis of buying out a contract for six years. He confirmed to the Board that what I had said to the Parliament was accurate. That was the 24th. So we had it on 19 August, 10 September, 19 September, confirmed on 24 September and then in the final conversations on 26 September, when the resignation was tendered and accepted, again the clear statement and acceptance that what was being done was the buying out of six years of contract. In those circumstances I accepted what Mr Reid was doing because I had no reason to believe, even up to a half hour before he resigned, that he had been doing anything differently.

The question of taking advice has been raised. I received a letter on 28 August from Mr Reid. I remind you, Mr Speaker, that it was a letter which made no mention of the fact that it was largely academic at any rate because the deed had been signed five days earlier on 23 August. Having signed it on 23 August, he wrote to me on the 28th and asked for my approval. What did I do? I got advice. The Leader of the Opposition said that I took no advice. I took advice from my Department. The advice from my Department was associated with advice from the Attorney-General's Department, which advice I accepted. I accepted the advice given to me that this was not a matter for me to approve, that the approval of this, was a matter for the Bicentennial Authority. So I replied.

It was stated in this debate on the censure motion that I did not take any advice; I was too proud; I would not listen to my Department. The very fact is that the letter which I wrote and sent to him on 30 August, not approving the settlement but saying to Mr Reid that it was his responsibility, was based precisely on the advice which I sought from my Department in association with the Attorney-General's Department, and which I accepted.

That advice was given under the law. What law? It is the law that was created by honour- able members opposite. We did not create this law. Honourable members opposite put the Prime Minister and the Government at arm's length. I operated on that advice. If I made a mistake in this matter I have indicated it. For too long I accepted that the Chairman of the Australian Bicentennial Authority was putting the position to me honestly and accurately. However we find, but not until the death knell on 26 September, that the whole edifice of advice that he had put to me was not in accordance with the document and the contractual relationship. The mistake I made was accepting for too long the proposition that the Chairman of the Bicentennial Authority would not have misled me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of issues were raised. There is the question of ministerial responsibility, the matter of Dr Armstrong's resignation, the resignation of Mr Reid, the actions of the Prime Minister, the payout to Dr Armstrong and, now, the advice given by the Solicitor-General in relation to this matter. It would be fair to start by making available to all honourable members who have not read it the letter from Dr Armstrong to Mr Reid on his resignation on 22 August. I take the time of the House to read it because honourable members will get in context the problems that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been facing in relation to the Australian Bicentennial Authority. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Reid,

As you know, the Bicentennial Authority has been the object of increasing questions and criticism in recent months, both publicly and privately. In my view, that criticism has been largely ill-informed. The questions raised have been dealt with fully and firmly, one by one; I believe that the answers given have been generally satisfactory to the Government, the media and the community as a whole.

Nevertheless, the criticism has left in its wake a vague, generalised disquiet concerning the Authority and its management. More specifically, critics of the Authority continue to express their concerns at my own approach to the role of Chief Executive. I do not accept the validity of those concerns, but nonetheless, I have to recognise that despite every effort to define and respond to them, they continue to exist.

The coming months represent a critical phase in the Authority's development. Already much has been accomplished. The Authority is now moving from program concepts and planning to implementation. This transformation, I firmly believe, simply cannot be accomplished successfully in the current environment in which criticism of the Authority and of myself is having a destabilising effect on the conduct of its affairs. The Authority has such critical paths to determine and such tight, immovable deadlines, that it simply cannot afford such instability. I have therefore concluded very reluctantly that it would be self-indulgent of me to continue to stand and fight the critics although that is, of course, my natural inclination when to do so might place at risk all that we have achieved so far and the success of the Bicentennial itself.

I therefore consider it my duty to stand aside in the earnest hope that this gesture will satisfy the critics and permit the Authority to successfully complete its important work. Accordingly, I hereby give you notice of my resignation from the position of Chief Executive of the Authority, in accordance with the Terms and Conditions of my Appointment.

There are three other paragraphs. The document is a public document and is available to everybody. First, it establishes that Dr Armstrong recognised that there was widespread criticism of his administration as Chief Executive of the Bicentennial Authority. It was bit just a criticism coming from the Prime Minister. It was, as established in the debate yesterday, criticism coming even from the Opposition, through its shadow spokesmen who, in July, long before these events, had written to the Prime Minister questioning the efficiency of the Authority. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) raised the question of the efficiency and the operations of the Bicentennial with the Prime Minister at the very time that the Prime Minister was involving himself in what was happening, and receiving criticisms from the honourable member for Bradfield and other people. Dr Armstrong recognised that and used it as the reason he submitted his resignation.

Secondly, he gave notice of his resignation `in accordance with the terms and conditions of my appointment'. We now find the terms and conditions of his appointment in a letter between Mr Reid and himself were four months notice either way. They were the terms of his employment. The terms were not that his contract should be bought out should he leave sometime before 1989, as was suggested earlier in the discussions or was the impression left from the discussions between Mr Reid and the Prime Minister, which led the Prime Minister to believe that the payout could be in the order of over $400,000 and perhaps approaching $500,000.

When the letter came to light expressing the arrangements that had been made by Mr Reid, the Chairman, and Dr Armstrong, it showed that there was four months notice either way. Frankly, I would have been surprised if there had been any other contract signed between a government authority and one of its employees, considering that that person would have been promised employment for up to 10 years. So firstly, Dr Armstrong recognised the criticism within the community; and secondly, he said; `It is an immovable object; we have to hold the celebrations in 1988. We cannot put it off for a while until we get things back on a more even keel, with me as Chief Executive'. Dr Armstrong recognised all that and resigned, which is what the Prime Minister said to Mr Reid would be in everybody's best interests when he held a meeting with him. Mr Reid did what he considered to be in the best interests of the Authority by seeking Dr Armstrong's resignation. All that came to pass.

The Opposition now raises the question of the $500,000. From the evidence given to this House, there is no doubt that the impression left with the Prime Minister was that we were buying out Dr Armstrong's contract and that was our responsibility. That was not the Government's responsibility. The letter given to Dr Armstrong by Mr Reid four years ago said that four months notice either way could be given. That was our legal responsibility, as was pointed out yesterday in the Solicitor-General's opinion. There was a marked contrast between the reality of the contract between the Authority and Dr Armstrong and what the Prime Minister was led to believe. Nevertheless, that having been settled, Mr Reid then placed himself in the precarious position of giving the Prime Minister the impression that the Authority would have to pay out that money.

All the cards are now on the table. Everybody knows exactly what happened. Someone has said that there should perhaps be some criticism of the Prime Minister for taking this action. The Prime Minister is the Minister responsible for the Australian Bicentennial Authority. There was a widespread criticism. In Dr Armstrong's letter of 22 August, he said that it would help the Authority if he resigned and got out. He recognised that the criticism was not just Government criticism but widespread community criticism which he could not overcome by staying in his position. He said that it was in the interests of the Authority and of Australia for him to resign, to get out and let somebody else carry on the task.

The Opposition has tried every tactic in bringing this matter forward for debate, as is its responsibility, and today it is the ministerial responsibility of the Prime Minister. The Opposition has said that things should have happened slightly differently, and it should have been brought home to the Prime Minister. We all know what the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration said in relation to ministerial responsibility. The Royal Commission said that the issue of ministerial responsibility is sometimes used by the Opposition in a very minor way to point up what it hopes will be a political embarrassment to the Government.

I suppose it is fair enough, if honourable members opposite are going to do that, to compare the conduct of this Government in regard to this issue with the conduct of the Fraser Administration on a couple of occasions when it had to look at ministerial responsibility. I remind honourable members what the Kelly Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems had to say about the colleague of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). What did the Committee inquiring into the meat scandal have to say about Mr Nixon and what he should be doing? The Royal Commission said that the Minister, Mr Nixon, did not deal with these allegations adequately and effectively. It said that the Minister had been grossly negligent in his duties. That is what the Royal Commission said about Mr Nixon. What was the reaction and the response of the government of the day to the criticism by the Committee of Mr Nixon's administration of his portfolio? The then Prime Minister stood up here and said that the Committee was wrong. He said: `The judge has misinterpreted the evidence given before him. I do not intend to take any action at all'. That was one response we had from Malcolm, the mate of the Leader of the National Party, in relation to the criticism of Mr Nixon by the Committee.

The all-party Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in September 1981 reported that the Australian Dairy Corporation had contravened General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade arrangements on minimum export prices. It further found that the responsible Minister had knowledge of the breach at least as early as September 1976 and that he did nothing. This was despite the Minister's numerous subsequent statements in the House denying any knowledge of the breach. It was despite his own subsequent statements that he regarded any breach of the GATT as totally unacceptable. The Minister was grossly derelict in his duties and he misled the Parliament, yet he not only remained in the Ministry but in the Cabinet. Who was that? The second speaker for the Opposition today, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), was found guilty by all these authorities in terms of his ministerial responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about you?

—We can take it one step further. The Deputy Leader of the National Party has opened up a new arena. He asks `What about you?'. I think we are entitled to put all the cards on the table, now that the honourable member has opened the debate up. Who will be Deputy Prime Minister if the coalition gets back into government? The right honourable member for New England will be Deputy Prime Minister. Let us look at what Mr Justice Cross said about the right honourable member for New England. My God, talk about parliamentary and ministerial responsibility! I was not going to get to this matter, but honourable members opposite did provoke me. On page 23 of the report of the Special Commission of Inquiry under Mr Justice Cross it was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It must be said that in his evidence to this Commission Mr Sinclair has retreated a considerable distance from the forthright and grave nature of his televised comments in his Canberra speech. And indeed, in an interview with a senior police officer between the time of that speech and his appearance at this Commission, Mr Sinclair retreated much further . . . The Commission comes very comfortably to the view that no such . . . proposal or representation as Mr Sinclair alleges occurred took place.
This is a statement made about somebody who will be the next Deputy Prime Minister in a conservative government. The Cross inquiry stated on page 24 of its report:

. . . it is clear that an independent magistrate had found that there was sufficient evidence to warrant Mr Sinclair standing trial and that a plurality of Senior and independent Counsel had recommended Mr Sinclair's prosecution . . . In the light of the number and status of persons unanimously recommending prosecution the direction of the Attorney-General that the trial proceed was at least understandable . . . It appears to this Commission that it would have been improbable in the extreme bordering on the impossible for such a prosecution suddenly to have been stopped by political direction.
Do honourable members remember all the allegations made at the Tattersall's Club by the right honourable member for New England?

TALK.START.PARA: —How is Mr Justice Hope?

—The right honourable member need not worry about opening up these things. The House will recall that a few minutes ago the right honourable member for New England was talking about Bourke's store. I thought he had Manning Clark on his staff as a research officer. He was going back into history. I will tell honourable members opposite what the Prime Minister did when he was running Bourke's store. He stopped all that nonsense about retail price maintenance, which those opposite would not do. They were allowing companies to fix their prices at the retail outlets. That is something the Prime Minister did. I will tell the House something else the Prime Minister did which was totally consistent with the action he has taken on Dr Armstrong. Honourable members know and the Australian public knows that one of the most beneficial superannuation schemes in this country belongs to parliamentarians. They also know that the person who has taken the action to ensure that these vast lump sums cannot be taken from taxpayers in future is this Prime Minister. After 1983, we had Sir Billy Snedden, Mr McLeay, Mr Fraser, Sir James Killen, Sir Billy McMahon and Mr Nixon all coming in here with their wheelbarrows and taking out about $500,000 in superannuation. It looked like the Liberal Party branch of the Builders Labourers Federation! They were coming in here with their wheelbarrows to take out their superannuation. This Government has put a stop to that.
—For 25 years of service, not five years.
—This is totally consistent with the action the Prime Minister has taken in relation to the payment made to Dr Armstrong. He was told we were buying out his six-year contract.
—You can't even count.
—I warn the honourable member for Bradfield.

—I can say to honourable members opposite that if they tell the people at the next election that when they get back into power they will change the parliamentary superannuation scheme back to the giant rip-off under the Fraser regime, they will never get votes. That is what they did. The big wheelbarrows were coming in. Malcolm got $540,000, and was already a multi-millionaire living in the western districts of Victoria. But he came and got 560,000 bucks from the taxpayers to retire on. Bob Hawke stopped that. By his actions and by taking responsibility for the Australian Bicentennial Authority, he is also going to stop this massive payout to Dr Armstrong. What the Prime Minister has done in relation to all of these matters has been perfectly correct. The ministerial responsibility shown by the Prime Minister has been far and above the conduct of many of the Ministers who served in the Fraser regime. I move:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:

2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all, fulfilling employment, a sustainable society conserving natural resources and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Create an Australian Ministry for Peace specifically devoted to peace-building and the non-violent resolution of conflict;
2. Convene a national Summit of Survival to discuss the issues of world disarmament, security and national and international co-operation;
3. Support the United Nations World Disarmament Campaign by allocating the equivalent of at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund peace activities;
4. Actively assist the International Year of Peace in 1986 by initiating programs for peace education, self help development and environmental repair;
5. Develop National Employment Programs to give priority to the planting and growing of forests, food-producing trees and other crops to assist the greening of Australia.

6. Implement National Recycling Programs to reuse water and to compost all presently wasted domestic sewage-sludge and organic garbage with mineral-rich gravel dust, a by-product from rock quarries and mines, into hygeinic humus, a natural fertiliser, for use in revitalising improverished soils.
7. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
