PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Home and Community Care Bill 1985 establishes the framework for a home and community care program. The Bill authorises the Commonwealth to pay financial assistance to the States and the Northern Territory under agreements with the Commonwealth for the provision of home and community care services. The companion of this Bill, which I will introduce shortly, is the Home and Community Care (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985. That Bill will amend four existing Commonwealth Acts to ensure that the home and community care program operates as intended. The four Acts are the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act 1970, the Home Nursing Subsidy Act 1956, the States Grants (Home Care) Act 1969, and the States Grants (Paramedical Services) Act 1969.

The home and community care, or HACC, program established by the Home and Community Care Bill 1985, which contains the agreement in the Schedule, will be a joint Commonwealth-State program. The financial assistance provided under the Bill will assist State and local governments and community organisations to provide a comprehensive range of home and community based care designed to provide basic maintenance and support services. Services are to be targeted at aged or disabled people, either directly or through their carers, to prevent their unnecessary or premature admission to long term residential care.

When this Government came to office it had before it an array of reports done over the last 10 years at both the Federal and State levels. These reports all recommended a change in the balance between institutional and community based services for aged and disabled people. Important among these was the report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, `In a Home or at Home: accommodation and home care for the aged'-the McLeay report-completed in 1982. Arguments for improving the planning and delivery of community based services have been given by organisations in the field and by aged and disabled people whose views have in many cases shaped the various reports to governments in this area. These arguments are compelling.

Many people doubt their continuing ability to provide for the needs of aged or disabled family members at home. In the past, families have felt that they have had no option but to encourage or seek institutional care for their relatives, even when this may be a quite inappropriate solution. The existence of services to provide ongoing support should be of help to all Australian families. In the long run this should mean that nursing home beds will be used only when this is the most suitable option. It will lead to the development of a continuum of services, with assessment and referral services being developed as an integral part of that overall system.

What little statistical evidence we have in this field demonstrates the need to develop a comprehensive range of home based services for aged and disabled people. The 1980 Australian Bureau of Statistics survey on disability revealed that around 325,000 people over 65 years were severely or moderately handicapped and that over 70 per cent of this group live in the community. That 325,000 represents 42 per cent of the total moderately and severely handicapped population. Other data shows that only about 10 per cent of aged people living at home regularly receive help from formal health or welfare agencies.

It was clear to successive governments that administrative arrangements in this area were cumbersome and unco-ordinated. Some services were administered and funded by the Commonwealth, while others were administered by and cost-shared with the States. Additional complexity was caused by the split in administration of related programs between two departments at the Commonwealth level and two or more departments at the State level. The Government has already acted to remove this artificial barrier to effective and efficient planning and administration of services by bringing together all major welfare-related service activities into one department. However, while the planning and delivery of services remains fragmented and unco-ordinated, it can legitimately be argued that needs are not being met under the existing arrangements.

On 21 August 1984 a joint Press statement was issued by the Minister for Health, the Hon. Neal Blewett, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator the Hon. Arthur Gietzelt, and Senator Don Grimes as the then Minister for Social Security, to introduce the HACC program. Since then, there have been extensive negotiations with the States, and talks with service providers and other appropriate non-government organisations and service users on the shape and content of the program. The views of these governments, organisations and individuals have been taken into account in formulating the home and community care program and the supporting Commonwealth-State agreement. A feature of the new HACC program will be to ensure that service providers and users are involved in the future development of home and community care.
The two main objectives of the program are:

to promote the provision of a comprehensive and integrated range of home and community care designed to provide basic maintenance and support services both directly and through their carers to persons within the target population and thereby to assist them to retain their independence in the community and avoid their premature or unnecessary admission to long term residential care; and

to expand and develop home and community care services through the joint co-operation of the Commonwealth, the States, local governments and community organisations representing both service providers and users under a single cost-shared arrangement.
Services in a State funded under four existing Commonwealth Acts will be subsumed in the program once the State enters into a Home and Community Care Agreement with the Commonwealth. Those Acts are:

the States Grants (Home Care) Act 1969, under which the Commonwealth cost-shares with the States the provision of home care services and senior citizens centres, and cost-shares with organisations the salaries of welfare officers of senior citizens centres;

the States Grants (Paramedical Services) Act 1969 under which, in the three participating States, the Commonwealth cost-shares the provision of home based paramedical services such as physiotherapy and occupational therapy;
the Home Nursing Subsidy Act 1956, which provides for Commonwealth subsidy to home nursing organisations not exceeding the contribution of State or local governments to the home nursing service; and
the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act 1970 under which the Commonwealth provides various levels of assistance to organisations delivering meals to the aged or to invalid pensioners.

The program will provide financial assistance for recurrent or capital purposes to assist States, local government and non-government bodies to maintain or expand appropriate services funded under one of the four existing Commonwealth Acts, or to develop agreed new service types. Services which may be funded under the program will be included in the following 11 sub-programs: Home help or personal care, or both; home maintenance or modification, or both; food; community respite care; transport; a community paramedical service; community nursing; assessment or referral, or both; education or training for service providers and users, or both; information; and co-ordination. Financial assistance under the program will be by way of grants to the States and the Northern Territory. In line with its responsibility for day to day administration under the jointly established program, the State will either apply the financial assistance directly or will pay it to local governments or non-government agencies to be applied to services under the program in the local area.

In the first two years of the program, Commonwealth grants have a number of components and will, in part, be matched by contributions from each participating State and the Northern Territory. The base grant consists of the Commonwealth's expenditure under the four existing Acts in the State in respect of the 1984-85 financial year, indexed by a figure calculated in accordance with the formula contained in the agreement, plus other amounts as agreed between Ministers. The State will be required to contribute and have local governments and community organisations contribute to the program an amount equal to that spent in attracting matching Commonwealth funds under the four existing Acts in respect of 1984-85, indexed under the same formula contained in the agreement, plus other amounts as agreed between Ministers.

Commonwealth above the base funding in 1985-86 in participating States will comprise the State's share, on a resident population basis, of the unmatched Commonwealth $10m made available in 1984-85 and carried over to 1985-86; and an additional $25m provided by the Commonwealth. These funds must be matched by the State on the basis of $1 State for every $3 Commonwealth. Total Commonwealth outlays in 1985-86 under the program, including funding under the four existing Acts, are estimated to be $117m.

In 1986-87 Commonwealth above the base funding in participating States will comprise $30m, again distributed on a resident population basis, matched by a State contribution of $1 State for every $2 Commonwealth. This injection of significant new funds in this year and next will encourage the expansion of existing services, and the introduction of new service types not previously able to be funded under the more restrictive provisions of the present legislation. In turn this will have a flow-on effect in subsequent years. Total Commonwealth expenditure on home and community care services in 1984-85, 1985-86 and 1986-87 is estimated to be $317.6m. Total State expenditure for that period is estimated to be $247.2m, giving an estimated total Commonwealth-State expenditure of $564.8m over three years.

Commonwealth financial assistance in 1987-88 to a participating State will be up to a 20 per cent increase in money terms over the 1986-87 level. The exact percentage increase is to be agreed between Ministers subject to a State agreeing to increase its outlays by the same percentage. In future years, for the life of the agreement, Commonwealth financial assistance will represent a 20 per cent increase in money terms over expenditure in the preceding year unless otherwise jointly agreed, and subject to the State agreeing to increase its outlays by the same percentage.

The home and community care agreement is to be a continuing one but subject to a joint review at least every three years. If, following a review, the Commonwealth and State Ministers cannot agree on the continued operation of the agreement, then for the two years following the failure to agree the Commonwealth and State will provide sufficient funds to maintain the activity level of services previously funded under the program. The actual funding amounts would be determined in accordance with the formula in the agreement.

The agreement provides that the Commonwealth and State will jointly approve new services, the allocation of funds between all services and significant variations to such allocations, having regard to the views of local governments, service providers and service users on the needs and priorities under the program. All participating States will establish administrative mechanisms to enable service providers and users to participate in the identification of gaps in existing service delivery, the development of priorities and the evaluation of the effectiveness of services funded under the program. Any agreed Commonwealth-State planning machinery will also, of course, need to take account of developments in related health and welfare services, particularly in the areas of long term residential care.

In developing and strengthening the range of services, the priority under the HACC program will be to provide access to ongoing care to that large number of frail aged and younger disabled people who need help but who have had little or no support in the past in receiving the services they, and their carers, require to stay at home. For this reason the prime HACC target group embraces those people whose essential requirement is for longer term basic maintenance and support services to enable them to remain in the community rather than be placed in possibly inappropriate and unnecessary institutional care. Services such as accommodation services or aids and appliances are excluded from the program. Services of these kinds are provided under other Commonwealth-State programs.

A number of services which have been provided under the existing four Acts have initially been designated as no growth areas under the HACC program. The services so designated as compared with those for the prime HACC target group tend to meet short term and often intensive needs. Moreover, they tend to reflect a rather limited view of using support services as a means of assisting the hospital system to reduce average length of stay. The services included in the no growth category are post acute care, palliative care, services primarily for families in crisis and services designed specifically for a particular disability group. Services for these groups will be maintained at the existing level of activity subject to review over the next three years to determine the most appropriate source of funding. This does not mean, however, that people who suffer from a particular disability, such as multiple sclerosis, or a psychiatric disorder will be excluded from receiving services under the program. On the contrary, such people requiring basic support as will be provided through the HACC program will, of course, be eligible, but the new program is not a vehicle for the provision of specialist services or for other services which have traditionally been the function of other Commonwealth or State services.

Many people within the HACC target population will require more than one service. In the past, services have been delivered in a fragmented way with no co-ordination at a local level. It is our intention over the next three years to develop, through the HACC program, mechanisms for achieving better co-ordination of services and for establishing the level of service needed and being provided to any one individual. The co-ordination mechanisms established may vary from State to State and from area to area but must be able to determine the hours of service for each client. Such information is basic to establishing a picture of how resources are being used: Whether the package of services being provided to the individual is appropriate or whether other options including other services, medical treatment or residential care may need to be considered.

The Commonwealth has also foreshadowed with the States its desire to assist in the development of a national data base to enable effective monitoring of the program. Currently there is no nationally comparable data available on service provision, nor on any standards for services, and very little information on the efficiency and effectiveness of alternative methods of service delivery. During preliminary discussions the States have indicated a willingness to work with the Commonwealth to develop standard definitions and to establish a national data collection. As a significant proportion of services is in fact provided by local governments or the voluntary sector, the Commonwealth will seek to involve service providers in this developmental process.

The development of standards for services is an extremely complex issue which will again require input from service providers and users. National program guidelines will be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and their operation in each State and the Northern Territory will be agreed by Ministers. These guidelines will cover the administration of the program, financial arrangements, eligible services and organisations, and provide for input from service providers and users on program needs and priorities. The national program guidelines will be supported by more detailed sub-program guidelines for each of the 11 sub-programs to which I have earlier referred, with the latter guidelines being agreed jointly between Ministers.

Under the HACC program the Government is providing for a considerable increase over the level of funds provided in the past. The financial arrangements in the third and subsequent years will provide for a sensible and planned scheduling of new initiatives in a way which will ensure better financial planning by the Commonwealth and States, and which will enable new projects to be approved throughout the life of the agreement. Thus the Commonwealth and States will be able co-operatively to plan and develop services in the knowledge that there is a continuing commitment from both parties to provide financial support.

Three States-South Australia, Tasmania and Western Australia-as well as the Northern Territory have to date indicated that they will sign or have in fact signed the home and community care program agreement. Negotiations are continuing with the remaining States to facilitate their involvement in the program. The issue in these continuing discussions is not the principle of the home and community care program, which has been endorsed by all State governments. It revolves around associated matters such as long term financing, the scope and boundaries of the program and the extent of Commonwealth involvement in joint programming arrangements.

It is generally accepted that many matters relating to the program will need to be addressed and resolved over time. A first priority must be to gain a picture of the nature, scope and coverage of present programs. An understanding of these important aspects of the programs is sadly lacking. However, we will be developing a national home and community care database as an initial strategy to achieve improvement. The first three years are seen as developmental ones for the program. The present design and any jointly agreed administrative arrangements with States will reflect the Commonwealth's commitment to see that program objectives are achieved in the most cost effective way. Future developments will be determined when the Commonwealth, the States and the community are in a position to assess whether this new approach to the planning and delivery of needed services is successful.

Service-providing organisations and members of the community will naturally be concerned to know how the introduction of the program will affect them. For that reason and in co-operation with the States, letters will go to all community organisations in receipt of Commonwealth and/or State funds to advise them of the impact. The home and community care program signals a new approach to the planning of community services in Australia, an approach which will hold out the possibility of achieving a more caring and equitable society. Services which are appropriately planned, distributed and financed provide an essential complement to other social policies in achieving social equity and needed support to ensure that our society functions properly.

The introduction of broad enabling legislation and agreements with State governments provides the basis for the Commonwealth and States jointly to demonstrate their commitment, through cost shared programs, to improving the quality of life for the aged and disabled who are being cared for at home. Let me emphasise again the features which mark the proposed change in approach.

Firstly, the inflexibility built into the present four legislative programs will be removed. The introduction of flexible agreements allows the scope and nature of the program to alter as community requirements change and government priorities alter. Secondly, a joint approval process means that both Commonwealth and State governments are involved in a partnership. Such an approach provides a mechanism to promote national priorities, to ensure that jointly agreed objectives can be achieved, and to see that State and regional differences can be recognised. Thirdly, there is a recognition that community services are not the monopoly of governments. Over the first three years machinery is to be established to ensure that service providers and users are offered an on-going opportunity for involvement in priority setting. This will allow service users a vital opportunity to become involved in the planning and delivery of services which affect them. The Office for the Aged and the Office of Disability will play an important role in assessing whether this objective is achieved. I thank State and Territory Ministers for their co-operation to date and look forward to increased opportunities to develop the total program over the coming years. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOME AND COMMUNITY CARE (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I foreshadowed this Bill in my second reading speech on the Home and Community Care Bill 1985. As I explained in that speech, the Home and Community Care (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985 amends four existing Commonwealth Acts. The four Acts are: The Delivered Meals Subsidy Act 1970, the Home Nursing Subsidy Act 1956, the States Grants (Home Care) Act 1969 and the States Grants (Para- medical Services) Act 1969.

The Bill aims to ensure that the transition from funding under those Acts to the home and community care program is as smooth as possible. For an explanation of the program, I refer honourable members to my second reading speech on the Home and Community Care Bill 1985. The Bill provides that the four Acts cease to apply in the States which sign the home and community care agreement. Services previously funded under the four Acts will then be funded under the home and community care program.

The Bill also provides that in States which have not yet agreed to participate in the program, financial assistance under the four existing Acts will continue to be provided in respect of existing services at a level sufficient to enable those services to be maintained at their 1984-85 activity level. No new services or expansions to existing services will be approved. Funds for this purpose are available only under the home and community care program. The amendments contained in the Bill are designed both to ensure a smooth transition to the new arrangements, and as an indication of the Commonwealth's commitment to the home and community care program and to working co-operatively with participating States. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND REPATRIATION (BUDGET MEASURES) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
This Bill is an omnibus Bill implementing many of the major social security and repatriation initiatives of the 1985-86 Budget.

In the Budget the Government provided for an increase in expenditure on social security and welfare of $100m in 1985-86 and $245m in a full year. This is in addition to increases in expenditure that automatically result in 1985-86 from factors such as the indexation of pensions and benefits and increased numbers of pensioners and beneficiaries. In combination, these increases in social security and welfare outlays are considerable and demonstrate the Government's commitment to improving the adequacy of assistance for those most in need. They have been achieved within an overall economic strategy that also will be of substantial benefit to low income groups by reducing unemployment and inflation.

The Bill provides substantial increases in assistance to those most in need. For example, as a result of these initiatives and the November indexation increases a sole parent pensioner who has two children will receive almost $8 a week extra from November 1985 and almost $10 a week extra from next May; a single unemployed adult aged 21 or over who rents privately could receive more than $16 a week extra from May 1986; and an unemployed couple aged 18 or over who have two children and are renting privately could receive up to $10 a week extra from November 1985 and up to $20 a week extra from May 1986.

The Bill also implements several initiatives concerning programs administered by the Minister for Community Services. I will give details of the financial impact of the measures in this Bill as I deal with each major initiative.
SOCIAL SECURITY ACT 1947

The major Budget initiatives dealt within Part VI of this Bill consolidate and extend the steps taken by the Government in the previous two Budgets to provide additional assistance to those in greatest need in our community. In particular, the Bill seeks to address the needs of low income families, single parents, and people who are unemployed. Additional assistance will also be provided to people receiving sickness and special benefits. Other special needs have also been addressed.
Increase in Assistance to Families

This Government is strongly committed to improving the level of assistance provided to low income families with dependent children. Accordingly, we have built on the priority we gave these families in the previous two Budgets by again increasing payments to them. From 1 November 1985, the additional pension or benefit payable for each child in the care of a pensioner or beneficiary will be increased by $2 to $16 a week per child. This increase will not apply after 1 January 1986 in relation to young people who receive assistance through the secondary assistance scheme or the tertiary education assistance scheme.

In conjunction with this increase, the maximum rate of family income supplement, a payment made to low income families not receiving a pension or benefit, will also increase by $2 to $16 a week per child. Together with the $2 increases provided in each of the last two years, these payments will have been increased by 60 per cent since this Government came to office in 1983. In 1985-86 these measures will benefit an estimated 309,000 social security and repatriation service pensioner families and 114,000 beneficiary families, as well as 26,000 families in receipt of family income supplement. The net cost will be an estimated $56.3m in the current financial year and $86.2m in a full year.

The Bill also provides for a 20 per cent increase in the rate of mother's-guardian's allowance from 1 May 1986, bringing the maximum rate to $12 a week. This allowance is provided in recognition of the particular needs of sole parents and is paid in addition to additional pension or benefit paid for each child. In 1985-86 an estimated 267,000 pensioners and beneficiaries will benefit from this measure at an estimated cost of $5.4m in the current financial year and $28.9m in a full year.

The Bill introduces a new category of pension from 1 November 1985 for people providing constant care and attention on a long term basis for a severely handicapped age or invalid pensioner spouse or close relative at home. The new carer's pension will replace the existing spouse carer's pension, which is paid only to men caring for their wives. The provision of a pension to those caring for invalid near relatives, for example, aged parents, is an important Government initiative. The carer's pension is estimated to cost some $1m in the current financial year and $1.6m in a full year. These figures take into account savings from those persons currently receiving spouse carer's pension or special benefit who are expected to take up the new pension.

From 15 November 1985, the Government will introduce special additional assistance for families with multiple births. An increase of family allowance payments of $150 a month for triplets and $200 a month for quadruplets and higher multiple births will be made until the children reach the age of six. Being an increase in family allowance, these amounts will not be taxable or means tested and will be made in addition to other income support payments. The previous system of discretionary act of grace payments for quadruplets and higher multiple births will be discontinued.

In 1985-86, 180 families with triplets and six families with quadruplets are estimated to benefit from the increased payments at an estimated cost of $200,000 in the current financial year and $300,000 in a full year.
Initiatives for People Who Are Unemployed

One of the Government's major 1983 election commitments was to restore progressively the rate of unemployment benefit for single adults to parity with the standard rate of pension. Before November 1978, the single adult rate of unemployment benefit was the same as the single rate of pension and sickness benefit. The previous Government excluded it from automatic pension and benefit indexation arrangements, causing its real value to decline substantially. As a result, single adult unemployment beneficiaries were subject to discrimination and required to bear the greatest burden during the economic recession. Since coming to office, we have moved to end this discrimination by progressively closing the gap between this group and single pensioners and sickness beneficiaries. In 1983, we increased the rate of single adult unemployment benefit by $9.20 a week in two stages. We also provided for automatic indexation of the rate from May 1984 and made special ad hoc increases above the requirements of indexation in May and November of 1984, and in May 1985.

In keeping with our election commitment, this Bill provides further assistance. From November 1985, the rate of unemployment benefit for single people aged 21 years and over will be raised by $3 a week in a special ad hoc increase. Along with an indexation increase of $3.25 a week, the rate will rise to a total of $91.45 a week. In 1985-86 this initiative will affect on average some 247,000 unemployment beneficiaries at an estimated cost of $25.7m in the current financial year and $41.8m in a full year. In addition, we will create a new category of unemployment benefit for single people aged between 18 and 20 from 1 November 1985. To establish an intermediate rate, unemployment benefit payments for 18-20-year-olds will not be subject to automatic indexation increases. This will result in savings of $14.9m in 1985-86. The new intermediate rate of $88.20 a week will be created by an ad hoc increase of $3 a week to the current single adult rate.

Further ad hoc increases will be made from the beginning of 1987 and 1988. At that point, the Government intends that the intermediate rate of unemployment benefit will be equal to the level of tertiary education allowance paid to students who live away from home. Both rates will then be automatically indexed at the beginning of each subsequent year. An estimated average of 101,000 unemployment beneficiaries will benefit in 1985-86 from the ad hoc increase which creates the intermediate rate. The estimated cost will be $10.4m in the current financial year and $16.1m in a full year. The single junior rate of unemployment benefit will increase from 1 November 1985 by $5 to $50 a week. Currently, only people aged 16-17 years who have been receiving unemployment benefit for 6 months or more receive this higher rate. This increase means that since March 1983, the rate of unemployment benefit for 16-17 year olds will have risen by 25 per cent. An estimated 34,000 unemployment beneficiaries will benefit in 1985-86 from this initiative at an estimated cost of $5.8m in the current financial year and $8.9m in a full year.

There is another measure in the Bill which is of major significance for people who are unemployed. From 1 May 1986, rent assistance of up to $10 a week will be available, for the first time, to people over 18 years who have been receiving unemployment benefit for 6 months or more and who rent privately. This measure will not apply in the case of a single beneficiary who has no dependants, is under 25 years and is living at home. This initiative recognises the increasing reliance on unemployment benefit as a means of long term income support. In 1985-86 the measure will assist some 109,000 unemployment beneficiaries at an estimated cost of $9.1m in the current financial year and $56.4m in a full year.

A further measure to assist unemployed people, intended to be introduced in a Bill later in the current sittings, is the easing of the income test. From May 1986, unemployment beneficiaries will be able to earn an extra $10 a week and still qualify for full payment. The `allowable income' limit will increase from $20 to $30 a week, making the income test free amount for beneficiaries the same as that for single pensioners. This will help overcome the poverty trap that discourages beneficiaries from seeking part-time work. This measure will benefit approximately 40,000 unemployment beneficiaries in 1985-86 at an estimated cost of $1.6m in the current financial year and $9.7m in a full year.
Sickness and Special Benefits

Single sickness and special beneficiaries aged 16 to 17 who have received benefits for less than six months will receive the rate of $50 a week from November 1984, an increase of $5. Rent assistance of up to $10 a week will be paid from May 1986 to special beneficiaries aged 18 and above. It will be paid on the same basis as for unemployment beneficiaries. Sickness and special beneficiaries will also benefit from the liberalisation of the income test that will be introduced in legislation at a later stage in these sittings. Some 6,400 sickness beneficiaries and 7,000 special beneficiaries in 1985-86 will benefit from these initiatives, at an estimated cost of $1m in the current financial year and $4.4m in a full year. In addition, certain sickness and special beneficiaries who are paid at the unemployment benefit rate will receive similar increases to those received by unemployment beneficiaries. This will benefit an average of 27,000 sickness and special beneficiaries at an estimated cost of $2.9m in the current financial year and $4.7m in a full year.
Other Measures

A major initiative in the Bill will facilitate respite care arrangements for parents of handicapped children. From 1 November 1985, the handicapped child's allowance will remain payable for up to 28 days a year while the child is temporarily absent from the family home and in respite care in an institution. This will enable the parents of severely handicapped children to take a break or holiday at least once a year. The estimated cost of this measure is $65,000 in the current financial year and $100,000 in a full year. From 1 November 1985, the waiting period which must be undergone by some persons qualified to receive an unemployment or a sickness benefit will not apply where a beneficiary is transferring from another social security income support payment. In addition, there will be no waiting period for the spouse of a person who receives an additional amount of such a payment, where the spouse qualifies to receive such a payment.

The Bill also clarifies and rationalises the rules concerning overpayments of social security pensions. Specific rules will provide for the creation of a legally recoverable debt if payment continues after the pensioner ceases to qualify for the pension. In addition, specific rules will provide for the creation of a legally recoverable debt where the amount of pension to which a pensioner is entitled is reduced, but the pensioner does not duly notify the change in his or her circumstances. The relationship between social security pensions and benefits and repatriation service pensions will also be rationalised to prevent overlap of entitlements and ensure that overlapping payments will be legally recoverable. The Bill also includes provisions which will permit the waiver and write-off of debts arising under the Act to improve administrative efficiency.
REPATRIATION ACT 1920

Repatriation service pensions are similar to age and invalid pensions except that, where granted on the ground of age, they are available at the age of 60 for men and 55 for women. Service pension rates are calculated by reference to the rates of pension payable under the Social Security Act 1947. Increases in the additional pension for children and mother's/guardian's allowance payable to social security pensioners will also apply to service pensioners who are in similar circumstances. Some 6,500 service pensioners will benefit from increases in additional pension for children and a further 280 families will benefit from increases in guardian's allowances. These measures will cost an estimated $600,000 in the current financial year and $950,000 in a full year.

The Bill provides for increases in allowances paid to veterans suffering certain amputations or loss of vision, in attendant allowance and in pensions paid to orphans. The increases will have effect from 7 November 1985 and represent movements in the consumer price index in the 12 months since increases in last year's Budget. Higher amounts for certain other amputations are adjusted automatically in May and November in line with any movements in the consumer price index in the six-months period ending in December and June, respectively, of the relevant year.

The rate of attendant allowance is to be increased from $53.80 to $57.40 a fortnight in the case of the veteran who is blind or is suffering from a cerebro-spinal injury. In the case of a veteran who has had both arms amputated or who is blind and has lost hearing or speech, the allowance is to be increased from $107.60 to $114.80 a fortnight. This allowance is also paid in addition to disability pension.

A double orphan's pension will be increased from $76.80 to $82 a fortnight while the increase for a single orphan will be from $38.40 to $41 a fortnight. These measures will cost an estimated $120,000 in the current financial year and $190,000 in a full year. Other initiatives for increases in recreation transport allowance and clothing allowance will be achieved by amendment of the Repatriation regulations and associated regulations.

The Repatriation Act provides for the payment of a spouse carer's pension to a man caring for his severely handicapped veteran wife. This pension will be extended, in line with the creation of the social security carer's pension, to cover near relatives caring for severely handicapped veterans. The extension is not expected to affect a large number of people and the costs are expected to be negligible. The Bill will rationalise rules concerning overpayments of pensions along the same lines as the changes to the Social Security Act. Similar provisions for the waiver and write off of debts are also included.
SEAMEN'S WAR PENSIONS AND ALLOWANCES ACT 1940

The Bill also makes consequential amendments to the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940. That Act provides benefits similar to those provided under the Repatriation Act to Australian mariners who suffered a war injury during World War II. The Bill implements two major measures in relation to legislation administered by the Minister for Community Services.
AGED OR DISABLED PERSONS HOMES ACT 1954

Under this Act, the Commonwealth pays a personal care subsidy and a hostel care subsidy to eligible organisations which provide hostel type accommodation for aged or disabled people. These subsidies are payable at weekly rates. The Commonwealth also provides a respite care bed subsidy to encourage the provision of respite care beds in hostels. A respite care bed subsidy of $11 a week is payable in respect of an approved respite care bed which is occupied for 14 days or less during a 28-day period. Fifty-five dollars a week is payable where the bed is occupied for at least 15 days during the 28-day period. Unfortunately, this arrangement has tended to cause distortions in availability of respite care beds as advantage is taken of the differential subsidy levels.

The report of the Joint Review of Hostel Care Subsidies Arrangements recommended that payment of hostel care subsidy, personal care subsidy and respite care bed subsidy should be converted to a daily basis without reducing the total amount of Commonwealth recurrent subsidies for hostel care (policy recommendation 9 (b)). Accordingly, the Government has decided that hostel care, personal care and respite care bed subsidies will be paid on a daily basis calculated with effect from 18 December 1985 and to be paid in January 1986. The daily rates to apply are $1.80 per day for hostel care, $7.80 per day for personal care and $7 per day for respite care. The revised arrrangements are estimated to add $1.3m to outlays in 1985-86 and $2.3m in 1986-87.
NATIONAL HEALTH ACT 1953

Under this Act, benefits are paid by the Commonwealth to approved nursing homes for all qualified patients in such homes. The benefit rates are prescribed in the National Health Regulations and are reviewed annually.

In the `May statement', measures were announced which are directed to slowing the rapid growth of nursing home outlays that has occurred over the past decade. One of those measures included freezing the level of Commonwealth nursing home benefits in government nursing homes in all States and Territories, except in some government nursing homes run by non-profit charitable or benevolent organisations. The Bill amends the National Health Act so as to enable different rates of benefit to be prescribed for different classes of approved nursing homes.
The measures contained in this Bill demonstrate the Government's commitment to assisting those most in need in our community. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to implement Government decisions regarding the power of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to make program standards and the inquiry procedures of the Tribunal. The proposed amendments can be summarised as follows.

In relation to the power of the Tribunal to make standards, the Bill provides for the preclassification of children's program by the Tribunal and the inclusion of quantitative elements in standards. The provisions relating to the enforcement of standards are based on recommendations of the Administrative Review Council-the ARC-in its 1981 report on the inquiry procedures of the Tribunal. The Council recommended that the Act be amended to confer upon the Tribunal a wider range of powers to respond to breaches of broadcasting standards.

Honourable members will recall that amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act were passed last year to streamline the Tribunal's inquiry procedures by the automatic extension of licence periods pending completion of a licence renewal inquiry, and the formation of divisions of the Tribunal. In the autumn sittings of Parliament this year further amendments were passed which provide the framework of uniform procedures for Tribunal inquiries. They empower the Tribunal to dispense with a public hearing where no substantive issues of public concern are raised. The Bill will enable regulations to be made to allow the Tribunal to apply the new uniform inquiry procedures to inquiries which would otherwise be required to be dealt with under old, less efficient procedures.

Amendments relating to the enforcement of program standards were also originally scheduled for inclusion in the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1985 passed by the Parliament in the autumn sittings. Following the decision of the High Court of Australia in Herald-Sun TV Pty Ltd v. Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, the amendments were withdrawn to allow for further consideration and consultation with representatives of industry and public interest groups.

The amendments contained in the Bill will not alter the costs or revenues of the Commonwealth. The purpose of the legislation is to give the Tribunal the power to make and enforce certain standards. I should point out that, until recently challenged, the Tribunal had already exercised this power in the belief that it was within its authority under the Broadcasting and Television Act. The machinery-that is, the personnel and facilities-are therefore in place and the amendments will not necessitate an increase in the resources of the Tribunal.

The Bill provides for the amendment of two Acts, the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 and the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1985. In general terms, the amendments will commence on 1 January 1986. The form of the Bill is complicated. However, as a result of the commencment of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1985 on that date, that Act preserves the application of the previous Act in some circumstances. The result is that some amendments made in the Bill are in duplicate form. I now turn to the detail of the proposed amendments.
Standards-making powers

There is a history of doubt about the standards-making powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and its predecessor, the Australian Broadcasting Control Board. As long ago as 1963 the Senate Select Committee on the Encouragement of Australian Production for Television expressed the opinion that the program standards-making power of the Broadcasting Control Board was confined by legislation to a qualitative determination and did not extend to determinations as to content, type, variety or country or origin of programs.

Its concern was that unless the regulating authority had the power to set legally enforceable standards it would not be able to ensure that adequate and comprehensive programs were provided by commercial broadcasters. The Committee recommended amendment of the Act but no such legislation eventuated.

In 1978, when the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts inquired into children's television, it commented on the fact that the questions raised by the Senate Select Committee in 1963 had never been resolved. It said:
Over the whole matter of industry regulation, there still hangs the question of the Tribunal's powers to regulate effectively.

It recommended that if it were considered by the Attorney-General's Department that the Act was in any way inadequate for effective regulation, it should be amended to remove any inadequacies, ambiguities or inconsistencies. Still the Act was not amended. A number of recent court decisions against the Tribunal have now, once more, highlighted the need to amend the Act to affirm the standards-making powers of the Tribunal. The decisions have actually invalidated a number of the Tribunal's standards.
Definition of Program Standards

The first of these decisions was of the Federal Court in Saatchi and Saatchi Compton (Victoria) Pty Limited v. Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The Court ruled that a `Standard' must relate directly to the quality or nature of the material broadcast: That is, the Tribunal's power does not extend to the regulation of circumstances connected with the production of a program were these circumstances are not intrinsically related to the nature of the end product. The Court found that the requirements of the Tribunal's standards relating to the Australian content of advertisements was in no way related to the quality or nature of the advertisement produced. Therefore, these provisions did not qualify as a standard in respect of the televising of advertisements for the purposes of the Act. Subsequently, the Full Federal Court upheld the decision after an appeal by the Tribunal.

The effect of these decisions is that many of the Tribunal's current program and advertising standards which purport to impose quantitative rules, and this would possibly include time based rules, could well be void. In this category would fall major aspects of advertising time standards, Australian content program standards, children's program and advertising standards. The Bill redefines `program standard' to include the concept of `condition'. This is to avoid the interpretation given by the Federal Court in the Saatchi case that `Standard' must relate directly to the quality or nature of the material broadcast. The inclusion of `condition' will enable the Tribunal to apply standards which regulate the circumstances connected with the production of a program. In particular, this will enable the Tribunal to apply standards which relate to Australian content in productions.
Preclassification of Children's Programs

In May of this year 14 commercial television licensees successfully challenged the Tribunal's power to require children's programs to be pre-classified prior to telecast. The High Court of Australia, in the Herald-Sun TV case, decided that the pre-classification requirements in the Tribunal's children's television standards were beyond the Tribunal's power under the Act.

Since 1979 the Tribunal has required `children's' or `C' programs to be preclassified prior to their telecast by commercial television licensees. The assessment of programs is carried out by the Tribunal which has the benefit of the recommendations of the Children's Program Committee. The Tribunal has employed the preclassification approach to `Children's' programming as a quality control mechanism and to ensure that these programs, which are produced specifically for the needs and interests of children aged six to 13 years, meet the Tribunal's standards. `Children's' programs are those which:
(a) are designed specifically for children older than five years and younger than 14 years;
(b) are designed to entertain children;
(c) are well produced technically and artistically;
(d) can be easily understood and appreciated by children;
(e) fulfil some special need of children;
(f) contribute to the social, emotional or intellectual development of children;
(g) are appropriate for Australian children, not assuming too much of the culture, dialect or environment of some other country; and
(h) are not outdated in content or in technical or artistic production.

The regulatory action of the Tribunal followed numerous inquiries into children's television. As early as 1953 the Royal Commission on Television examined children's television. It received numerous submissions from parents and teachers concerned about the predicted preponderance of American programs on Australian television, the effects on children of television violence and overt commercialism. The Commission recommended the introduction of special standards regulating the production of television programs; the addition of two members to the Australian Broadcasting Control Board to present the interests of the public; and the establishment of a children's advisory committee to advise the Broadcasting Control Board.

Other inquiries into television which have demonstrated community concern about children's television include: a Senate select committee inquiry into the encouragement of Australian productions for television, 1963; a Senate standing committee inquiry into `all aspects of television and broadcasting, including the Australian content of television programmes', 1971-1975; and the Australian Broadcasting Control Board's standards inquiry, 1975. In 1977 the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts began its inquiry into the impact of television on the development and learning behaviour of children. It concluded that there was genuine widespread public concern about children's television and that given the economics of commercial television, the prospects for improvement were not bright.

This inquiry was conducted concurrently with the Tribunal's self-regulation inquiry of 1977. That inquiry was also highly critical of children's programming. It recommended the establishment of a new classification for children's programs, the establishment of the Children's Program Committee and the introduction of a pre-classification system for children's programs. The pre-classification system was introduced in 1979.

In 1981 the Senate Standing Committee presented its report entitled: `Children's television revisited'. This reviewed progress in children's television since its earlier report of 1978. At the time of that review the powers of the Tribunal were under consideration by the Government. The Committee, therefore, did not pursue the matter in detail. Nevertheless, it placed on record its opposition to any amending legislation that would in any way diminish the Tribunal's powers and obligations to regulate in the area of children's television. Earlier this year the Committee examined children's television standards in its examination of annual reports. Its report recommended that the Broadcasting and Television Act be amended so that the Tribunal has the clear power to regulate in the field of children's television including the power to pre-assess `C' programs.

In 1984, the Tribunal thoroughly reviewed its approach to children's program regulation and decided that the requirement for preclassification should continue on the basis that it had produced a marked improvement in the quality and variety of children's programs since 1979. At that time it also introduced a new requirement for Australian children's drama programs which was that licensees televise a minimum of 8 hours of first release Australian children's drama each financial year and that this also be submitted to the Tribunal for prior approval.

The justification for preclassification of children's `C' programs is overwhelming. Independent inquiries have consistently concluded that children's programs need special treatment. There can be no doubt that preclassification of this very small proportion of programs is not only appropriate but also necessary at this time. The Bill will affirm the Tribunal's power to make program standards for `children's television programs'. The standard may require prior approval for children's programs which are shown during specified hours-referred to as `C' time. These are usually 4 to 5 p.m. on weekdays. They may also provide for the preclassification of children's drama programs.

In addition to the affirmation of these powers the Bill will permit sub-classifications of standards for programs designed for children under the age of 14 years. At present the Tribunal standards for children's programs are for those designed for the six to 13 years age group as a whole. It will also enable the Tribunal to extend its preclassification standards to programs designed for younger children-that is, children up to five years of age. The Bill will provide the Tribunal with the power to require preclassification of programs which are to be televised at times other than `C' time but which a licensee wishes to present as meeting the tribunal's conditions for `C' time programs. I would like to point out that under the principal Act any revision of standards by the Tribunal can be undertaken only after consultation with broadcasters.

Some concern has been expressed about the application of the preclassification requirements to the production of programs classified as `children's drama'. Commercial television licensees and the television production industry have expressed the wish that children's drama programs be awarded a full `C' classification at script stage prior to actual production of the program. In the past, the Tribunal has awarded a `provisional C' classification at script stage, with the subsequent award of a full `C' classification of the completed program. With these concerns in mind the Tribunal is considering the most appropriate form of preclassification arrangement. It will be consulting with representatives of the television and production industries and other interested organisations about the options available.

The Government is not in favour of a general power of preclassification. The Bill, therefore, expressly limits the Tribunal's power to require preclassification to that of children's programs. I would also like to emphasise that `preclassification' is not a form of censorship. Programs which are rejected as unsuitable for a `C' classification can be broadcast at other times. It is also important to remember that `C' time is normally 4 to 5 p.m. Monday to Friday-that is one hour only, 5 days per week.
Enforcement Provisions

The Bill provides for a significant change in the enforcement of program standards. A breach of a program standard will no longer attract a criminal penalty. The Bill will, of course, require that licensees supervise the broadcasting of their programs to ensure that the program standards are observed but the enforcement of this provision will be decriminalised.

The Bill will retain, in a slightly modified form, the power to give directions to a licensee for the purpose of ensuring that the program standards are complied with. A failure to comply with such a direction will remain a criminal offence. The giving of such a direction will, however, be the exercise of a substantive power by the Tribunal and thus must result from an inquiry under the Act which will be subject to the uniform inquiry procedures provided for in the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1985 which was passed during the 1985 autumn sittings. The Amendment Act also provides that in matters of urgency the Tribunal may vary the inquiry procedures or adopt different procedures, as appropriate.

In its 1981 report the Administrative Review Council proposed that the Tribunal be given the power to impose temporary restrictions on advertising by licensees as a penalty for breaches of the Act or program standards. This would, however, have raised a number of problems with respect to the separation of executive and judicial powers. The Government decided that the current Tribunal's powers to give directions be modified to complement the new scheme of enforcement of program standards as outlined above. A history of breaches of program standards may also be relevant at licence renewal inquiries as such a pattern of behaviour could amount to a breach of licence conditions and of the undertakings given by a licensee on the grant or renewal of a licence.

The Bill also includes a new defence provision which applies where the failure of the licensee to adequately supervise broadcasts was due to a reasonable mistake; reasonable reliance on information supplied by another person; or the act or default of another person or any accident or other cause beyond the licensee's control and the licensee took reasonable precautions and exercised due diligence to avoid the breach. This defence is based upon a similar provision in the Trade Practices Act 1974.

The Bill also adopts a specific recommendation of the ARC to empower the Tribunal to reprimand or admonish a licensee for a breach of program standards and, most importantly, to direct the licensee to broadcast the reprimand or admonishment in such form and manner as is specified by the Tribunal in its direction. This will be a substantive power of the Tribunal and thus subject to the uniform inquiry procedures provided for under the Act.

In addition, the Bill extends the circumstances in which the Tribunal may issue directions and give orders under section 119 of the Act. This section currently permits the Tribunal to place restrictions on individuals broadcasting material or rendering or selecting material for broadcast where they have been either convicted of broadcasting or selecting blasphemous, indecent or obscene matter or where the Tribunal has reason to believe a person has rendered, or selected for broadcast, an item which has, or may, cause offence to a section of the public.

The Bill will amend these provisions to enable the Tribunal to call upon an individual who has presented in live broadcast, or who has selected material which has been broadcast in breach of the program standards, to show cause why a direction should not be issued. Such a direction may prohibit or impose restrictions on a person from presenting live broadcasts or from passing or selecting programs for a broadcast. A direction may be given only where the person fails to show cause in accordance with the Act. Further, the issue of such a direction will be the exercise of a `substantive power' of the Tribunal and thus must result from an inquiry under the Tribunal's new uniform inquiry procedures.

The objective of this clause is to give the Tribunal a means of enforcing program standards against individuals who may otherwise be able to infringe the standards in circumstances where licensees have limited, practical, supervisory powers. The classic example is where live broadcasts are involved. In fact the Tribunal will not be empowered under this provision to censor material. A licensee may pre-record any such material and subsequently broadcast it. In these circumstances it would, however, be the licensee who would be clearly responsible. Although not specifically stated in the Bill, directions made by the Tribunal in relation to the abovementioned provisions must be reasonable having regard to the breach involved. An unreasonable direction given by the Tribunal would be subject to review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.
Transitional Amendments

The Bill will amend the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1985 to provide that regulations may be made to extend the application of the new streamlined uniform inquiry procedures. These procedures will come into operation on 1 January 1986. As the Act currently stands the new procedures could not be used for Tribunal inquiries involving old system licences. The Bill amends the transitional provisions of the 1985 Amendment Act to empower the making of regulations to apply the new procedures to old system licences. The effect of this will be to enable all inquiries conducted pursuant to notices issued after 1 January 1986 to be conducted under the same procedures, that is, the new procedures. The Tribunal inquiries and new arrangements will streamline the Tribunal's inquiries and will overcome the administrative difficulty of having two inquiry procedures operating concurrently.
It is proposed to make regulations under this power to apply new procedures to:

Inquiries into the grant of licences under section 82 of the amended Act where the return date for applications for licences to the Tribunal-that is the specified date under section 82 (1) (b) (i)-is later than 1 January 1986. This will, however, result in the grant of an old system licence which will need to be subsequently converted to a new system licence pursuant to section 99 of the 1985 Act.

New inquiries on applications for supplementary licences referred by the Minister to the Tribunal after 1 January 1986, that is, where the date of referral under section 82A (4) (a) of the amended Act is after 1 January 1986. Licences issued following applications made prior to 1 January 1986 but not referred until after 1 January 1986, would result in old system licences granted pursuant to a tribunal inquiry conducted in accordance with the new uniform inquiry procedures. Conversion of old to new system licences would then subsequently occur.

Other applications to the Tribunal made after 1 January 1986 for the exercise of any of its substantive powers-as specified in section 17A (2) of the Amendment Act-in relation to old system licences; and
Inquiries into the exercise of the Tribunal's substantive powers into old system licences which are initiated by the Tribunal of its own volition, after 1 January 1986.
I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr White) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATE HEAD OFFICE BUILDING FOR TELECOM AUSTRALIA, SYDNEY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of State Head Office building for Telecom Australia, Sydney.

The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works has reported that there is a need for the construction of a major high rise building in the Sydney central business district to provide a new State head office for Telecom Australia. The new building is to be constructed immediately adjacent to the existing Telecom House between Pitt Street and Castlereagh Street. It will enable Telecom staff and State head office activities to be consolidated on the one site and allow expensive leased space elsewhere in the city to be relinquished. The proposed building will provide about 29,000 square metres of office floor area in 33 levels above ground. Associated works will include modifications to the existing through-site shopping arcade and the provision of additional retail space for rental.

The estimated cost of the proposed work is $45.5m at January 1985 prices. Subject to the approval of the House, it is proposed to invite tenders as soon as possible. Construction of the building will be completed by late 1987 or early 1988 and it will be occupied during the bicentennial year. I thank the Committee for its prompt consideration of this proposal. If the House agrees to support the motion, planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Public Works Committee. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) for making the paper available to me. The Opposition notes the recommendation of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. The sum of $45m is large. Given the Government's commitment in its trilogy to curtail government expenditure, we have to raise the question with the Minister: Why should this building be in the centre of Sydney? Rents in that area are of the order of $30 a square foot, whereas out in Chatswood or Hurstville, for example, rents are around $17 a square foot. On the 300,000 square feet proposed in the motion for this building there would be a saving of $13 a square foot, which is of the order of $4m a year. If that were transposed into the capital cost, we might be building in a Sydney suburb at a cost of perhaps $35m, not $45m.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not think that occupation during the bicentennial year has too much to recommend it at present, given the gross mismanagement of the Australian Bicentennial Authority by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is worth saying now that if Telecom Australia were in the private sector there would be a saving of nearly $50m against this motion. This is not the place to canvass the transfer of Telecom to the private sector, but it is well known that the Opposition is reviewing this whole question. Privatisation of Telecom will give better efficiency, better organisation and better returns for the consumers. As I said recently with regard to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, the employees of Telecom have nothing to fear from privatisation. The Opposition will not oppose the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FITOUT OF OFFICE SPACE AT CANBERRA NATIONAL CONVENTION CENTRE, CANBERRA CITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Fitout of office space at Canberra National Convention Centre, Canberra City, for Commonwealth use.

This proposed work involves the fitout of 42,000 square metres of general office accommodation in the National Convention Centre complex currently under construction in the Civic area of Canberra. Among the tenants of the completed complex will be the Australian Customs Service. This will be a welcome move for the members of that service who have for many years endured sub-standard accommodation in Barton offices which are commonly referred to as the Barton woolsheds. Indeed, these wooden buildings, which date back prior to World War II and which are an eyesore in an important area of Canberra, will be demolished once the Australian Customs Service is located in its new premises.

Another major tenant will be the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. This Department is currently located in a number of dispersed buildings in Canberra and the rationalisation of its accommodation is long overdue. Some elements of the Department of Territories currently dispersed in a number of locations throughout Canberra will also be relocated in this complex. This should improve public access to that Department's services.

The work involved in the fitout of the five Commonwealth leased buildings in the complex is typical of work normally required to allow occupancy of leased premises by government departments. It involves: Partitions for offices, conference rooms and interview rooms; alterations to mechanical services, light and power, telephones, and other services to suit specific office layouts; joinery to public counters and reception areas; appropriate finishes to executive and staff amenities areas and guard posts, building perimeter security and other security measures. As normal practice, my Department has consulted extensively with bodies affected by this proposal, including officials of the various staff associations representing the future occupants of this complex. The estimated cost of this work is $12.3m at August 1985 prices. I present plans of the proposed work and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I thank the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) for making the paper available. The Opposition notes the motion for the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works to review the fitout of general office accommodation in the National Convention Centre. We hope that the Minister will take the opportunity, when he refers this matter to the Public Works Committee, to ask it to keep in mind certain points. First is the need to organise the design in such a way as to maximise the involvement of the private sector. Second, is the the need to contain costs. Facilities of this type are usually of a one-off nature and costs are mainly irrecoverable. Spending $12m for around 400,000 square feet is a cost of $30 a square foot, which may very well be able to be lowered.

SPEECH.PARA: The rationalisation of office facilities for the Australian Customs Service, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Department of Territories gives the Government an opportunity to review and streamline the operations of those departments. In particular, this involves the reduction of equipment and certain functions, more efficient operations and better service to clients. During the election campaign, the Government gave several undertakings about government spending. The Minister should ask his colleagues to review the operations of their departments so that during this change they will become more efficient. As we all know, interest rates remain high at present because the Government is supporting the Australian dollar. Another fall in the value of the dollar would destroy the prices and incomes accord. As the Minister has noted, he expects interest rates to remain high, at least in the short term. These high interest rates are placing a heavy burden on the home owners of Australia and on the fabric of the family. Interest rates are high because monetary policy is bearing the brunt of the load of the Government's economic policy. Interest rates, and hence the burden on the families, will come down only if the Government excercises determination in other economic policy areas, namely, the progressive deregulation of the labour market to make us more competitive internationally and to bring down our overseas debt and, in regard to fiscal policy, the curtailment of government spending. In this last respect, the Minister can take the lead in this matter by persuading his colleagues to use this proposed rationalisation to improve the efficiency of their departments and to cut their costs.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
