DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EXPENDITURE: INTERIM AND FINAL REPORTS ON THE INQUIRY INTO THE ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Government, I am responding to the interim and final reports of the inquiry into the Aboriginal Development Commission by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. The reports were presented to the House on 5 October 1984 and 22 May 1985 respectively. The Aboriginal Development Commission, which was established by this Parliament when the former Government was in office, commenced operation in 1980. The Commission is an independent statutory body under the control of a board whose members are all Aboriginal. Originally it took over the functions of the Aboriginal Loans Commission and the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission as well as the enterprise function from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Since that time, but before this Government took office, it was given the housing grants-in-aid function previously administered by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: When this Government took office we were committed to maintaining and supporting the Aboriginal Development Commission as well as ensuring that its methods of operation and decision making were in line with the developing political, social and economic circumstances of Aborigines. That commitment will continue not only for the Commission but for all the effective organisations within or associated with the portfolio.

I say this because the House does well to recall that the Expenditure Committee's inquiry was conducted largely in respect of a time when the former Government was in office. It was that Government which denied the ADC the staff and resources it advised Ministers to provide. It was that Government which placed the ADC under a staff ceiling. Yet it was that Government which loaded on to a then new and inexperienced agency the extra, as it turned out, onerous responsibilities for housing grants administration.

Since its inception, when it inherited procedures not entirely suitable to its present mode and extent of operation, the ADC has been attempting to modernise its management systems to a point where it can achieve a standard of efficiency commensurate with its current range of functions. Problems have, of course, been encountered during this developmental stage, some of which have been outlined in the interim report. Criticism of the Commission, particularly during the first three years of its existence, can be linked to the inadequacy of resources allocated to it by the government of the day. Unlike its predecessor, this present Government has acted to overcome this problem by removal of staffing restrictions on a trial basis, providing increased funding and by responding positively to the Committee's recommendations. This reflects the Government's commitment to the attainment of equality for Aboriginals.

Many of the recommendations in the interim report are associated with management and administration procedures within the Aboriginal Development Commission. It is proper for the Commission to ensure that measures are taken to rectify the problems which have been identified. The commissioners have considered the recommendations of the Committee and new procedures have been implemented and others are being considered. This positive response from the Commission is complete justification of the Government's commitment to the principles of Aboriginal self-determination.

I, as Minister, will require regular briefings from the Aboriginal Development Commission on the progress made with any outstanding issues. I stated in the House at the time the interim report was tabled that the Government's response would be provided as soon as possible. Time does not permit me to respond in detail to each of the Committee's recommendations. I therefore seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document which outlines the Government's response to each of the Committee's recommendations.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Role of the ADC
Recommendations

1. The Commission's role should be maintained and strengthened. Its emphasis should be increasingly on programs associated with Aboriginal developments, including housing, enterprises and land acquisition, with welfare programs remaining with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs or elsewhere.

2. Further fragmentation of responsibilities within the portfolio should not occur. Any new organisation experiences teething problems and requires a settling-in period to function efficiently. Continuing changes of responsibilities and creation of new organisations militates against achieving efficient program delivery.
Response
1. The Government supports the recommendation.
2. The Government supports the recommendation to the extent that it does not impede the introduction of changes that may be necessary in the interests of program efficiency and effectiveness.
Aims and Objectives of the ADC
Recommendations

3. The Commission should, as a matter of high priority, establish a corporate plan for its objectives which should be updated on a regular basis. Whilst the Commission cannot be insensitive to the wishes of the Aboriginal population at large it does have a leadership role to exercise particularly in the area of Aboriginal enterprises, which is not being fully exercised at present.

4. The Commission should be encouraged to develop the freedom inherent in its Act to establish its own objectives and to acquire the resources, including staff, which are necessary to achieve those objectives.
Response
3. The Government supports the recommendation.
4. The Government supports the recommendation for the ADC to set its own objectives consistent with the statute under which it is established.
Capital Fund
Recommendations
5. Greater emphasis should be applied within the Capital Fund to acquisition of assets more directly concerned with Aboriginal purposes.
Response

5. The Government notes there is provision in the ADC Act for the ADC to approach the Treasurer for approval to invest moneys from the Capital Fund in a manner other than those specified in the Act. Any approach would be considered on its merits with due regard being had to the Standing Committee's recommendation.
Administrative Systems
Recommendations

6. High priority should be given to completion of the development of systems for monitoring the programs of expenditure. Examples are the Rural Accounting and Management System and the Housing and Enterprise Loans Systems. Such systems should ensure regional and sub-regional accountability and be instituted to strengthen the decentralisation of ADC personnel at these levels.
7. A much more rigorous filing system of submissions for projects requiring Commission approval should be instituted.
Response

6. The Government has been informed by the ADC that the Housing and Enterprise Loans System is now fully operational and that the Rural Accounting and Management System is operational with provision of input data now being made regularly.
7. The ADC has informed the Government that new filing systems are being introduced this financial year.
Role of Commissioners
Recommendations
8. The role of Commissioners should be to:
Monitor the ongoing performance of the Commission
decide policy issues
approve projects/activities beyond the delegated authority of Commission staff.
Exercising this role should lead to a reduction in the amount of material presented to Commissioners for meetings and the material should be confined to:
(a) brief reports of activities-current period and year to date, including progress reports of major ongoing projects;
(b) policy papers; and
(c) submissions on projects/activities beyond the delegated authority of Commission staff.
Response
8. The Government supports the recommendation.
Register of Commissioner's Interests
Recommendations
9. A chronological register of interests of Commissioners should be maintained with the obligation placed on Commissioners to update the register as interests are changed.
Response

9. Section 18 of the ADC Act provides that Commissioners should declare any interests in any matters before the Commission. The ADC has informed the Government that a register of interests is to be completed by Commissioners as at 1 July 1985 and to be maintained thereafter. The Government also requires statements from Commissioners, before their appointment, of any matters that could cause a conflict of interest situation to arise.
National Aboriginal Conference Car Loans
Recommendations

10. The ADC should not have the responsibility for providing motor vehicle loans to NAC members, and that the NAC should take this matter up with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs with a view to satisfactory transport allowances being made for members.
Response
10. The Government accepts that the particular circumstances giving rise to this recommendation are unlikely to occur again in the future.
Staffing Matters
Recommendations

11. The Committee recognises that there are particular staffing difficulties in organisations such as the Commission and that standard ratios of staffing to expenditure should not necessarily apply. The Government should clarify the provisions of section 33(1) of the ADC Act 1980 as to whether the Commission's staff levels are subject to direct Government regulation.

12. The Commission should be given greater freedom to employ the number of people at classifications it sees as necessary to carry out its functions, and be able to self determine the proportion of its budget devoted to staffing and administration expenses.
Response
11. The Government has informed the ADC that, for a trial period of two years, it is free to set its own staffing levels in the light of its own budgetary priorities.

12. The Government considers that a balance must be maintained between staffing and administrative costs and the cost of the Commission's programs. Subject to that, however, the recommendation is supported, consistent with the decision set out above in respect of Rec. 11.
Training
Recommendations

13. The training process should be considered as an integral function of other Commission responsibilities so that funding of housing and enterprise programs can be linked with associated training programs. This is considered to be particularly important in the case of enterprise programs where the basic skills are best learnt on the job rather than in an institutionally provided course. The emphasis on acquisition of enterprises should switch from acquisition per se, to acquisition linked to training and development opportunities.
Response

13. The Government supports the recommendation. It notes that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and other Commonwealth and State agencies also have training responsibilities which complement those of the ADC.
Employment under Commonwealth Public Service Act
Recommendations

14. The majority of persons employed by the Commission should be employed under the Commonwealth Public Service Act with provision for employing a smaller number (say 20%-30%) outside the provisions of the Act.
(NOTE: Mr C. W. Tuckey dissents from this recommendation. His dissent is recorded on page 55)
(Mr Tuckey's comments are at Attachment A to this document).
Response
14. The Government requested the ADC and the Public Service Board to review this recommendation in the light of ss. 33-35 of the ADC Act and current policies relating to public sector employment.
Area Officer Networks
Recommendations

15. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Commission should maintain separate area officer networks but the administrative resources available to officers of both organisations should be rationalised and integrated.
Response
15. The Government is considering rationalisation of administrative elements of the portfolio at local (area office) level.
Housing Responsibilities
Recommendations
16. The Grants-in-Aid Housing program should remain the responsibility of the Commission.

17. The Commission should take over from the DAA responsibility for the supply of services associated with housing; water supply; sewerage; power. In addition services such as the home-maker scheme, which is training in the process of running and caring for a home and therefore not strictly a welfare function, should also become the province of the Commission.
18. Maintenance of the existing stock of housing should receive more attention:
(a) by way of training programs within communities in simple house maintenance tasks associated with the home-maker programs or care of houses and equipment; and
(b) by taking into account in the allocation of funding for new housing, the performance on rent collection and house maintenance of the existing stock of housing.
Response
16. The Government supports the recommendation.
17. As the first stage in such a transfer of functions, responsibility for housing-related matters in Aboriginal communities will be transferred as from 1 July 1985.
18. The Government is concerned that existing houses be adequately maintained and therefore supports the recommendation. The ADC has been requested to take appropriate steps.
Housing Loan Scheme
Recommendations

19. The interest rate and eligibility structure for the housing loans scheme should be restructured to ensure those most in need have highest priority for low interest loans. The restructured scheme should have the following features:
loan interest rates should be tied to bank home loan interest rates, rather than be fixed rates as at the present time;

a discount structure should be established such that the discount from the bank lending rate is a function of the Average Male Weekly Earnings of the person applying for the loan, or some other suitable indicator;
persons in the higher earning categories should receive no discount at all. Persons in this category should not be eligible for loans if there is unsatisfied demand by lower income earners;
criteria for elibility for loans at concessional interest rates should be broadly consistent with those applying in other comparable assistance schemes;
the requirement for borrowers to have been rejected by a lending institution should be abolished;

loans at concessional interest rates for all housing loans should be subject to regular, say, biennial or triennial review to check whether the circumstances of the recipient have changed to the extent that a revised interest rate can be charged;
one lending institution should operate as the Commission's agent for the scheme.

20. To stretch the current housing loan allocation over a wider number of people, schemes such as loan guarantees modelled on the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation from commercial lending institutions and supplements to commercial loans through low interest second mortgages should be urgently pursued. In this way the housing loan money available to the Commission would be used to supplement funds available from other institutions rather than replace them.

21. The arrears position on housing loans is serious. Tighter administration of loans would improve this situation. In particular, implementation of the Commission's computer program for loan processing should be given high priority.
Response

19. The Government agrees that those most in need should have the highest priority for low interest loans. Interest rates and loan terms are a matter for the ADC to determine. The Commission has informed the Government that its housing loans policies, criteria and procedures have been reviewed so as to reflect these recommendations.
20. The ADC has informed the Government that schemes providing housing loan guarantees and second mortgages are already in operation.
21. The ADC has informed the Government that, with the introduction of its housing loan computer system, housing loan arrears should soon be within acceptable limits.
Property Acquisitions
Recommendations

22. The Commission should develop criteria for social value for properties bought either wholly or largely for social purposes in order that priorities can be allocated for purchase and disposal of such properties.
23. Reasons for acquisition of properties falling in the `social/economic' category should be clearly defined before properties are purchased.
24. Those properties meeting neither social nor economic needs should be considered for disposal.
Response

22. The Government supports the development of appropriate criteria against which proposals to acquire and to dispose of land can be considered, and understands that the Commission has set work in train for this purpose.
23. The Government supports the recommendation.

24. The Government agrees that, where properties are of no further value, they should be disposed of. The Commission has informed the Government that a review will be conducted of properties and consideration given to disposal where appropriate.
Financial Commitments to Existing Properties
Recommendations

25. Financial commitments to existing properties should be fully assessed before further land acquisitions are undertaken. Implementation of the Rural Accounting and Management System should significantly assist these assessments.
Response

25. The ADC has informed the Government that, with the introduction of its Rural Accounting Management System, the Commission will have the necessary information available to it during this financial year, and the future.
Title to Existing Properties
Recommendations
26. The transfer to local Aboriginal communities of titles to properties held in the name of the Commission should be expedited.
Response

26. The Government supports this recommendation provided the community is capable of managing the property for the purposes for which it was purchased. Section 27 of the ADC Act makes it clear that the transfer of title in any particular case is a matter for the Commission.
Community Based Enterprises
Recommendations
27. The use of the enterprise program to establish facilities such as stores for isolated Aboriginal communities is supported.
Response
27.The Government supports the recommendation.
Commercially Based Enterprises
Recommendations

28. Before enterprises are funded those which are to be of a commercial nature should be clearly identified. For such enterprises, the initial emphasis should be on establishing commercial viability; social benefits flowing from the profit generated should be seen as a secondary goal. Confusion of the two aims at an early stage seems to be a reason for failure of enterprises. Boards of enterprises should be limited in number to ensure that the enterprise is not burdened with excessive overheads.
29. The evaluation, feasibility and approval process for acquiring commercially based enterprises should be tightened up to:
(a) ensure that full feasibility studies containing future cash flow projections are made before the acquisition takes place;
(b) ensure that reports of the feasibility of the enterprise are obtained from competent, independent persons in the field of the enterprise;

(c) ensure that both the Commission and the enterprise directly have sufficient managerial expertise available to maximise the possibility of success; particular consideration should be given to these resources in the early years of acquisition;

(d) recognise that acquisition of commercial enterprises may generate considerable local hostility and ensure that the plan of acquisition takes steps to minimise this hostility when it may be prejudicial to the future of the enterprise;
(e) appoint outside directors with experience in that industry to the board of the enterprise;
(f) provide on-going monitoring of each enterprise program to ensure that it is achieving its objectives whether social or economic or a combination of these;
(g) prevent funding of the enterprise if resources are not available to provide this monitoring and direction.
Response
28. The Government supports the recommendation.
29. The Government supports this recommendation and has been informed by the Commission that it is intending to review its policy and procedures in this area.
ADC Officers as Directors of Enterprises
Recommendations

30. The roles and responsibilities of Commission officers appointed as directors to boards of enterprises should be clearly spelt out, particularly with regard to their responsibilities to keep the Commission informed of the enterprise's progress compared with plans. Commission officers should be indemnified against action that can be taken against them, for matters other than personal negligence, in their role as directors.
Response

30. The Government agrees that the roles of officers appointed as Director, etc., should be clearly defined and is of the view that they should be afforded the same protection as Commonwealth Public Servants are in similar circumstances.
Aboriginal Ownership and Control of Projects
Recommendations

31. Aboriginal ownership and control of projects should remain a focus of the enterprise program but where Aboriginals have few relevant skills gradual transfer of ownership and control as expertise is built up should be considered.

32. The joint venture approach whereby the Commission is able to supply capital to an existing entrepreneur and acquire a share of the business (not necessarily a controlling one) in return for a program of employment and training for Aboriginal staff should be utilised.
Response
31. The Government agrees with this recommendation.
32. The Government agrees with this recommendation.
Training and the Enterprise Program
Recommendations

33. The enterprise function should be considered integrally with the training function so that training in management and entrepreneurial skills is given equal, if not greater importance, than actually acquiring Aboriginal enterprises.
Response

33. The Government has been informed that the ADC has taken steps in this direction and is currently reviewing its training policy in the context of this recommendation. (See also response to recommendation 13.)
Conversion of Enterprise Loans to Grants
Recommendations
34. The necessary changes to administrative procedures to obviate the need in some circumstances to initially make grants to social organisations as loans should be implemented as soon as possible.

35. Under only exceptional circumstances should loans be converted to grants. The Commission should consider rescheduling loans in instances of seasonal hardship or other unforeseen circumstances but where mismanagement has occurred, foreclosure should be instituted.
Response
34. The ADC has informed the Government that this recommendation has been put into effect.
35. The Government supports the recommendation. In relation to foreclosure action, the Commission has stated that it follows a policy of considering each case on its merits.
RECOMMENDATION 14-DISSENT

The ADC Act has as its principal objective the granting of autonomy on decision-making to the Aboriginal people. It should not be necessary to impose Public Service Board staff or auditors upon the Commission to achieve its proper function. The extent to which the Commission is already inhibited by Public Service controls is an example of the problems that extension to full Public Service coverage would create.

The suggestion that there be persons employed inside and outside the Public Service must create problems including the opportunity to make selective appointments outside the Public Service. Recommendation 14 presumes that the Public Service Board is the repository of the skills and knowledge suitable for the operations of the ADC. I believe the private sector, particularly the merchant banks, would be a better source for many positions.

The suggestion that the Public Service Board would offer protection for Commission employees from improper interference from the Chairman or Commissioners ignores the responsibility of the Minister in his appointment of the Commissioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I turn now to the final report. The final report makes no new recommendations but does present some findings to the House. The findings relate to allegations made to the Committee about certain actions of people connected with the ADC, including the former Chairman and now Secretary of my Department. The majority of the Committee notes the explanations given and has accepted that the allegations are groundless; some of the honourable members opposite have, however, put in a dissenting report.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already informed the House of my views on this matter and do not propose to do so again. I should inform the House, however, that the Government does not intend to appoint a judge to inquire into the administration of the Aboriginal affairs portfolio. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The events leading up to the statement by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) in response to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure inquiring into the Aboriginal Development Commission have caused great disquiet to the Opposition. Firstly, I point out for the benefit of the House that this is the first report, of which I am aware, on which a committee was forced to divide and bring down a minority report. In fact, the Opposition has been concerned that the manner in which this inquiry was conducted and the failure of the Government members, particularly the Chairman, to support the recommendations contained in the minority reports-which essentially contained the fact that the matters examined should be referred to a judicial inquiry-has had the effect of denying natural justice to those witnesses who appeared before the Committee and whose reputations may have been damaged by the Committee's failure to give them the opportunity of a thorough examination of the allegations against them. As the Minister has pointed out, one of those people was in fact the Secretary to his Department. The reputations may therefore remain forever in what I call the limbo of public conjecture.

SPEECH.PARA: The Expenditure Committee of the Parliament cannot function effectively unless there is a large measure of bipartisan support. The events which culminated in the tabling of the Committee's report show clearly that the Committee is seriously divided and while it remains so on issues such as this, it will lose credibility and it will be incapable of carrying out its traditional functions of advising the Parliament on the efficiency of government expenditure. Both the standing and quality of any parliamentary committee depend ultimately on the ability of the Chairman to manage the affairs of the Committee in a proper, reasonable and responsible manner.

If I may go to the detail of the comments made by the Minister this evening in relation specifically to the ADC, I point out that this organisation was established as an independent national corporation by the previous Fraser Government in 1980. The Minister has gone to some pains to emphasise that any shortcomings in the administration of the Authority during the period covered by the initial and the subsequent report were in fact the responsibility of that government. Nevertheless, when that organisation was established it replaced the Aboriginal Loans Commission and the Aboriginal Land Fund, which had been set up in the mid-1970s. It was controlled by a board of about 10 Aboriginal commissioners. The ADC's main tasks are to distribute housing grants and low interest home loans to Aboriginals, assist indigenous enterprises and to help communities to acquire land. I agree with the Minister that the objectives of the ADC are excellent and provided they are conducted in an efficient and effective manner one would hope that in due course we will see that the indigenous people of Australia in particular gain substantially from their association with it.

The aim of the ADC is to become self-sufficient. I regard it as a matter of some concern that the present government has in fact allowed the contributions to the capital account to fall to zero. That may create major problems in the future. In terms of funding of the ADC and, in fact, in terms of funding of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in toto, it should be noted that total grants to the ADC since its inception were some $322.1m, while total grants to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs since 1982 alone are in excess of $1,010m. The attitude of the Minister is to give handouts of money without necessarily looking in depth at the real problems facing the Aboriginal community. I had the occasion to point this out to the Minister last night. It is a very multi-party problem that effectively for at least the last 15 years vast sums of money have been spent in trying to solve the problems of the Aboriginal community of Australia. I am sorry to say that if one looks at health and various other areas, we still have an enormous way to go. The World Health Organisation figures show in some areas that we have in fact gone backwards, despite the substantial funding that has been allocated. All I am simply saying is that we need to look in greater depth at the problems and make sure that the solutions to them are cost effective. There is reason to doubt that.

As the then Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee I conducted the first investigation into the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in 1976-77 and identified many of these problems. I am not at all certain that the identification has necessarily led to satisfactory solutions in all cases. No doubt the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), who was with me in those days, would perhaps find similar reasons as well. In terms of the Authority, the reason why Opposition members emphasised in their minority report that they believed a judicial inquiry was necessary was based on the recommendations of the Coombs report which was given to the Committee and which has not been made public. As I understand it, it has never been tabled in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Coombs report has been.

—I am glad to hear that. Legal counsel was employed by the Committee at a cost of some $5,000. There is sufficient reason in the comments contained in that report to give substance to the claim of the Opposition members that a further judicial inquiry ought to be carried out. The fact of the matter is that these recommendations contain certain matters relating to the Australian Federal Police. Members of the Committee chose to ignore that advice and proceeded with the investigations themselves, although they were advised that to do so they were venturing into a field effectively beyond the expertise of any parliamentary committee. Is it any wonder, therefore, that honourable members on this side of the chamber believe having identified individuals but not having necessarily carried out a thorough investigation, that it is preferable that those matters be examined by extra-parliamentary bodies, which are better equipped to do that sort of work. The Public Accounts Committe on many occasions has found a similar sort of problem in that there are difficulties for Parliamentary committees to get into areas which may be on the edge of illegality.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for that reason, as well as the fact I mentioned earlier that some $322.1m has already been allocated to the ADC since its inception, and the continuous stream of allegations, suggestions, Press reports and other sources of intelligence, all leading to the conclusion that the level of administration of the ADC is open to some doubt, that this inquiry was conducted in the first place. I would like to draw the attention of the Minister to a fact that he is probably aware of, that on no less than three occasions between 1982 and September 1985 the Auditor-General has drawn attention to matters concerning the administration of the ADC. For example, in his September 1982 report he said:

Results of the audit of the Commission as at March 1981 revealed weaknesses in internal control, absence of written instructions and procedures, and incomplete accounts for fixed assets, advances, investments and shares.
In September 1984 the Auditor-General, referring to accounting and other records, reported that:
Deficiencies in internal controls and accounting and other records and non-compliance with certain approved procedures were disclosed during the audit.
These included certain items. For the benefit of the House, I seek leave to incorporate the further comments in Hansard.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that case I will read it into Hansard. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: These included:
assets acquired and disposed of during the year had not been recorded in the Commission's asset register
the results of the stocktake of assets, which had been conducted in 1982-83, had not been reconciled with the asset register

instances were noted where approved procedures for periodic reviews had not been followed to ensure that borrowers were still engaged in the business enterprises for which loans had been made and that securities for loans were adequately insured
That is a very serious allegation. The report continues:
instances were noted of overpayments of allowances and of non-compliance with prescribed procedures in the processing of salary variations and the maintenance of personnel records
control over the approval and acquittance of travel advances was inadequate in some cases, and
accounting records and other documentation was deficient in respect of a number of housing loans.
In September 1985 the Auditor-General went on to say, again referring to accounting and other records:
Deficiencies in internal controls and accounting and other records and non-compliance with certain approved procedures were disclosed during the audit. These included:
inadequate maintenance of the asset register and no reconciliation to the general ledger
inaccurate general ledger records and lack of reconciliation with subsidiary data for housing and enterprise loans, and
absence of formal Commission policy regarding conditions for the conversion of loans to grants.

The financial statements of the Commission for 1983-84 record that a review of related documentation disclosed a total of $234,267 (at cost) in assets that could not be substantiated by stocktake records. It is noted in the accounts that, in the interest of a conservative statement of assets, this amount was written off during the year.

There are reasons why people continue to be concerned about the administration of the ADC. Since then other allegations have been made in this particular area. It is worth noting that the current Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs said in November 1983 to a semi-private meeting on Thursday Island that about 460 Commission business enterprises were going bad, and I quote:

We have got what they call a moratorium on business enterprises for individuals. Why we have done this is because we've got 460 business enterprises out at the moment and they're all going bad . . . or most of them are, anyhow. We're having great difficulty with them.
That is the Secretary to the Department, who was previously the head of the Aboriginal Development Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the source of that?

—It is a newspaper source. The ADC has been accused by Aboriginals of being an exclusive group of commissioners and staff that does not bother to consult with ordinary Aboriginal people about its programs and therefore does not know what is going on. In June 1984 a former Chairman of the National Aboriginal Conference claimed that the ADC had a lot to answer for to the Aboriginal people of Australia and that only a royal commission would get to the bottom of the problem. So not only the Opposition but also members of the Aboriginal community are asking for an inquiry. The co-ordinator of the South Australian Aboriginal trachoma and eye health program said that there is a great deal of disquiet in Aboriginal communities about how the ADC spends its money. A former ADC project officer and Deputy Chairman of Aboriginal Hostels Limited said that there is no doubt that all the decision-making power in Aboriginals affairs is concentrated in a small elite group in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: These accusations have continued. The ADC has been accused by the Ralkon Agricultural Company of South Australia, a farming company controlled by Aboriginals of the Point McLeay area on the Eyre Peninsula, of attempting to influence improperly the outcome of elections for the Point McLeay community council, threatening to suspend funding to the community unless the council passed resolutions requested by the ADC to support ADC action, and paying consultants for purposes not authorised by the Act under which the ADC operates. In addition, we have other examples such as the Gwydir Property Aboriginal Corporation. The ADC is meeting the funding for the Corporation's capital and recurrent accounts. The organisation operates a separate rent account into which all rent receipts are or should be paid. There is no trusteeship or co-signatory arrangement for this account, which is operated entirely by the directors. It is in the area of receipts for this account that moneys have been misused.

The accountant's dual role of financial adviser and trustee contains an inherent conflict. The antipathy felt by the directors towards the accountant, because of his policing role in the administration of the grant funds, has strained communication to the point where it is very difficult for the accountant to provide training or effective advice to the Corporation. We are told of extremely poorly run organisation and unaccounted rent receipts. None of the Corporation's 10 houses is insured, rates are owed to the council in respect of both 1981 and the current year, and there is a lack of simple maintenance of dwellings, even of houses whose tenants are not in rent arrears. Both the area office and the Corporation's accountant stated that it is almost impossible to arrange a meeting with the directors to discuss financial or other matters of concern. When pressed about the standard of the Corporation's records and general administration, the directors and employees professed some ignorance of such complexities. The deterioration of the records suggests at least an unwillingness to observe rudimentary management practices.

In addition, we have the situation of the Inada arts and craft shop in Perth. Inada Holdings is renting a retail outlet in Perth at a total cost of $18,000 a year, or $1,500 a month. The shop is alleged to have hardly opened its doors in the last eight months. Inada has already received about $500,000 from the ADC and is expected to receive a similar amount in its second year. I refer also to the ADC's involvement with the company Boomerang Insurances. Boomerang Insurances went into liquidation in 1983. A firm of solicitors claimed that its client, the Mercantile Mutual Life Insurance group, had not received $43,000 it lent to the company in 1982 which had been guaranteed by the ADC. In 1984 a former commissioner of the ADC failed to supply details of how a $90,000 grant to an Aboriginal community in Western Australia would be spent. The $90,000 grant from the Commission was to help establish a cattle enterprise on reserve land in north-western Australia. It is reported that the commissioner had refused to take advice on how the money should be allocated or how priorities should be drawn up, or even follow basic economic principles such as obtaining quotes. A $100,000 mackerel fishing venture by an Aboriginal group collapsed after being plagued by a constant drain of funds and loose overall control by the ADC.

The point I am trying to make is that giving Aboriginal organisations money but not being prepared to give them adequate backup and administrative support is a guaranteed way of ultimately doing no good for the Aboriginal community and certainly of wasting taxpayers' funds. Ultimately, when ventures of this type fail it is the Aboriginal community that is often left holding the baby and being held responsible. For all these reasons the Opposition was completely justified in coming forward at the time of the tabling of this report and recommending that there be a legal inquiry into the affairs of the Aboriginal Development Commission. I simply say to the Minister, on the basis of what he said tonight, that he has accepted responsibility and we will hold him to it.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian War Memorial-Mr John Wiseman-Premier Town Award-Cosmetic Toiletry and Fragrance Association of Australia-Interest Rates-RAAF Guard Dog-Scarborough: Television Reception-Sri Lanka

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, tonight I would like to raise an important matter in relation to the Australian War Memorial, a national institution which enjoys a very special place in the hearts and minds of most Australians, especially those who have served their country in time of war. I might add that it has been in recent years the most visited institution in the national capital, reflecting the high standing of the War Memorial and related museum, as thousands upon thousands of Australians have attended, amongst other things to pay their respects to those who made the supreme sacrifice for their country.

SPEECH.PARA: Administration of the Australian War Memorial now comes under the jurisdiction of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Arthur Gietzelt, who became the Minister responsible following the 1 December election last year and the subsequent transfer of the Australian War Memorial from the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. There is an appointed Council for the Australian War Memorial under the chairmanship of Dame Beryl Beaurepaire, and I point out that it is a council which elects its own chairman. The Council includes the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) and a wide cross-section of people with particular reference to the armed forces and the veterans' community. The Director is Air Vice-Marshal J. H. Flemming, AO, DFC, AM (United States), FAIM, and he has served in that position for some two and a half years.

Before proceeding further, it is fair to say that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has had ministerial responsibility for only a relatively short time-in fact, less than one year. Nevertheless, ministerial responsibility does rest with that Minister, and yesterday he chose to give an explanation in relation to management problems at the Australian War Memorial. Those remarks followed on the comments of a former senior curator of military technology at the Australian War Memorial from 1980 to 1985, Mr J. R. Heaton, who said, amongst other things:
There are problems that have greatly reduced the ability of the staff at the institution to provide a full service to the public.

It takes a considerable time to develop a full understanding of the aims and objectives of the Memorial and to acquire a detailed knowledge of its vast and complex collections. The current top management, however, has allowed staff morale to fall to a critically low level. The rapid staff turnover provides ample proof of this. There are more than 30 professional staff positions, but over the past 18 months the Memorial has lost an assistant director of collections, two senior curators, the senior exhibitions designer, the head of the conservation section and two specialised conservators, and a curator in the research area, along with a senior administrative officer.

Mr Heaton adds his contention that the staff are speaking with their feet by leaving. He says that a considerable number of other experienced curatorial staff members are either actively seeking employment elsewhere or, though unwilling to move, are unhappy with the existing management. Mr Heaton concludes that the Australian War Memorial is `in a state of internal crisis which indeed deserves a closer scrutiny of its top management'.

Information made available to me would indicate that the comments made by Mr Heaton are relevant and accurate and highlight the fact that many key people have left the Australian War Memorial over recent times. Let us refer to the Minister's statement. Senator Gietzelt said yesterday in another place:

I have satisfied myself, that to a great extent, his allegations have very little substance. All those who have held senior positions at the Australian War Memorial and have left in recent years have done so for personal reasons associated with domestic problems, career advancement or moving to institutions of a similar nature.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs was simply wrong in his contention and advice to the Senate yesterday. Indeed, his response smacks of a cover up in the best Yes Minister style or, alternatively, a real failure to investigate the situation fully. The facts are that the Australian War memorial has been haemorrhaging badly at the specialist middle management level, with a loss of personnel far in excess of what might be regarded as normal turnover. There are particular reasons for this, and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has the absolute responsibility to investigate comprehensively and then take corrective action. I serve notice that I will continue to monitor the Australian War Memorial situation closely for a host of reasons, not the least of which is its very special place as a national institution in honour of those who served their country in time of war and who made the supreme sacrifice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to tell honourable members the story of one of my constituents. I do not normally bring constituent matters before the House in this way, but I believe it is an appropriate course of action to take in this case. The constituent involved is a man by the name of John Wiseman. Mr Wiseman is a qualified ship's radio operator and until 1976 he had experienced a long and satisfactory career in this field. One could say he had a good employment record. In that year an incident occurred which was to change his life dramatically and, I might add, not for the better.

SPEECH.PARA: The incident to which I refer happened early in June 1976 on board the British flag, Australian chartered chemical tanker, the Silver Harrier. As she crossed Bass Strait, the ship struck a storm of intense fury, described as a force 10 gale. My constituent was the radio officer on board and during the crossing he lost the capacity to transmit emergency calls. As such, the ship and its crew were in a position of great risk. Luckily, the ship was able to make it to port quite safely.

Mr Wiseman, of course, reported the loss of radio signal to the ship's master and made a formal report of the affair. Having considerable knowledge of radio operations he made an initial investigation to determine the cause of the signal loss. He came up with the theory that the radio transmitter's signal had been interrupted because of sea spray thrown up on the aerials during the rough passage. The main problem, he believed, lay with the aerial insulators which were made of fibreglass. Fibreglass holds salt particularly well and wet salt is a well-known conductor of electricity, the aerials being charged with a high voltage to signal.

Following the storm, Mr Wiseman believed the ship unsafe to sail. He refused to travel to Melbourne when asked by the ship's master and was given a bad conduct discharge. As a result of this he has found it almost impossible to get work within Australian waters. In the nine years since the incident he has had only 37 months work, mainly in overseas operations. Believing he was correct, Mr Wiseman did not let the matter rest, he studied the problem further and has now written some seven articles in well-known international magazines about his investigations. The latest of these appears in the August 1985 edition of Safety at Sea which is published in England.

At the same time, he took up the matter with the responsible authorities. His formal report of the incident was sent to the Department of Transport, which has responsibility for maritime safety. In turn, the Postal and Telecommunications Department, as it was known then, became involved because the telecommunications aspects of sea safety are delegated to this Department, the Department of Transport having no one of sufficient technical expertise to investigate such matters.

The Postal and Telecommunications Department did a survey of the radio installations on board the Silver Harrier after the storm. The report stated that the vessel was fit for sea. Further surveys confirmed the original assessment.

Mr Wiseman was dissatisfied with these results and, as I mentioned earlier, spent considerable time building up his case on the Silver Harrier and the problems of fibreglass insulators. He took up the question of the survey results with some vengeance following his return to Australia, after a period overseas, in 1983.

Using material obtained under the Freedom of Information Act and as a result of a leaked document he obtained, Mr Wiseman became most concerned that the original survey had not been properly undertaken; that is, that the conditions which the Silver Harrier met in Bass Strait were not reproduced accurately in the survey tests.

My constituent now alleges that the two departments involved tried to cover up the fact that the original survey was bodgy. I remind honourable members that this occurred some years ago, prior to this Government coming into office.

For the information of honourable members, I will provide a couple of choice quotes which appear to support Mr Wiseman's claims. The first is, from a file note of the original surveyor of the Silver Harrier dated January 1977. It states:

I am disturbed at the implications of querying surveyors ability . . . if they (the British Board of Trade which determines the regulations) are going to alter the aerials of the Silver Harrier it places us in a very difficult position of having 5-6 of our official surveys contradicted.
The second is from the leaked document which I mentioned earlier, entitled `Minute to Radio Surveyor 10/1982'. In part, it stated:
Tests conducted in various states by the Department-
the Department of Communications in conjunction with the Department of Transport-
confirms that such insulation-
that is, fibreglass-
becomes most inefficient in wet weather . . . and represents a safely hazard and may prevent emergency communications in adverse weather conditions.
In a private handwritten note at the bottom of a letter sent to Mr Wiseman, the Ombudsman said:

`Mr Wiseman is probably on sound technical ground and we may have `missed the boat' in our earlier investigation, understandably because the insulator resistance/seawater conducting question was never satisfactorily explained to us.
What about giving Mr Wiseman a fair go?

—I thank the honourable member. Furthermore, Hamilton, Portland and Warrnambool, together with the south-east of South Australia, form part of an area known as the Green Triangle. It comprises most of the electorate of Wannon and part of the electorate of Barker, which is represented by my colleague the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter). These areas have all contributed to the betterment of the Green Triangle. The achievement of the three major centres in Wannon will do much to enhance the Green Triangle.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I say that it is a great honour, as the member for Wannon, to be able to represent such a great area in this Parliament. I think the towns of Hamilton, Portland and Warrnambool, have all, in their own right, demonstrated what a great part of Australia is south-western Victoria and what a great contribution it will make to the future. As I have said, it is not just the towns but the people in them who have achieved this success. They have achieved it in an area with limited natural advantages. We do not have snow fields and we have limited beach facilities, yet the people have won premier town awards.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have more beaches than the southern coast. What are you talking about?

—We have some special attractions. I remind the honourable member for Melbourne that we have the southern right whale which comes to the beaches of Warrnambool every winter. To anyone who has not seen it it is well worth a visit. It is one of the great marvels of the sea. The whales almost became extinct a few years ago. Fortunately, they are slowly breeding up, but I understand that even today there are few more than 1,500 southern right whales in the world. Warrnambool is one of only three places in the world where these whales can be seen from the beach. I congratulate Hamilton and Portland on their achievements in the premier town award and Warrnambool on its achievement in 1979.

—Today, along with every other member of the House, I had delivered to my room a package which contained a number of toiletry articles. It came with a letter from the Cosmetic Toiletry and Fragrance Association of Australia. There are two things I wish briefly to say about this. —I will be returning mine, and I hope that every other member of the House will be returning his or her's. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nearly 2,000 years ago Roman emperors initiated policies designed to placate their restless populations. The free bread and circuses policies, as they were known, were no more than a blatant and cynical attempt to take the minds of citizens from the problems of a declining empire and, instead, to focus those minds on immediate pleasures with no thought for the future. Like some flickering re-run of a Cecil B. De Mille movie, South Australians are witnessing the decline and fall of the Bannon Government as it desperately seeks the quick-fix solutions to the deep-rooted problems which it has, with Labor in Canberra, caused and with which it is quite unable to cope. Eight days ago the South Australian Government initiated a free bread and circuses policy of its own-a policy designed, as it was 2,000 years ago, to divert the attention of an electorate-in this case one increasingly tired of State Labor's incompetence.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the decision on 1 October by the Bannon Government to subsidise increases in current building society interest rates for just six months. Under the scheme the South Australian financing authority will invest $30m and in the process forgo $3m of interest. The money is to be used to pay South Australian building societies so that a recent 0.75 per cent increase in interest rates is not passed on to existing building society borrowers, at least for the next six months. Why would the State Government have done such a curious thing? For no other reason than to prop up the flagging fortunes of the Bannon Government because it hopes that in the process somehow it may be able to recover a few percentage points in the opinion polls and win the next State election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just six months.

—The move will provide assistance to some 25,000 people who, not surprisingly, are concentrated in several key State electorates-electorates which must be won or retained if the Bannon Government is to survive, which it will not. But it will not assist the other 250,000 South Australians who have home loans with the State Bank, the Commonwealth Bank, the private trading banks and so on. It will not help most South Australians faced with spiralling interest rates. They are all being ignored. It will not help new borrowers from building societies; it will not help small businesses struggling to service their loans. It will help just a tiny minority who are being used for political purposes, and it will help them, as the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) rightly said, for just six months.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members do not need to be reminded that by the end of that six months the State election will have come and gone. No wonder that the unanimous verdict of Press commentators, bankers, businessmen and economists is that this is little more than a cynical political move, a pork-barrelling exercise of the worst kind. Even the Federal Government has refused to endorse this cynical scheme-and I hear no endorsement coming from the other side of the House tonight. The Federal Labor Party knows, as does everyone else, that this band-aid measure will do nothing to mitigate the impact of spiralling interest rates. It knows that it is just a waste of money. Whether he likes it or not, the Premier of South Australia and his colleagues the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) hold total responsibility for the increases in interest rates which are causing hardship in the mortgage belts of Adelaide and in other capital cities. Their incompetence has caused the collapse of the Australian dollar, and that collapse has guaranteed the rise in interest rates. Interest rates in South Australia are now in real terms five times as high as they were when the Tonkin Government was defeated in 1982. That is the legacy partly of the Bannon Government and partly of the present Federal Government.

Whenever the next State election is held, Mr Bannon will be confronting the electors with this cynical exercise under his belt, and with other cynical exercises, such as the tax cuts he promised not for a long time but for just one year and a freeze on State bank loans for just three months. These measures are designed to deceive the South Australian people and that deceit will be rewarded at the next State election by the ejection of the Premier, Mr Bannon, and his deceitful and absurd Government and will result in the election of Mr Olsen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to take a few minutes of the time of the House to raise an issue on behalf of a man who has just left the Royal Australian Air Force-Brendan Prendergast, from Stratford in Victoria. Brendan served in the RAAF for some nine years and for the last six years was responsible for guard dog work and guard dog work in that service. Over the last six years Brendan worked with a dog called Sheriff. No doubt many people have heard of this case in the last few weeks because it has become somewhat of an issue whether this dog's life should be saved or whether it should be put down. Some months back, in April, Brendan Prendergast applied to the RAAF for permission to take the dog with him when he was discharged from the Air Force. The process was put into operation for the dog to be assessed and in the first instance Brendan was given permission for the dog to be released with him. It appeared at that stage that his request would be carried out.

SPEECH.PARA: However, on about 2 September the dog had to undergo a special test. In that test the dog, which is now nine years old-way past the normal age for a dog working in the RAAF-performed extremely well in its duties as a guard dog. This created a problem in regard to the dog's release. Under the orders and agreements within the RAAF under which dogs can be released, a dog has to show some sign that it is losing interest as a guard dog in order for it to be eligible for release with its handler. Another requirement is that the dog must be able to be handled by other people. These two areas have caused problems in deciding whether the dog shall be released.

There seem to be discrepancies in the opinions of experts on this case. This matter was raised with me and I took it up with the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). Brendan left the Force a few weeks back and we have been able to have a stay of execution on the dog until such time as an investigation takes place. We have now reached the situation where in normal circumstances the dog itself would be treated as a guard dog and be put down, but there has been such public interest in this issue that I have received possibly more letters on this matter than on most other issues I deal with. I think other people have also received many representations.

Consideration must also be given to the public good. A guard dog should not be released in a local town if there is a possibility that it could attack somebody if it is upset. So, a very strong case can be argued one way or the other in this situation. No doubt a major decision will have to be taken in regard to this Alsatian or German Shepherd dog. I quite clearly appreciate the RAAF's position. If the indications are that the dog cannot be deprogrammed and returned to normal society, I think the RAAF would have a responsibility to see that the dog was not released. However, regardless of what happens, I am not of the opinion that the dog should be put down. I think a dog that has served the amount of time that this dog has with the RAAF should in some way be allowed to see its life out and not be destroyed. There must be some use for it within society.

The position at the moment is that the Minister has called for reports on the dog. We are still waiting on a reply from him. I am making a plea to him that the dog should not under any circumstances be put down. I think the life of the dog should be preserved. I also understand Brendan Prendergast's position. He has worked with the dog for six years and is quite confident that he can look after it. Therefore, I hope that the decision on this matter will turn out for the good, one way or the other. I do not think that a beautiful animal such as this should be put down when it has served so well for so many years. I hope that the Minister can give us an answer within a week about the future of the dog.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support in one sense the comments of the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) and, in another sense, to query the matters that he has put before the House. As the honourable member would be aware, I support his plea to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to save the life of the dog known as Sheriff. I also know Brendan Prendergast and his family. I have been involved for some time now in this affair that has become so widely known and which has involved so many sympathisers who have written to me and expressed concern. My query relates to the form of inquiry which the honourable member for McMillan and the Minister have announced. I understand that the inquiry will involve nothing more than the seeking of advice from the Department of Defence on possibly deprogramming Sheriff and his release into the community. I join with the honourable member for McMillan in making a plea for the life of Sheriff. However, I also make a plea to the Minister to conduct an independent bona fide inquiry and not merely one that is a rubber stamp of the Department's views. From the very start of my inquiries I have been advised by the Royal Australian Air force at every level that this dog would be a complete and utter danger to the community if released in the care of Brendan. I am quite certain what the advice would be if the Minister simply asks his Department for an opinion on the deprogramming of this dog. The advice will amount to simply nothing more than a temporary stay of execution, to use the words of the honourable member for McMillan.

SPEECH.PARA: It is incumbent upon the honourable member and the Minister to quash the concerns which are increasing day by day that this inquiry will be a complete and utter sham. What sort of inquiry will it be if the RAAF gives the Minister the views that it has already expressed to me on numerous occasions? Where would be the independence in such an inquiry? Moreover, what opportunity will Brendan Prendergast and his family have to put the independent views of experts to this so-called inquiry? I understand that the Prendergast family are able to obtain sworn documents from a whole range of experts in regard to German Shepherd guard dogs which show that this dog can be deprogrammed and is not a menace to society. What opportunity will there be for these matters to be put before an inquiry? Instead, it is becoming increasingly clear that either the honourable member for McMillan, the Minister, or both, have cynically resorted to cynical opportunism to quash what is a matter of real public concern.

The Minister acted quickly as soon as the publicity about this dog started steamrolling right throughout the printed and electronic media in Victoria. I invite the honourable member for McMillan to explain the nature of that inquiry to this chamber and to the Prendergast family. If he is unable to show that the inquiry will be independently conducted and that the Prendergasts and experts will have the opportunity to appear before that inquiry and submit evidence, the whole exercise will be a sham and the honourable member and the Minister will rightly stand convicted of political opportunism and cynicism of the worst kind.

I support what the honourable member has said about the dog. I am instructed by the family that it is not what is called a siege dog. Like the honourable member for McMillan, I would like expert evidence to be given before we act in the public interest and release the dog into the hands of Brendan Prendergast. My absolute concern and the concern of many of my constituents, not least the Prendergast family, who have contacted me, is that there will be no independent inquiry. I warn the honourable member and the Minister that if there is no independent inquiry and the Minister acts only on the advice of the RAAF, which has made its views abundantly clear, I will raise the matter again in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to address myself very clearly to a problem that has arisen in Scarborough in my electorate concerning a high-rise block that the Bond Corporation has built near the beach for use during the America's Cup. This development has caused a major problem for the residents of Scarborough whose television reception is being totally disrupted. In fact, hundreds and hundreds of residents of this area are receiving a shadowed television signal.

The people of Scarborough are now seeking some redress from the Bond Corporation, which, to its credit, has been engaged in negotiations with myself and the State member for Scarborough to try to resolve the problem. We believe that the only way the problem can be resolved is by installing a relay transmitter on top of the Bond Corporation building at a cost of between $50,000 and $60,000. The relay, in effect, will turn the original VHF television signal into a UHF signal to enable people to receive a clear television picture. However, the problem has become very acute because television provides a major form of entertainment for some people in my area who are very old or invalid. The husband of one person who wrote to me is an invalid pensioner who suffered injuries during the war. More recently he has had a stroke. In fact, he cannot speak and his only form of entertainment is watching television. He is an example of the people whose lives have been totally disrupted by the construction of this building. Television interference is so great that they cannot receive any television signal from any of the available channels, namely, channels 2, 7 and 9.

Unfortunately, recent information which has been given to the people of Scarborough indicates that the problem is likely to go away in some 30 working days when a crane will be taken down from the top of the building. The reality is that the problem will not go away. The crane will not come down in some 30 working days. In fact, the Bond Corporation has said to me that the problem will remain until next February. But even after that point, because of the amount of structural steel that is in this concrete and steel structure, the problem may never disappear. That brings us squarely to the position: Why have we got the problem? We have the problem because the building has been approved by what was then the Liberal dominated Metropolitan Regional Planning Authority. It showed no concern at all for the local people. The Liberal-controlled local council has also shown no concern.

My view is that the local people ought to be taking legal action because there clearly is a case of negligence to be established in terms of the planners. There also should be a much quicker reaction by the Bond Corporation. The reason for that very simply is that for some months now people have had this disruption to their lives. I say simply to the people of Scarborough that if they are having television interference they should not get a new television or a new antenna. In fact, they should seek as a community to redress the problem. I am happy to work with them in seeking some redress. I am hopeful that the Bond Corporation will see the good sense in the need to install a transmitter on top of the building to try to overcome the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1978 I attended a parliamentary conference in Sri Lanka on population and development. It was the first time I had been out of Australia. Things that occurred at that conference have probably left an indelible mark on me in the sense that the island of Sri Lanka is the size of Tasmania; Tasmania has a population of 400,000 and Sri Lanka has a population of 14 million, which is roughly the same population as that of Australia. Of course, Australia seems to be the lucky country. We certainly were in those days. In 1978 we had a belief that zero population growth would occur by the year 2000. One thinks about population and development because, I suppose, they are inextricably bound together.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought about Australia being a lucky country, about the year 2000 and zero population growth, and about Australia being a large continent. But also one wondered about the reason for zero population growth. At that time, I think from memory, there were about 90,000 abortions and we allowed about 90,000 people to come into Australia for immigration and compassionate reasons. So one could understand that other countries would look at Australia in a peculiar sort of way. As soon as one walked out of the hotel into the streets in Sri Lanka one saw absolute poverty-babies being bathed in the street gutters and poor people with the look of loneliness in their eyes, the look of wanting something but not being able to get it at all. I continually made comparisons with what I know in Australia. So, of course, I changed dramatically. Since that time I have been to quite a few conferences on this subject but I have found that it is not a very fashionable subject to talk about. If one talked about uranium or peace and disarmament many people would listen.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have never seen this quite compassionate side of your nature.

—No. Usually Hansard hates me when I speak and the Speaker wakes up. I start ranting and raving about the things that may occur in this country. But I think very seriously about other things. I am pleased that my colleague realises that. I went to India and after talking to people there I realised that we in Australia should start to realise that two-thirds of the total world population live in absolute poverty compared with what we have. For example, babies die in India because the mothers cannot read the prescription which would save the babies from dying of diarrhoea. There are lots of things we can do.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that parliamentarians should get involved in this subject. I think a committee should be formed in this Parliament to talk about it and to have contact with other countries, particularly developing countries, which have these massive problems. We do not have them in Australia. We have our arguments about immigration and other matters. But we need to be aware that developing countries have massive problems to which parliamentarians should sometimes address themselves rather than these other fashionable subjects into which many people put a lot of effort. But really they do not do us very much good in the long term. I think we need to do that. I will be talking to Mr Speaker with the hope that I can form just a very small committee to talk about this very important subject of population and development which will have a massive effect on what we do in Australia in the long term.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
